INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death, on 28 September 1987, of Sir Keith Cameron Wilson, a former Senator for South Australia and a former member of the House of Representatives.

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on 28 September 1987, of Sir Keith Cameron Wilson, a Senator for the State of South Australia from 1938 to 1944 and a former member of the House of Representatives for the division of Sturt from 1945 to 1954 and from 1955 to 1966, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service, and tenders its profound sympathy to his widow and family in their bereavement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition, I wish to support the motion of condolence moved by the Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans. My last contact with the late Sir Keith Wilson was in a most appropriate context in terms of the contribution that he made to Australia. It was at a splendid aged persons centre at Noarlunga in South Australia which Sir Keith had been asked to open and which I attended as a guest as the then Minister for Social Security. It was particularly appropriate because Sir Keith Wilson made a major-indeed, a dominant-contribution to the establishment of the system of housing for the aged which has been such a feature of the past 30 years in Australia. Sir Keith Wilson's political and other life is a substantial reminder of the capacity of individual Australians to change for the better the society into which they are born.

SPEECH.PARA: Sir Keith Wilson is also a reminder to the many people who serve in parliament but who never serve in government as a Minister that it is possible to make a major contribution to government policy and to the administration of one's country from the back bench. Sir Keith Wilson served as a senator for a period and was distinguished from every other senator who served in this place in that he left the Senate to enlist in the Army and served his country overseas whilst a senator. That, of course, is a very great mark of his devotion to his country. But I have no doubt that he will be long remembered publicly not for the fact that he served in two Houses or that he served in the armed forces at the same time as serving as a parliamentarian, but for his contribution to the housing of the elderly in Australia. The Aged Persons Homes Act, which was a statute of the Menzies period, was very much the product of his initiative and his concern for the decent housing of older Australians and the very substantial capital and other programs which have flowed from the mid-1950s through to the present day were significantly initiated by the views he promoted whilst he was a member of parliament and a back bench supporter of the Menzies Government.

He continued his activities outside the Parliament, Mr President. Again, whilst he will be remembered for his contribution to the migrants to Australia through the Good Neighbour Council and otherwise and whilst he will be remembered for other public works that he undertook as a private citizen, his very substantial contribution and permanent memorial will be the villages and other facilities which were established because of his initiative. That initiative came both in the promotion of community support for these programs and in the achieving of a steady system of government support for those community efforts.

Mr President, it is a privilege for me to have the opportunity on behalf of the Opposition to acknowledge the very significant contribution which Sir Keith Wilson made to Australia in that way. Sir Keith is the father of the Hon. Ian Wilson, who is a current member of the House of Representatives and who was a Minister in the Fraser Government. Sir Keith was one of that not rare breed of politicians who beget other politicians. At this time, the thoughts of his family-of Ian, Andrew and Elizabeth and, of course, Lady Wilson-are predominantly on the personal loss which they have suffered. On behalf of the Opposition I extend our sympathy to them but more importantly, I think, I extend our respect and admiration for the contribution which their husband and father made to the public life of this country. It was, I think, rarely successful-that is, his success was rare and will be emulated by few of us in this place-in terms of the very substantial improvement in the lives of many Australians that he affected. His death was a great loss to Australia as it was a great personal loss to his family. I believe that we owe a great debt of gratitude to Sir Keith Wilson. I acknowledge that on behalf of all senators sitting in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Australian Democrats I would like to add our support to the motion moved by the Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans). Sir Keith, as Senator Chaney has already pointed out, was a most distinguished South Australian who served his State and, I believe, his Party very capably and very conscientiously for many years in this place. He was a well-known and well-respected man. Indeed, the Wilsons are an old and very respected South Australian family. As Senator Chaney has also indicated, Sir Keith was a man of considerable compassion, a man who was motivated by a deep and long-held commitment to the community in which he lived, in particular to the needs and improvement of living standards of the elderly members of the community. He will be sadly missed. We extend our condolences to his widow and family in their loss and, in particular, to our current colleague Ian Wilson, who I think has followed a distinguished father with competence and with the commitment to South Australia that his father had when he was in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to be associated with the Senate's motion of condolence to the family of Sir Keith Cameron Wilson and I note that the Senate chamber is nearly full as we debate the motion before us. I wish to extend my condolences to his widow, Lady Wilson, and to the families of his children, Ian, Elizabeth and Andrew. They are close to me and my family and they are close to many South Australians, not least the members of the Liberal Party of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Sir Keith, or `K.C.' as he was affectionately known, died in Adelaide nine days ago, a month into his eighty-eighth year. This past week our thoughts and prayers have been for the comfort of his family. Sir Keith Wilson was first elected to this Parliament as a senator for South Australia in 1937, 50 years ago. He served in the Senate during the war years but for most of that period he had the unique distinction of coming into this chamber in the uniform of the 2nd Australian Imperial Force and he was given leave by the Senate to serve in the 2/7 Australian Field Regiment in the Middle East and the Western Desert where he rose to the rank of major. The Senate was a different Senate then, with only 36 senators, and senators from distant States, such as South Australia, were unable to return to their homes as regularly as we do now.

Sir Keith was much involved in the founding of the Liberal Party of Australia in 1944 and, at the 1949 election, he was elected to the House of Representatives as the first member for Sturt, in which capacity he served for some 15 years. At the 1966 election he was succeeded by his son, Ian Wilson, the present member for Sturt and our very close colleague.

Sir Keith Wilson was distinctively a Liberal. He cared about individual Australians and, for that reason, he brought a distinctiveness in his representation of South Australia into both chambers of the Parliament. When we look at the antecedents of the Liberal Party we see that Sir Keith Wilson looms large. In the 1920s-as far back as 1928, 60 years ago-he was the first President of the then Young Liberal League. As a lawyer in Adelaide he inspired many young South Australians to take up the political values that we know as Liberal values. His wife, Lady Wilson, who is dear to many of us in South Australia, was inspired by `K.C.' and helped in the formation of the Young Liberal League and its political impact on my State of South Australia. The commitments that they shared in the 1920s they have consistently held through all the decades since. Let me quote from his first speech in the Senate chamber 49 years ago this week. Senator Wilson said:
People . . . should not be disadvantaged because of where they live . . . or because of their circumstances.
He declared:
There should be equality of opportunity.

Senator Chaney has already spoken of Sir Keith's pioneering achievements in terms of housing for the aged. He was especially committed to the welfare of veterans and to the welfare of the aged and migrants. In South Australia the movement to establish homes for the aged is chiefly the result of the pioneering work of K. C. Wilson. He was Chairman of Aged Cottage Homes Inc. and inspired similar aged persons homes in other suburbs of Adelaide and other parts of South Australia. This became the model on which the then Menzies Government based homes for the aged throughout Australia. K. C. Wilson is undoubtedly the pre-eminent pioneer in that area. He was the president of the Good Neighbour Council in my State of South Australia. In the 1950s, before we used such terms as `ethnic affairs', before we spoke of the importance of every Australian in the way in which we do now in our debates about the settlement of migrants, the terms that were used were the `good settlement of migrant Australians' and the `Good Neighbour Council'. It was in that era that the Liberal values of K. C. Wilson were reflected by his leadership.

I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the eulogy given last Thursday at the funeral service at St Matthew's Church, Kensington-a church I know very well-by former Senator Gordon Davidson. The eulogy concluded with these fitting remarks:
May God in His mercy
give him a safe lodging
a quiet rest
and peace at the last.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Eulogy delivered by Gordon S. Davidson, C.B.E. at the Funeral Service of Sir Keith Cameron Wilson at St Matthew's Church, Kensington on Thursday 1 October, 1987.
We are here this morning for several reasons.
Firstly . . . to pay our respects to Keith Cameron Wilson, 1900-1987.
Husband . . . father . . . grandfather
Knight Bachelor
Bachelor of Laws, University of Adelaide
Both Senator and Member of the House of Representatives in the Commonwealth Parliament of Australia
Colleague . . . friend . . . and mate.
Who died on Monday last 28 September, 1987 . . . a month into his 88th year.
We are here also . . . to express our sympathy and remembrance to his family.
To Lady Wilson
to Ian
to Elizabeth
and to Andrew
and to their families
and to assure them that our prayers are for their comfort.

Again we are here . . . to give evidence of our tribute to his years of service . . . service to our State and Nation . . . service to the discipline of politics and to the High Court of Parliament . . . and service to our public affairs and commonwealth.
And very importantly . . . we are here . . . to give thanks for his long life and all that the years have been.

For all of his vision . . . his innovation . . . his high hopes and work for the future . . . for his concern for his fellow Australians . . . the aged . . . the migrant . . . the wheatgrower . . . the serviceman . . . the pensioner . . . for his enthusiasm for Australia and the great diversity of its talents . . . and for the way he carried these and other causes into the public arena.
Disraeli once observed of a friend, ``He was a public man of light and leading in the whole country''.
The same could well be said of K. C. Wilson.
K.C. to everyone and to us all. A public man of light and leading.
Indeed he may have taken his first initiative into the public arena as he stood that day in 1918-on the wharf at Port Adelaide-having enlisted for service in the A.I.F. in the First World War.

His zeal for his country and its defence and its security remained with him . . . to when the call came again . . . this time in 1940 . . . he enlisted once more . . . in the 2nd A.I.F. It was with the 2/7 Australian Field Regiment . . . a unit to which he has remained very specially related ever since.

But in the intervening years his public emphasis had embraced the discipline of politics. This resulted from a series of concerns . . . of experiences . . . of observations on the state of the nation . . . and of opportunities.
These same concerns confirmed in him a political philosophy . . . a political philosophy through which he sought to
build a better neighbourhood . . .
establish a better community . . .
and move towards a more responsible and worthy nation.
In terms of political philosophy K. C. Wilson was a Liberal.
He was a Liberal
by conviction
by practice
by example
by enthusiastic application
and most of all . . . by loyalty.

He held strong political concerns for his own life and times. As a young man he worked ceaselessly within his own environment to gather together young people of like mind and to persuade them to bend their energies to the political development . . . as he saw it . . . in Australia. He gave leadership . . . and was the first President of the then Young Liberal League as far back as 1928. He went on to hold office and become a Vice President in what was then the Liberal and Country League.
We see in these various exercises some early examples of his enthusiasm and persistence . . . characteristics which he was to put to good effect all of his life.
So it is not surprising that he sought early election to Parliament . . . and was elected to the Senate in 1937. That was fifty years ago . . . a half a century ago.
It was a different Senate then . . . only 36 Senators and pace of life somewhat different to now.
But K.C. Wilson's own pace was worthy of the man and of his dedication to Parliament and the people.

Standing in the Senate alongside his red leather seat and desk on the 5th October, 1938 . . . 49 years ago next Monday . . . he addressed himself to his maiden speech . . . ``Mr. President'' he began . . . and then he declared himself . . . his responsibility to South Australia as more important than anything else . . . and then to its people.

``People,'' said Senator Wilson, ``people . . . should not be disadvantaged because of where they live . . . or because of their circumstances''. ``There should be,'' he declared . . . ``equality of opportunity!''

Later in the same speech he pressed the case for immigration . . . ``Australia,'' he went on . . . ``Australia can and must support many more than six million people. We want migrants . . . more migrants . . . migrants with families and with skills . . . the best migrants we can get!''
Years later he was to confirm that interest and to sustain those arguments when he accepted appointment by the Minister of the day as the Chairman of the Commonwealth Immigration Advisory Council.

It wasn't long after that maiden speech . . . and still in that same Senate seat . . . that the then Senator Wilson appeared in uniform. For he had enlisted in the Second A.I.F. and whilst still a Senator he served with the 2/7 Australian Field Regiment in the Second World War . . . in the Middle East and the Western Desert . . . and rose to the rank of Major.

He returned to Australia in 1943 . . . somewhat restless but with a clear conviction about the necessity for people to have opportunity to help themselves . . . and the provision of circumstances which would assist them in their desire for achievement and to have some elements of independence.

He . . . in due course . . . gave expression to that conviction in his work with various communities . . . pensioner groups . . . his own regiment . . . and others. Meantime the matter of housing needs pressed heavily upon him. He wanted houses and more houses . . . homes and more homes . . . homes which people could afford . . . which they could enjoy . . . and homes in which they felt secure.
But his equally strong conviction about the role of politics and Parliament in the affairs of people called him again to Canberra.

In 1949 he took his place in the House of Representatives as the Member for the new electorate of Sturt. He was there from 1949 to 1966 with the exception of a short break in 1954-55. His party was now in power and he was able to plead his cause at the seat of Government . . . and what is more he was able to do this at the National and Commonwealth level. He continued his representations in the Committee Room . . . in the Party Room . . . and in the House.
The program of subsidies and allocations developed and improved . . . other allocations and facilities were included . . . indeed speaking in the House in May 1963 he was pleased to be able to say,
``No Act in the history of the Commonwealth has done so much good with the same allocation of funds as has the Aged Persons Homes Act.''

But K.C. was not content with what support he might get in Canberra. Here in Adelaide he was busy encouraging groups to take their own initiatives. His own Aged Cottage Homes organisation of which he was the Chairman for 20 years . . . 1952-72 was a model.

He sat down with scores of Committees . . . and groups . . . and individuals . . . including me . . . as we sought to meet the need for senior citizens homes. He was called in by an executor company to advise as they sought to place funds from an estate for the purpose of aged care.

Meantime organisations like the War Blinded Welfare Fund . . . Adelaide Legacy . . . the Burnside R.S.L. . . . and the Queen Elizabeth Hospital Research Foundation all knew and valued his patronage, support and in some cases his presidency.

But his outreach towards people did not cease. The immigration interest which he had so clearly stated so long ago now found expression in his work for the Good Neighbour Council. In due course he became its President and continued with the organisation and its branches in a service to the people with whom he enjoyed so many links for so many years.

But K. C. Wilson's interest in the migrants found an intense and personal dimension among the new citizens within his own electorate. Stories of what he has done for them are legion. Not only of what he has done for them . . . but of what he has done to encourage them to do more for themselves.
They have not forgotten . . . and they have made their responses over the years in very many ways.

In 1930 K. C. Wilson married Betty Bonython . . . a union which was a precious one for 57 years. In it there was an enduring feature in which there was total support and interest shown by each of them for the activities and pursuits of the other.

Then as a family of five people their total interests and activities . . . whether vocational . . . professional . . . social or cultural . . . covered an area of our public affairs that was very large indeed. What is more it was as varied and diverse as it was large.
And K.C. as a public man . . . stood with a public family.
He was indeed a ``public man of light and leading . . . ''

K.C. had a public and political career which had its frustrations . . . and its disappointment. Anyone in politics and public life has the same experience . . . but he stayed there . . . as though he felt that ``the reward of a thing well done was to have done it''.
But another reward was to crown his efforts. In the New Year Honours of 1966 Her Majesty the Queen conferred upon him the honour of Knighthood . . . Sir Keith Wilson.
It was shortly before his retirement from the Parliament and the hearts of the countless friends with whom he was associated one way or another were indeed glad.

In presenting a tribute to a man like Sir Keith Wilson . . . and in drawing it to a close . . . we may well ask ourselves questions about the sources of his abundant life and his abundant energy for living.
Was it his awareness of the life that was being lived all around him . . . in the lives of the people with whom he worked and served?
Was it in the abundance of young life which he saw in his grandchildren whom he adored?
Or was it in the life of Nature which he observed at the farm at Williamstown and from which he drew so much renewal?
It came . . . I believe in part from all of these and the Divine spark within him responded . . . giving him the grace and power to discharge the many responsibilities entrusted to him.
So we take our leave . . . for . . . in the words of John Henry Newman . . .
for him . . . the shadows lengthen and the evening comes
the busy world is hushed
and the fever of life is over
and his work is done.
May God in His mercy
give him a safe lodging
a quiet rest
and peace at the last.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to associate myself with the condolence motion now before the Senate. It was only a few minutes ago that I learned of the death of Sir Keith Wilson, because I have been absent on business associated with two committees of the Parliament. I rise to speak not only because I am in a position where no one else can speak for me but also because I have, as Sir Keith Wilson's family knows, a personal reason for knowing the pioneering work that was done by Sir Keith Wilson in the establishment of homes for the aged. I take this opportunity of joining with my colleagues in the Senate in conveying condolences to Lady Wilson and to her family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I would like briefly to associate myself with this condolence motion. I grew up in South Australia, as you would know. The first Federal member where I lived was the late Sir Philip McBride and the second was Sir Keith Wilson, and he remained so until I came to Canberra. He was, therefore, a person who was very important in my activities within the Liberal Party of Australia. I met him soon after I joined the Party when I left school, and I would say he had more influence than any other person on the role I have played in the Liberal Party since that time. He was none of the things that people say about politicians. He was not cynical; he was not pragmatic. He was a man who cared for his community. He was a man who cared for the young people who joined the Party, and he took a great deal of interest in it.

SPEECH.PARA: I also got to know Lady Wilson very well. She was an active member of the Liberal Party and chairman of the federal women's committee for many years. His children, Ian, Elizabeth and Andrew, were friends of mine and still are. I wish today to acknowledge the role he played in influencing my life. I say to Lady Wilson and to Ian, Elizabeth and Andrew that he will be missed, and I offer my condolences to them and to his grandchildren, particularly Julie, who is also my goddaughter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to join my colleagues in their remarks in regard to the death of Sir Keith Cameron Wilson. I noted particularly the remarks of Senator Teague in relation to Sir Keith Wilson's activities with aged persons homes. Even in recent years, while I was Minister for Veterans' Affairs, I frequently had phone calls from him to gen me up on the information that was important in that particular industry as it affected veterans. His interest in people was a continuing one throughout his later years. I think that that signifies the greatness of the man.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Teague also referred to some of Sir Keith Wilson's earlier roles in the foundation of the Liberal Party of Australia, particularly in South Australia. There is just one other point I want to mention in regard to that. My first experience of Sir Keith actually was after he had left Parliament in 1966. In 1968 he and some other people and I were appointed by the Liberal Party at that time to a committee called, for want of a better name, the Wilson Investigating Committee. Its role was to examine the whole function and operation, from a political standpoint, of the Liberal Party in South Australia. That Committee brought down a report which subsequently led to major changes to the constitution of the Party and, in fact, brought it up to date and turned it into a modern day political organisation. Again, Sir Keith was one of the major forces in bringing about the future and further development of liberalism in Australia. My condolences and that of my family go to Ian and Andrew, whom, of course, we have known for many years and, of course, to Lady Wilson.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable The President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That we consider the 2% discounting of Commonwealth Occupational superannuation Scheme pension adjustments on 10 October 1986 to be a serious breach of trust by the Government. The Commonwealth has reneged on an established commitment as incorporated in Commonwealth legislation and benefit promise pensions are not being paid in full. In particular we resent the long-term effect of the discounting. The pension loss is compounded throughout the life of a pensioner and surviving dependants-into the 21st century for many. We consider this Government-induced penalty to be out of all proportion to the short-term `extraordinary circumstances of the economy' given as the reason for the discounting.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should urge the Government to:

1. limit the pension discounting effect of the Superannuation and Other Benefits Legislation Amendment Act 1986 to the period 10 October 1986 to 1 July 1987 so that pensions are restored to the 9 October 1986 level as a base for the 1987 pension adjustment; and
2. consult with organisations representing pensioners before changing the terms and conditions of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Schemes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware that it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its place in space;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901 and each point depicting a State and the Territories of the Commonwealth.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to its form or to its acceptance as the sole Australian National Flag will produce divisions in the Australian community.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should ensure that the existing Australian National Flag remains sacrosanct from change and remains the sole national flag.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Moreton Island Preservation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Moreton Island is an invaluable natural resource for Queensland and the world and that mining on Moreton would gravely compromise its unique flora and fauna and its outstanding recreational, archaeological and scientific values.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:
Urge the government to use its proven constitutional powers to halt sand mining on Moreton by supporting the Moreton Island Preservation Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: War Criminals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. This petition of concern to Australian citizens asks that:
If there is to be legal process against alleged war criminals resident in Australia, the foundations of justice should be clear and equitable.
1. Let the term, ``war crime'', be first clearly defined.
2. Let specific prosecutions be swiftly launched against those individuals alleged to have committed them, thus releasing the rest of their co-nationals from unwarranted slur and suspicion.
3. Let an Australian tribunal hear the charges. Nobody should be deported to face the ``tender mercies'' of any foreign government.
4. Let the presumption of innocence until proved guilt be clearly established.
5. Let all evidence obtained from the Soviet or any other communist government be set aside and totally disregarded.

6. Let all the costs of any person charged and found not guilty be paid by the Commonwealth government so that innocent people are not financially ruined in the course of establishing their innocence.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Greenpeace Yacht Vega
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth of Australia:
On June 9th the Greenpeace yacht ``Vega'' was involved in a peaceful protest against the nuclear armed frigate U.S.S. Ramsay because of the threat that her presence posed to the people of Australia.
We the undersigned demand that criminal charges against her crew be dropped.

PETITION.TITLE: Identity Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:
that we are totally opposed to the introduction of the Government's Identity Card;

that this form of national and compulsory identification will be intrusive, costly for taxpayers and business and will not be effective in combating the growing problems of tax evasion, illegal immigrants or social security;
that we call upon the Government to improve management systems within the Australian Tax Office and other Departments to crack down on tax evasion and fraudulent practices.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Hamer (from 756 citizens), Knowles (from 26 citizens), MacGibbon (from 83 citizens), Puplick (from 140 citizens) and Reid (from 10 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
1. The proposed Australia Card will have a dramatic impact on the lives of all Australians.

2. The following citizens of Australia express their concerns at the potential violation of civil rights and democratic freedom posed by such a national identification system and urge that the Government not proceed with its planned introduction of the Australia Card.
3. Or that a national referendum on the Australia Card bill be held before the proposal is re-submitted to Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That we are totally opposed to the introduction of the Australia Card.
(2) That this national identity system will be intrusive, will not appreciably combat tax or social security fraud, is authoritarian and alien to the Australian way of life.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Urge the Government to institute a national referendum on the Australia Card Bill before the proposal is re-submitted to Parliament.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Durack) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to amend the Family Law Act 1975 with respect to maintenance.
Motion (by Senator Durack) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.
SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have my second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
On 5 December 1985 I introduced a Bill to amend the Family Law Act which addressed the twin problems of determining child maintenance and enforcing an obligation to pay it.

The Family Law Act itself made a revolutionary change to family relationships by abolishing the concept of fault and changing the responsibility for maintaining a former spouse and the children of the marriage.

Section 73 of the Act squarely places the obligation on both parents according to their respective financial resources to maintain the children of the marriage at least up to the age of 18 years. However in giving effect to this obligation the Family Court is required to take into account a large number of considerations which are set out in Sections 75 and 76.

These considerations have qualified the general responsibilities laid down by the previous Sections and have in practice led to some confusion where a parent who would otherwise be liable to pay an adequate and perhaps substantial sum for the maintenance of his or her children has successfully reduced that amount where other responsibilities have been assumed following the break-up of a marriage.

The overall result has been outlined by the Institute of Family Studies in the report entitled ``Cost of Children in Australia'' (August 1984) which established that the level of maintenance being ordered by Courts in respect of children is significantly less than the actual cost of their maintenance.
This result has exposed an important social issue which requires to be addressed by the Parliament.

Another problem arises under Section 75 (2) (f) of the Family Law Act which provides that the Court shall take into account `the eligibility of either party for a pension or allowance or benefit under any law of the Commonwealth or of a State or Territory . . . or the rate of any such pension, allowance or benefit being paid to either party'.

At the time the Family Law Act was passed the Government of the day had recently introduced the Supporting Parents Benefit. Since then there has been an astronomic rise in the cost of that benefit to the Australian taxpayer as the following table demonstrates:
Year
Number
Per cent
increase
Expenditure
Per cent
increase
There is a great deal of evidence to establish, and wide recognition of the fact, that these two events are related.

Although there is justification for a Court having regard to a Social Security benefit available to either party where there is a low income by one and no income by the other there can be no justification for a Court taking into account the existence of such a benefit in the case of parents who can afford to pay for the maintenance of their children.
The problem is by no means confined to orders by a Court being influenced by this statutory signal which the Parliament unfortunately gave when it passed the Family Law Act.

Most maintenance obligations do not arise out of court orders but by agreement between the parties or by orders made with the consent of the parties. It does seem that the taxpayer has been ripped-off by such agreements in much the same way as he has been by tax avoidance schemes. One might also say that in recent years there has been a growth industry of maintenance avoidance and that the payment of maintenance has virtually become optional.

My previous Bill proposed to solve these problems by preventing the Court taking into account the availability of Social Security benefits and to give a signal to the Court about the priority which should be accorded to the needs of a child of the marriage over other responsibilities and commitments of its parents.

My previous Bill also proposed some amendments to the Family Law Act to strengthen the enforcement provisions of that Act but I recognised and mentioned in my Second Reading Speech that this problem required urgent action by the Government which was beyond the powers of a private Senator to achieve.

At the time I introduced this Bill, the Government's attitude to the problem of child maintenance was particularly delinquent as the magnitude of the problem had emerged towards the end of the term of the Fraser Government. As Attorney General in that Government in conjunction with the then Minister for Social Security, Senator Chaney, I had been considering in the light of a report of a Joint Select Committee of the Parliament a number of ways of establishing adequate enforcement machinery.

Although the first Attorney-General in the Hawke Government, Senator Evans, set up an inquiry into this question and obtained a Departmental report, nothing further transpired until after my Bill had been introduced.
The Government then commissioned an inquiry into the matter from Dr Meredith Edwards who reported in October 1986. The Government's response to that report was made by Mr Howe in March 1987.

One of the first steps the Minister announced was the introduction of a Bill to amend the Family Law Act along the lines of my 1985 Bill. Despite these events the Government Senators voted against my Bill when brought to a vote in the Senate on 14 May 1987 and no such Government Bill has been introduced.

In these circumstances I am now bringing forward a new Bill to amend the Family Law Act with the same object as my 1985 Bill. Although passed by the Senate it was allowed to languish in the House of Representatives until it was wiped off the Notice Paper with the Double Dissolution on June 5 last.

In view of the fact that the public debate has now concentrated on the question of child maintenance as against spousal maintenance, I have decided to make some changes to my former Bill to focus it on the problem of child maintenance.
I have also had the benefit of considering some important new contributions to the solution of these problems.

In particular I refer to the decision of the Full Court of the Family Court of Australia in Mee and Ferguson 1986 FLC No. 91/716. The report of the Law Reform Commission on Matrimonial Property and the Report of the Family Law Council on Issues Relating to Sections 86 and 87 of the Family Law Act have also been most helpful.

In view of the fact that the Government has decided to establish more adequate machinery for the collection of maintenance even though it has not yet unveiled its final plans, I have omitted from this Bill provisions of my previous Bill which were designed to better enforce that obligation. I had in fact agreed to the excision of such provisions in order to assist the passage of that Bill through the Senate.

Accordingly the Bill which I now introduce simply addresses the problem of determining adequate child maintenance and sheets that responsibility home to parents of the child instead of the taxpayer. This basic parental responsibility has been firmly emphasised by the Full Court in Mee and Ferguson,

``. . . the essential first step is to ascertain in financial terms the needs of the child in question. This will obviously vary with the circumstances of the individual case, taking into account amongst other circumstances the age and sex of the child, the relevant standard of living and any special factors applicable in that particular case. Very often in maintenance cases this aspect is neglected and very imprecise evidence is given, . . .''

Clause 3 of the Bill deletes the provision in Section 75 (2) (f) of the Act which requires the Court in assessing maintenance to take into account the eligibility of either party for pension, allowance or benefit under any law of the Commonwealth, State or Territory.

This is a fundamental step towards a solution of the problems I am seeking to redress. The Family Law Act has clearly given a wrong signal from the Parliament to the Court. Its mere deletion will not of course prevent the Court taking this matter into account in appropriate circumstances on a question of spousal maintenance.

However it is clearly necessary to go further in relation to child maintenance. Accordingly Clause 4 (2) of the Bill prevents the Court taking these matters into account in relation to the determination of child maintenance. The full extent of that responsibility should be determined by the Court in accordance with the other guidelines in Sections 75 and 76.

If as a result of that determination the means of the parties is such that one or both of them may be entitled to a pension or part pension, there is nothing in the Bill which prevents that party from receiving such a benefit.
The Bill proposes two other significant amendments.
Clause 4 (1) adds a further matter to be taken into account in determining child maintenance.

I have already mentioned the important report on the cost of keeping children in Australia by the Institute of Family Studies. Hopefully Judges of the Family Court have taken note of that report but Parliament should require them to do so. I also hope that the Institute of Family Studies will keep that report up to date.

The Act does not give any guidance to the Court about the priority which the needs of a child should have ahead of any commitments and responsibilities which a parent may acquire after the breakup of marriage or, indeed, after the birth of the child.

Since I introduced my previous Bill the Full Court of the Family Court in Mee and Ferguson have tackled this question but it would be helpful if Parliament clearly laid down the rule that the needs of the child should be paramount over other commitments of the parent. Clause 4 (2) does so.

This may work an injustice in the peculiar circumstances of a particular case but Clause 4 (2) gives the Court the power to have regard to such circumstances. There is also the general directive to that effect in Section 75 (2) (n).
Clause 5 of the Bill deals with the problem of maintenance agreements. These are dealt with in Sections 86 and 87 of the Family Law Act.

Section 86 provides that agreements may be registered with the Court but these agreements do not prevent either party seeking to modify an agreement by a subsequent claim for maintenance if circumstances have changed.

To prevent parties entering into agreements under this Section which minimise child maintenance, the Government should enforce the requirement of the Social Security Act (Section 83AAD) that it is a condition of the payment of a benefit that steps are taken to enforce the right of maintenance.

Agreements under Section 87 require the approval of the court because these prevent either party, except in certain extreme circumstances, from coming back to the Court to seek any variation of maintenance. These are the ones favoured by the better-off sections of the community for maintenance avoidance purposes.
The Bill provides a simple amendment to exclude the maintenance of a child of the marriage from the effect of a Section 87 agreement.
It is interesting to note that the Report of the Law Reform Commission on Matrimonial Property adopts the same approach to these agreements.

`The paramount consideration of the welfare of the child requires that the court should never be deprived by an agreement between spouses of its powers to make orders concerning children, including child maintenance orders.' (p. 195)

As I have said, the Government has been most tardy in dealing with this major social problem. Despite its flurry of activity earlier this year, it still does not seem to have grasped the urgency of providing a solution to this problem. The most disappointing aspect has been the refusal of Labor Senators to support any move in recent years to amend the Family Law Act to remove the now widely recognised flaw in the Act by which Parliament has signalled the Courts and the legal advisers of parents that the maintenance of children is more the responsibility of taxpayers than the parents themselves.

The Full Court of the Family Court has eloquently repudiated that notion. The Minister for Social Security in his statement to the Parliament has done so as well. The Institute of Family Studies and the Family Law Council have identified the problem. It is incredible that Labor Senators' thinking has been so outmoded on such a major social issue.
This Bill still gives such Senators an opportunity to bring themselves up to date and repair the damage they have done by their earlier opposition to similar proposals.
I commend this Bill to the Senate.
