TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House consents to termination by the Commonwealth of the Airlines Agreement 1981.

After 35 years of detailed economic regulation of interstate aviation by successive Australian governments, I today place before the Parliament a motion which will bring the two airlines policy to an end, and open Australia's interstate air services to free competition. The 1981 airlines agreement, a copy of which is set out in the schedule to the Airlines Agreement Act 1981, was put in place by the previous Government. It required three years notice of termination. The motion now before the Senate, which was foreshadowed by my predecessor, the Hon. Peter Morris, on 5 June this year, and which will subsequently be put to the House of Representatives, seeks to enable the Government to serve that notice and to bring the existing arrangements to an end in 1990.

In essence, the Government's major objective in bringing the two airlines policy to a close is to create an environment which will foster increased responsiveness by airlines to consumer needs; a wider range of fares and types of services to provide enhanced travel opportunities; increased competition and pricing flexibility leading to greater economic efficiency in the industry; and a continuation of Australia's world renowned aviation safety record. To achieve this objective, the Government has decided to withdraw from aviation-specific economic regulation and to allow the market to operate within the constraints of the established competition policy controls applicable to industry generally. I emphasise that this withdrawal is from economic regulation, and not the regulation of safety.

The airline industry in Australia is now well developed by world standards. The aircraft and facilities used are of the highest standard, and the expertise and safety achieved in Australian operations are of world renown. Given the size and established position of the trunk airlines, there is simply no longer a need to continue the absolute protection from domestic competition. In fact, the development of the aviation industry has now reached a stage where detailed economic regulation can no longer help, and may be hindering, the achievement of the broader economic and social objectives which have previously underlined the two-airline policy.

The question of the Commonwealth's role in the economic regulation of the industry has recently been subjected to the most detailed and public scrutiny in the industry's history by the Independent Review of Economic Regulation of Domestic Aviation-the May Review. The May Review was critical of existing arrangements and drew attention to significant public dissatisfaction with the current policy, including the widespread view that it works to the disadvantage of consumers and encourages the airlines to serve the high yield business markets to the detriment of the leisure market. It found that in comparison with its overseas counterparts, Australian aviation is characterised by relatively low labour productivity and relatively high and stable profit levels. Public comment on the May Review generally favoured substantial withdrawal by the Commonwealth from economic regulation of the industry.

We have decided to adopt the broad thrust of option 5 proposed by the Review. What this means is that the Government will-upon termination of the Airlines Agreement in October 1990-withdraw from the detailed economic regulation of four matters. First, controls over the importation of aircraft will be removed. These controls have provided the threshold underpinning of the legislative and contractual arrangements which currently regulate the industry. Secondly, the detailed determination of the amount of passenger capacity that may be provided by each trunk airline and each regional airline which uses jet aircraft larger than 30 seats, will cease. Thirdly, the Independent Air Fares Committee which currently sets all air fares will be abolished and the Commonwealth will withdraw from the determination of air fares. Fourthly, the existing constraints on the entry of new domestic operators to trunk routes will be removed.

Let me make it clear what this deregulation decision does not mean. First, as I have already stated, economic deregulation does not mean that the Government will in any way withdraw from, or lessen the effectiveness of, safety regulation. On the contrary, a series of new initiatives are proposed that will significantly further strengthen Australia's already outstanding aviation safety record. They are spelt out in full in the detailed statement I shall be tabling, and seeking leave to incorporate in Hansard, at the conclusion of this speech. The statement has, I believe, now been distributed in the chamber.

Secondly, the economic deregulation decision does not mean that there will be any abdication of the Government's responsibility for consumer protection, or any lessening in our commitment to ensuring that effective competition prevails in the Australian aviation industry. On the contrary, we have taken the view that there is a need to apply the Trade Practices Act to the new aviation industry environment, to maintain a limited degree of price surveillance of the kind that applies in many other deregulated industries, and to ensure that in the operation of the airport infrastructure under the Federal Airports Corporation new entrants will not be excluded from effective access.

Thirdly, economic deregulation does not mean that an open skies policy will prevail domestically insofar as foreign airlines, and in particular those operating international services to Australia, are concerned. There is a close interrelation between the position of domestic and international carriers, with the viability of each depending to some extent on how the boundaries are drawn between them. The Government has made decisions and formulated guidelines on all these matters, and they are set out in full in the statement I will table shortly.

Fourthly, it does not mean that we will abdicate our responsibility to ensure that the Government's own domestic airline, Australian, is well equipped-both managerially and in terms of its capitalisation-to succeed in the robust competitive environment that will prevail from 1990. Again, the steps we are proposing to follow in this regard are set out in full in the accompanying tabled statement.

The Government has been acutely conscious of the difficulties that have occurred in the United States following deregulation there in 1978, and our policy is designed to avoid the undesirable effects of the kind of economic deregulation that occurred in that country. We have also had the benefit of the Canadian experience, where the industrial relations framework, market size and characteristics are much closer to Australia's and where economic deregulation has not, in fact, resulted in the significant problems experienced in the United States. What is involved in the Government's economic deregulation policy is not a simple, or simple-minded, lifting of existing controls, but a complex group of interacting policies involving a number of internal checks and balances.

The key elements of that total policy are, in summary, as follows: first, withdrawal from detailed economic regulatory controls over aircraft imports and capacity, air fares and route entry; second, continuation and enhancement of regulatory controls over aviation safety and security; third, watchdog protection for consumers through the application of the Trade Practices Act, appropriate fare scrutiny by the Prices Surveillance Authority, and assured access to terminal facilities by new entrants to the industry; fourth, action to strengthen Australian Airlines to confront the post-1990 environment, including immediate incorporation, removal of a number of Public Service controls immediately with a review of others to follow, and a full review of options for generating necessary capitalisation and managerial effectiveness; fifth, neither Qantas Airways Ltd nor any other international airline to carry domestic passengers or freight on regular services, international operators into Australia to be confined to less than 15 per cent equity in any Australian domestic carrier and Qantas to remain Australia's sole designated international carrier; and, sixth, as interim measures to encourage competition before 1990, Qantas's interlining rights to be restored, and restrictions on large aircraft passenger charters by domestic operators to be modified and arrangements for the approval of commercial domestic charters by Qantas to be subject to review on termination of the Airlines Agreement.

The Government has not taken in isolation its decision to terminate the two airlines agreement. The deregulation policy we have developed is based on a comprehensive approach encompassing sweeping changes to the Commonwealth's role in Australian aviation, including new approaches to the provision of infrastructure and services, safety regulation, and the role of government aviation business undertakings. The policy is designed to take the domestic aviation industry into the 1990s and beyond. I table, and seek leave to incorporate in Hansard, a detailed statement in support of the resolution to terminate the aviation airline agreement, and commend this motion to the Senate.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
DOMESTIC AVIATION : A NEW DIRECTION FOR THE 1990s

After 35 years of detailed economic regulation of interstate aviation by successive Australian Governments, I have today placed before the Parliament a motion which will bring the two airlines policy to an end, and open Australia's interstate air services to free competition.

The 1981 Airlines Agreement, a copy of which is set out in the Schedule to the Airlines Agreement Act 1981, was put in place by the previous Government. It requires three years notice of termination. The motion now before the Parliament, which was foreshadowed by my predecessor, the Hon. Peter Morris, on 5 June 1987, seeks to enable the Government to serve that notice and to bring the existing arrangements to an end in 1990.
GOVERNMENT'S OBJECTIVE
In bringing the two airlines policy to a close the Government's major objective is to create an environment which will foster:
-increased responsiveness by airlines to consumer needs;
-a wider range of fares and types of services to provide enhanced travel opportunities;
-increased competition and pricing flexibility leading to greater economic efficiency in the industry; and
-a continuation of Australia's world renowned aviation safety record.

To achieve this objective, the Government has decided to withdraw from aviation-specific economic regulation and to allow the market to operate within the constraints of the established competition policy controls applicable to industry generally. I emphasise that this withdrawal is from economic regulation, and not the regulation of safety. I will return to the paramount question of safety at some length later.
BACKGROUND: THREE DECADES OF AIRLINE INDUSTRY REGULATION

The first Airlines Agreement originated in 1952, and by 1960 a package of contractual and legislative arrangements was in place which provided for government regulation of the domestic aviation industry to achieve the following objectives:
-foster the development and growth of the ``infant'' aviation industry in an orderly manner;
-ensure long term financial stability of the major domestic airline operators;
-provide assistance to operators on unprofitable routes in rural areas;

-enable airline capacity to be closely matched with market demands, thus avoiding the provision of excessive capacity and resultant higher costs which could ultimately be borne by the whole community; and
-promote fair and workable competition between the airlines and discourage monopolisation or uncompetitive practices within the industry.

By 1970 the domestic airline industry was considered to be a strong, financially stable industry. The 1972 Airlines Agreement was framed against a background of perceived shortcomings in the regulatory system in areas such as parallel scheduling, and lack of innovation in fares and rural services. It placed a number of obligations on the airlines as to the level of service they were to provide in return for the retention of the two airline policy.

The airline industry continued to develop, and the 1981 Airlines Agreement was designed to increase the level of competition within the industry, while maintaining the established network of services on a safe and efficient basis.

The airline industry in Australia is now well developed by world standards. The aircraft and facilities used are of the highest standard, and the expertise and safety achieved in Australian operations are of world renown. Given the size and established position of the trunk airlines, there is simply no longer a need to continue the absolute protection from domestic competition.

In fact the development of the aviation industry has now reached a stage where detailed economic regulation can no longer help, and may be hindering, the achievement of the broader economic and social objectives which have previously underlined the two airline policy.

The operation of capacity controls is perhaps the clearest example. They have not been effective in achieving their aims, insofar as, under a system which is designed to closely match capacity with market demand, at various times wasteful excess capacity has not been prevented. Capacity controls have also stifled airline incentives to develop new markets and interfere with normal business responsibility for efficient utilisation of assets.
THE MAY REVIEW

Against this background, and the increasingly widespread perception that the present regulatory regime has lost its rationale, the question of the Commonwealth's role in the economic regulation of the industry has recently been subjected to the most detailed and public scrutiny in the industry's history.

The Independent Review of Economic Regulation of Domestic Aviation commissioned by the Government in March 1985 (the May Review) conducted its Inquiry over a period of almost two years and received more than 80 written submissions.
Public comment on the May Review was sought in January 1987 and written comment was received from 30 organisations, including the airlines, State Governments and unions.

The May Review was critical of existing arrangements and drew attention to significant public dissatisfaction with the current policy, including the widespread view that it works to the disadvantage of consumers and encourages the airlines to serve the high yield (business) markets to the detriment of the leisure market. It found that in comparison with its overseas counterparts, Australian aviation is characterised by relatively low labour productivity and relatively high and stable profit levels.
The May Review identified five options for future Government policy on aviation. These range from maintenance of the status quo to more or less full economic deregulation.
Public comment on the May Review generally favoured substantial withdrawal by the Commonwealth from economic regulation of the industry.

The Government has developed its response to the May Review against the background of our general, and by now well known, policy of withdrawing from business regulation where it is not, on balance, justified as a means of promoting efficiency, improving the competitiveness of Australian industry or securing long term benefits for consumers.

We have taken the view that maintenance of the current arrangements (May Option 1) would not promote, and may prevent, attainment of economic efficiency, and that other options short of total economic deregulation (May Options2-4) would involve as much regulation as atpresent, if not more, but would still fail toresolve the problems identified with thecurrent arrangements.

We have accordingly decided to adopt the broad thrust of Option 5 proposed by the Review, and will withdraw from detailed economic regulation of domestic air fare setting, aircraft imports, capacity controls and route entry.
A summary and assessment of the May Review's options is at Attachment A.

The Government has not taken this decision in isolation. The policy we have developed is based on a comprehensive approach encompassing sweeping changes to the Commonwealth's role in Australian aviation, including new approaches to the provision of infrastructure and services, safety regulation, and the role of Government aviation business undertakings. The policy which I will outline today is designed to take the domestic aviation industry into the 1990s and beyond.

The Government has been acutely conscious of the difficulties that have occurred in the United States following deregulation there in 1978, and our policy is designed to avoid the undesirable effects of the kind of economic de-regulation that occurred in that country. Wehave also had the benefit of the Canadian experience, where the industrial relations framework and market size and characteristics are closer to Australia's, and where economic deregulation has not in fact resulted in the significant problems experienced in the US.
WHAT DEREGULATION MEANS-AND DOES NOT MEAN

The economic deregulation of the Australian airline industry means, in essence, that Government will-upon termination of the Airlines Agreement in October 1990-withdraw from the detailed economic regulation of four matters.

First, controls over the importation of aircraft will be removed. These controls have provided the threshold underpinning of the legislative and contractual arrangements which currently regulate the industry.

Secondly, the detailed determination of the amount of passenger capacity that may be provided by each trunk airline, and each regional airline which uses jet aircraft larger than 30 seats, will cease.
Thirdly, the Independent Air Fares Committee (IAFC) which currently sets all air fares will be abolished and the Commonwealth will withdraw from the determination of air fares.
Fourthly, the existing constraints on the entry of new domestic operators to trunk routes will be removed.

A paper setting out the legislative basis for the constraints that currently apply to domestic aviation operators, and enumerating the controls that will be removed following termination of the Airlines Agreement is at Attachment B.

One additional aspect of economic regulation that is not addressed in this statement but will require consideration before 1990, is the application of the Government's offsets policy to the airline industry. Both Australian Airlines and Ansett are presently required to comply with that policy, and the question for decision will be whether, in a deregulated environment, it is appropriate for that situation to continue.
Let me make it clear what this deregulation decision does not mean.

First, economic deregulation does not mean that the Government will in any way withdraw from, or lessen the effectiveness of, safety regulation. On the contrary, a series of new initiatives are proposed that will significantly further strengthen Australia's already outstanding aviation safety record, and I will spell them out shortly.

Secondly, it does not mean that there will be any abdication of the Government's responsibility for consumer protection, or any lessening in our commitment to ensuring that effective competition prevails in the Australian aviation industry. On the contrary, we have taken the view that there is a need to apply the Trade Practices Act to the new aviation industry environment, to maintain a limited degree of price surveillance of the kind that applies in many other deregulated industries, and to ensure that in the operation of the airport infrastructure under the new Federal Airports Corporation new entrants will not be excluded from effective access.

Thirdly, economic deregulation does not mean that an open skies policy will prevail domestically insofar as foreign airlines, and in particular those operating international services to Australia, are concerned. There is a close interrelation between the position of domestic and international carriers, with the viability of each depending to some extent on how the boundaries are drawn between them, and the Government has made decisions and formulated guidelines, which I will spell out later, addressing this.

Fourthly, it does not mean that we will abdicate our responsibility to ensure that the Government's own domestic airline, Australian, is well equipped-both managerially and in terms of its capitalisation-to succeed in the robust competitive environment that will prevail from 1990. We have addressed that question closely and I will, again, have more to say about it later in the statement.
BENEFITS OF ECONOMIC DEREGULATION

The Government is well aware that unlimited benefits do not always flow from the operation of market forces. However, it is clearly the case that the existing economic regulatory environment does not actively encourage industry efficiency, and is not an appropriate basis for the further development of the industry through the 1990s.
Increased opportunities for competition in a deregulated environment will provide a number of benefits that I will spell out in more detail in a moment;
- greater incentives for existing and new participants in the industry to become more efficient and responsive to consumer needs;
- a wider range of air fares, in particular an increased availability of discount fares;
- growth, particularly in the price sensitive leisure travel market; and
- a greater variety in the types, standards and frequency of services provided, and use of more appropriate aircraft on some routes.

No one can predict precisely what will happen when economic deregulation occurs in 1990. However, it is possible to clearly point to the areas in which the existing regulatory arrangements have failed to meet consumers' needs and enhance industry efficiency, and from this address the potential for improvement in an environment designed to foster competition.

Opportunities for New Entrants. New operators will be able to compete on interstate trunk routes presently served by Ansett and Australian. The May Review found that there are a large number of routes between trunk centres (the State capitals plus 10 other key regional ports) that are not being directly served-eg Adelaide/Hobart-and that certain other routes are only infrequently served, eg Canberra/Brisbane. Such routes may well provide scope for new operators to provide services using more appropriate aircraft.

Scope for increased efficiency. No one would argue that costs in the Australian aviation industry under economic deregulation should be reduced to the extent experienced in the United States, with the adverse consequences that have there been evident for that country's aviation workforce and the quality of service provided.

But the May Review did, nonetheless, identify cost differentials between the two countries' airline industries which-even after taking into account all relevant differences-suggest that there is scope for significant improvement in management and work practices in the Australian aviation industry: with resultant cost savings then being passed on to customers, with the help of competitive pressures, in the form of lower fares.

The study commissioned by the May Review from Travers Morgan Pty Ltd involved an assessment of comparative airline efficiency which sought to discount factors specific to particular operating environments, so that the remaining performance differences between airlines could be linked to regulatory and associated management influences.

After adjusting for differences in cost environments, nature of services provided (such as relative emphasis on scheduled passenger rather than charter and/or freight services), route network structures (including stage lengths and route densities), and quality of services provided, the study found that, overall, Australian trunk airlines were some 7%-10% more costly than US airlines undertaking comparable operations.

Among the elements of the cost structures of the Australian airlines found to be much higher than equivalent elements of the cost structures of the US airlines sampled were the costs of flying crew and general administration - in both cases up to 90%-100% above US levels.

Airfares. Currently both Ansett and Australian are obliged to operate on identical economy fares, and because these airlines are each accorded 50% of the available aircraft capacity for trunk routes there are few incentives for competition on the basis of price. Competition has occurred mainly in the areas of standards and frequency of service. The operation of the IAFC Act has limited the types and extent of discounts and allowed overly restrictive conditions to be applied to the fares which can be offered. The complicated web of regulatory limits on discounts will be lifted after 1990 and the airlines will be free to offer a wider range of fares and place fewer conditions on them.

Overseas experience suggests that with increased competition, airlines offer more and better discounts, and more consumers take advantage of them thereby reducing the average level of fares to the travelling public. For instance, latest figures from the US suggest that more than 90% of air travellers used some form of discount fare, and the average discount was over 60% off the standard fare. By comparison, less than 45% of Australian trunk route passengers utilise discount fares. Again, while the US experience is not to be uncritically embraced, it does suggest that there is room for improvement here.

Growth in the market. If, as was suggested in many submissions to the May Review, there is a substantial untapped market for air travel in Australia, deregulation will encourage the airlines to compete more vigorously to attract the price-sensitive consumer. There is a body of evidence that strongly suggests that leisure travellers, particularly in the over 45 age group, provide scope for significant growth in air travel.

On the basis of the experience in other countries, any effect on employment levels resulting from efficiency initiatives is likely to be balanced by increased employment opportunities flowing from the expansion of the industry.

Types, standard and frequency of services and appropriate match of aircraft to markets. Not every air traveller wants a five star service with prices to match; on the other hand, there will always be people who are prepared to pay for top of the line service. In a deregulated environment there will be greater incentives for airlines to serve all segments of the market, rather than concentrating on high yield traffic, as at the moment.
East-West Airlines has shown the potential for the development of low cost `no frills' services. Economic deregulation will allow these and other specialised niches to be filled.

Inevitably there will be further changes in service patterns, aircraft types and operators on individual routes. However, what is often overlooked is that, under the present heavily regulated system, there has already been major rationalisation of services to the point where together Ansett, including its regional airlines, and Australian Airlines now serve only about 50 of the more than 150 ports to which they provided services in 1968. In the overwhelming majority of cases services to these centres have been taken up by East-West Airlines or commuter operators, and consumers have often benefited from the use of more appropriate equipment resulting in a higher frequency of service.

There is every reason to expect that under economic deregulation there will be even greater scope for specialised carriers, using more appropriate aircraft, to occupy any further market niches where services are reduced or vacated, or appropriate discount fares are not offered, by the major airlines.
SAFETY

Safety regulation will continue to apply, and be of paramount importance, after the Airlines Agreement terminates. The bodies responsible for standard setting, operational control and safety investigation will have ample resources, including the necessary legislative compliance tools, to ensure that safety regulation and surveillance are in no way diminished.

Civil Aviation Authority. Both safety standard-setting and day-to-day regulatory control will be the responsibility of the proposed new Civil Aviation Authority, which will also have operational responsibility for air traffic control, flight advisory services, communications, navigation and surveillance systems, and rescue and fire fighting services at airports. The Government's in-principle decision to establish such a body has already been announced by my predecessor in October last year, and its structure and functions have been the subject of extensive consultation with the industry and unions. I would hope to see the Authority operational-after appropriate further consultation on implementation details, and parliamentary approval of the enabling legislation-within 12-18 months..

The question of whether safety regulation should be subsumed within the Authority, or rather be a function continuing to be separately exercised by the Flight Standards Division of the Department of Transport and Communications, has been the subject of some debate. I believe, however, that there is strong logic in the view that the task of regulating aviation safety must be regarded as an integrated system in which all elements are coordinated to achieve maximum reliability and effectiveness. The operation of air traffic control and the flight advisory service is as much a part of safety regulation as the regulation of the aircraft and its crew. The two areas complement each other. I am certain that the Departmental officers who have made such a splendid contribution to our aviation safety in the context of integrated safety and operational functions within the Department will continue to do so in the new Authority.

It is to be noted that, in the United Kingdom, that country's Civil Aviation Authority has very successfully combined safety regulation with the operation of the airways system. The UK decision was taken after a formal review (the Edwards Committee) , and on the basis that the setting of standards, regulatory control and the day-to-day operation of the system should be under single control in the interests of efficiency and effectiveness, because of the close interrelationship involved..

I want to make it clear that the Australian Civil Aviation Authority will be required to give primacy to safety considerations over commercial ones, and that the enabling legislation will make provision for the Minister to give broad directions in relation to the safety regulatory role to ensure that occurs. I should also mention that the name of the proposed Authority has been changed from the originally proposed Civil Aviation Corporation as another way of reflecting and demonstrating this safety priority.

Bureau of Air Safety Investigation. By contrast, it is proposed that the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI) will remain in my Department, separate from the Civil Aviation Authority, and directly responsible to the Minister. There are several advantages in this. First, the Authority responsible for improving and enforcing safety standards, should not be allowed to be the judge of its own performance. Secondly, this separation will overcome the reluctance of some in the industry to report safety incidents to BASI when it is located, as at present, in the same agency as those responsible for enforcing regulations. The audit function that BASI currently performs may require some expansion under the changed arrangements and consideration will be given to the resources required for this.

Aviation Security. Another function that will be retained under direct government control in the Department is aviation security. The Government will shortly be considering the report of a task force that has been examining our current oversight of airport security. If any upgrading is required, we will ensure it is initiated quickly.

Review of Legislative Framework. My colleague the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support, the Hon. Peter Duncan, will shortly be announcing details of a review of the legislative framework for safety regulation, which he will be personally overseeing. The review will seek to simplify the aviation safety regulations and place them on a more rational basis. We will ensure that aspects of the review dealing with the need for effective action to ensure compliance with safety regulations are in place before 1990. We will also review the licensing system to ensure that new and existing airlines have and maintain appropriate safety standards. In addition, we will consult with the industry with a view to ensuring the availability of skilled personnel to meet the requirements of both the safety regulatory authority and the industry.

Regulatory Review Panel. The Government is also conscious of the need for the regulatory system to remain responsive to the needs of the industry while continuing to serve the public interest in maintaining aviation safety. Accordingly, the Government is discussing with industry the establishment of a Regulatory Review Panel with industry representation to examine and advise on new or changed safety regulatory provisions.

In the case of both the review of the legislative framework and the establishment of the Regulatory Review Panel, it is the Government's intention to take advantage of the three year period before termination of the Agreement to implement these measures well in advance of deregulation.
COMPETITION AND CONSUMER PROTECTION
After safety, the next area of vital concern to the Government is to ensure that adequate safeguards are in place to protect consumer interests.

Trade Practices Controls. The most immediate concern in this respect in a deregulated environment is to prevent the emergence of a monopoly on the network of interstate routes and to prevent the abuse of market power through anti-competitive practices such as predatory pricing.

With the demise of the current economic regulatory arrangements in 1990, the aviation industry will be fully exposed to the Trade Practices Act. Any move towards monopoly on the network of interstate services would be dealt with by Section 50 of the Act, which covers market dominance.
Other provisions of the Trade Practices Act, in particular sections 45-48, will ensure that other anti-competitive practices would be examinable by the Trade Practices Commission.

We have looked at whether there is any need for special aviation competition controls, either through amendments to the Trade Practices Act or industry specific legislation. However it is the Government's belief that the aviation industry does not display characteristics which significantly distinguish it from other industries to warrant special consideration in a deregulated environment.

Intrastate services, of course, will continue to be the responsibility of State Governments. The policy of the States currently ranges from complete deregulation in South Australia, to the allocation of route licences to individual operators in NSW.

Air Fares. Following the abolition of the Independent Air Fares Committee, interstate air fares will be made subject to surveillance by the Prices Surveillance Authority (PSA). As is the case with some other industries operating in a competitive market, the fares charged by domestic operators will become subject to public scrutiny. However, the discipline that competition will apply to the industry should ensure that the PSA's influence will, in practice, be limited to cases-likely to be isolated-involving abuse of market power.

Any concern that PSA scrutiny will become a disincentive to investment in the airline industry is answered by the statutory obligation of the PSA to take into account the influence of profitability on investment and the need for business enterprises to make reasonable returns.
The need for continuing involvement of the PSA will be reviewed after an interim period of three years.
It will be up to State Governments whether air fare controls are imposed on intrastate services.

Access to Airport Facilities. One of the key aspects of the debate on deregulation, especially in the US and Canada, has been the issue of access to airport facilities. Australia's major civil airports will, from 1 January 1988, be under the control of the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC), a new statutory body designed to place the airports-with their terminals, runways and associated facilities-on a proper commercial basis.

While proposing to vest all airport assets in the FAC, the Government has nonetheless recognised the need for existing airline operators to have security of tenure and to be able to project their own corporate identities throughout their terminal facilities. We are, as a result, engaged in negotiating with the airlines-prior to the FAC start up date-a series of longer term leases (of up to approximately 20 years duration) designed to give security of tenure over existing dedicated spaces and to secure dedicated spaces in other terminals where the physical arrangements are such as to make this reasonable and practicable.

On the other hand, it is essential to provide new entrants with the opportunity to gain access to terminal facilities if there is to be real competition. To this end the Government intends that, in the absence of other available access facilities, any leases negotiated or re-negotiated with the existing airlines make reasonable and adequate provision for the access of other operators to those parts of the terminal which are subject to such leases.

In addition, it will be open to the FAC to make provision at its airports for the construction of alternative facilities-which could range from low cost no frills facilities to high standard facilities-as a means of providing further scope for competition from new entrants; what provision is eventually made in this respect will depend very much on the circumstances prevailing at the particular locations.

I put the industry on notice that while the Government clearly recognises the commercial needs of the existing airlines, we are determined to ensure that nothing is done that will in any way stifle competition in the domestic aviation industry in a deregulated environment.
ROLE OF QANTAS, OTHER INTERNATIONAL CARRIERS, AND FOREIGN INVESTMENT

Earlier I referred to the close interrelationship between the roles of international and domestic carriers and the bearing that this has on their viability in the market place. The central question confronting us in the context of the economic deregulation decision is the extent to which international airlines will be permitted to compete in the domestic market and, conversely, what are the implications of such competition for the domestic airlines.

Role of Qantas. In considering the issue of access to scheduled domestic passengers by Qantas, the Government agrees with the May Review's assessment that to allow Qantas to perform such a role, which incidentally it does not seek, would undoubtedly lead to pressure for other domestic operators to be allowed to operate as designated international Australian carriers, which pressure would be difficult for the Government, on grounds of fair and equitable commercial opportunity, to resist.

However, it has been the policy of successive Governments to designate only one Australian airline to take up Australia's rights to operate scheduled international services as provided for in the air service agreements that we have negotiated with foreign Governments. The basis for this approach has included the desire to develop and retain a strong, competitive Australian `flag carrier' presence in international aviation, the fact that competition is already provided by a large number of foreign international carriers, and recognition of the relatively small traffic base in Australia.

Certain other countries, such as the US, UK, France and Japan, which designate more than one carrier to exercise their international air service rights, do so to serve vastly greater markets than Australia's, and the individual carriers concerned are many times larger than Qantas. For instance United Airlines and American Airlines carry 50 million and 46 million passengers per year respectively, with 373 and 330 aircraft respectively. Qantas, on the other hand, carries less than 3 million passengers per year with a fleet of 32 aircraft. The emerging international trend is towards the amalgamation and the further development of mega carriers-witness the proposed mergers between British Airways (17 million passengers) and British Caledonian (2.4 million passengers), and between UTA (1 million passengers) and Air France (12 million passengers).

Arguments have been put that there should at least be an open skies policy between Australia and New Zealand as an extension of the Closer Economic Relations Agreement (CER) between the two countries. This would place the international airlines of both countries in direct competition with the domestic carriers of both countries, thereby leading to pressures from the domestic carriers to be granted full international rights. However, as I have already outlined, the Australian international market is not large enough, and already has competitive pressures such that multiple designation of Australian international carriers is not warranted. The New Zealand international market is even smaller than Australia's and is similarly served by a number of international carriers.

It is difficult to see any rational solution short of the possible designation of a single international carrier to service both Australia's and New Zealand's international markets-possibly involving the ultimate amalgamation of all the major carriers of both countries along the lines of SAS in Scandinavia, which exercises domestic and international rights on behalf of Sweden, Denmark and Norway. This could possibly be envisaged as one scenario which could evolve under the CER. It would obviously involve extremely complex and difficult political, legal, industrial relations, and other practical issues. The point I would particularly emphasise in this respect is that any intermediate solution would also involve many of these difficulties, without the corresponding benefits.

In these circumstances therefore, it is in Australia's best interests to retain the single designation policy, at least for the foreseeable future, and for Qantas to remain Australia's sole designated international airline.

If Qantas is to remain Australia's sole international airline with domestic Australian carriers denied the right to operate internationally, then the commercially fair and equitable converse of that limitation is that Qantas should be restricted in its ability to operate in the domestic market. The Government will not, accordingly, permit Qantas to operate domestic scheduled air services, nor to carry domestic passengers or freight on domestic sectors of its international services.

Interlining. The Government will, however, with effect from 1 July 1988, restore Qantas's rights, removed by the Fraser Government in 1979, to carry passengers of other international airlines on domestic sectors of Qantas's international services. This practice, which is called interlining, is expected to increase the number of tourists who travel by air while visiting Australia and is one of the few initiatives which can be taken to increase competition on interstate air routes prior to 1990.

In addition to the benefits from increased air travel by international tourists within Australia, interlining will reduce the waste of economic resources represented by empty seats on Qantas flights within Australia.

As this decision will not take effect until 1 July 1988, the domestic airlines will have an adequate period of notice to develop their competitive responses. In this regard, the domestic airlines enjoy a significant frequency advantage over Qantas on all routes and will be well placed to compete for what is expected to be a growth market for international tourists travelling within Australia.

Concerns have been expressed in the past, when interlining previously applied, about the possible misuse of interlining-involving carriage of domestic passengers on international services-by travel agents and some international airlines. Before the new interlining arrangements come into effect, the Government will have discussions with Qantas, the domestic airlines, and representatives of the travel industry with a view to implementing, if necessary, arrangements to avoid the potential for such misuse.

Other international airlines will not be permitted to interline or exercise cabotage rights in Australia. Cabotage is the term given to the right of the airline of one country to carry domestic passengers or freight between points in another country. It would not be appropriate for Australia to give cabotage rights to foreign international airlines while Qantas does not enjoy similar rights in other countries and in circumstances where our international airline is excluded from operating domestic scheduled air services in Australia.

Domestic Charters. As a further small contribution to stimulating competition in the interim period before 1990 the Government proposes to lift existing policy restrictions which have prevented domestic operators other than Ansett and Australian Airlines from operating commercial domestic passenger charter flights with large jet aircraft. In this interim period we will give sympathetic consideration to proposals by domestic operators other than Ansett and Australian Airlines, to import large jet aircraft for this purpose. The Government will ensure that any initiatives taken would not be allowed to undermine the scheduled passenger services provided by Ansett and Australian Airlines under the terms of the Airlines Agreement. Domestic charters by Qantas are not presently subject to prohibition under the current Airlines Agreement but are required to be approved on a case-by-case basis. It is intended that this situation will continue but be subject to review on termination of the Agreement.

International Charters by Domestic Airlines. The domestic airlines will not be without new commercial opportunities themselves in the period immediately ahead. They will be able to expand their international freight charter operations if they wish as a result of changes to Australia's international freight charter policy. These changes, while recognising the primary role played by scheduled carriers, lift restrictions on genuine freight charter operations to permit carriage of consolidated cargo inbound and outbound from any gateway or combination of gateways. This gives the domestic carriers an opportunity to play an important supplementary role in the promotion and development of Australian exports.

There are similarly new avenues being opened up for the domestic carriers in new guidelines agreed for passenger charter operations. The Government believes that inbound tourism, especially, will be fostered by enabling passenger charter operators to play a real and complementary role to that already being undertaken by the scheduled carriers.
New guidelines for international freight and passenger charter operations are at Attachments C and D respectively.

Foreign Investment. The objective of the Government's decision to deregulate domestic aviation is to open up the industry to competition. Access to foreign capital could make an important contribution to this aim. Continuation of the special category status for aviation under the Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB) Guidelines would not be appropriate in a deregulated environment.

However, as I said earlier, this does not mean that an open skies policy will prevail domestically insofar as the capacity of foreign airlines, and in particular those operating international services to Australia, are concerned. Allowing foreign international airlines unlimited investment in domestic aviation or the right to operate such services, would not be appropriate while Qantas is so excluded.

However, the Government would not wish to totally exclude the contribution of equity capital by foreign international airlines. Accordingly, foreign investment in established Australian domestic airlines or new domestic airline businesses will generally be permitted, subject to the normal FIRB Guidelines, except where the applicant is a foreign international airline operating services to Australia, in which case the level of investment will be limited to less than 15% in any one domestic operator; this level having been accepted elsewhere in Commonwealth legislation as signifying the extent beyond which the interest would involve actual or potential control of the business in question. ``Foreign international airline operators'' will be sufficiently broadly defined to ensure that associated companies and substantial shareholders will be excluded.

The proposed prohibition on the operation of domestic services in Australia by foreign international airlines and the restriction on foreign investment in Australian airlines will obviously extend to proposals that have been floated for Air New Zealand to operate domestic services in Australia.
ROLE OF AUSTRALIAN AIRLINES

An essential element of the deregulated environment after 1990 will be a strong, viable, efficient Australian Airlines, able to provide effective competition across the trunk route network. This means it is essential that the constraints on the airline's management flexibility and effectiveness are minimised and that it has an adequate capital base..

In its public comment on the May Review, the Australian National Airlines Commission stated that the airline would have to undergo major changes to enable it to compete effective in future, and called for:
* establishment of the airline as a company;
* provision of an adequate capital base;
* exemption from Loan Council restrictions on commercial borrowings; and
* independence from controls in respect of its commercial activities, labour relations and staff remuneration.

Some progress has already been made, in recent times, in strengthening Australian's position. We provided a major capital injection in 1983, strengthened the airline's charter in 1984, and the Commission and staff have responded with improved results in recent years. I have also recently announced a number of new appointments to the Commission which will enhance its commercial orientation.

I want now to outline three further steps we propose to take to put Australian Airlines in the best possible shape to compete in the post 1990 environment, and in particular to address the concerns raised by the Commission in its response to the May Review.

Incorporation and removal of day-to-day controls. The first step we propose to take is to establish, as soon as possible, Australian Airlines as a public company, giving it exactly the same corporate structure and status as Qantas. In association with that step, we will take action to remove day-to-day controls over:
- all but exceptionally significant expenditure decisions (eg those requiring additional equity capital);
- detailed terms and conditions of borrowing and leasing arrangements (but not so as to involve removal from the requirement for Loan Council consideration);
- investment of surplus money;
- choice of auditor;
- dividend recommendations;
- provision for insurance against risk.
A number of advantages will flow from this initiative.

As a public company established under companies legislation, the airline will be subject to the normal provisions relating to control, performance, accountability and reporting of company activities. The directors will become fully responsible for the activities of the company, in particular the airline's financial performance, in line with their statutory obligations under the companies legislation. Incorporation will in itself operate to distance the airline from the public service environment and will help management and staff focus more closely on the airline's commercial objectives.
Removal of the day-to-day controls over the airline will help streamline management decision making and place increased responsibility with the airline's board, where it properly belongs.

Removal of Broader Controls. The second step the Government proposes to take, consistent with the approach set out in the Policy Discussion Paper on Statutory Authorities and Government Business Enterprises, is to examine the scope for removing other broader controls from Government business enterprises generally, and specifically, from Australian Airlines.

These controls involve borrowings by enterprises being subject to Loan Council consideration; remuneration of board members and senior executives being determined by the Remuneration Tribunal; industrial relations arrangements being subject to Government oversight and coordination; and certain restrictions being placed on the ability of business enterprises to adopt commercial superannuation arrangements.

Given the broad application of these controls, and the wide-ranging implications of their removal in any one Government enterprise, the scope for change in this area will be considered over the next few months by the Cabinet's Structural Adjustment Committee in the context of the further development of our policy on statutory authorities and government business enterprises generally.

Establishment of Advisory Group-Even if we take all the steps I have just foreshadowed-incorporation, removal of day-to-day controls, and consideration of the removal of more broad ranging controls-questions still remain as to how Australian Airlines will be able to optimise its managerial effectiveness in the post deregulation environment, and in particular how it will be able to meet its future recapital requirements.

The Government has decided, accordingly, to establish a high level Advisory Group to examine and report back to us within six months on any further measures that should be adopted to enable Australian Airlines to compete with maximum flexibility and efficiency in the context of imminent and actual economic deregulation.
The Advisory Group will comprise:

Mr Ted Harris-AO (Chairman)-Chairman (from 1 November 1987) of Australian National Airlines Commission (Australian Airlines); Managing Director and Chief Executive Officer of Ampol Ltd and Ampol Exploration Ltd.

Mr Colin Carter-Commissioner (from 1 November 1987) of Australian National Airlines Commission (Australian Airlines); partner with the consulting firm Pappas, Carter, Evans and Koop; former consultant with McKinsey and Co. Inc. and visiting lecturer at Yale University School of Public and Private Management.
Mr Bill Kelty-Secretary of the ACTU; Member of the Board of the Reserve Bank of Australia; and Member of the Economic Planning Advisory Council.

Mr Peter Redlich-Senior Partner of Holding Redlich & Co. Solicitors; Director AIDC (Australian Industrial Development Corporation) 1973-76; and Board Member AIRDIB (Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Board) 1983-86.

Dr Peter Wilenski-Secretary to the Department of Transport and Communications; former Chairman of the Public Service Board, and Secretary to the Departments of Education and Youth Affairs, and Labour and Immigration; and foundation Professor of the Australian Graduate School of Management from 1977-81.
The Group's terms of reference will be to advise the Government, against the possibility of either the removal or retention of the broad-ranging controls I have already referred to, on:
(a) the extent of Australian Airlines's capital requirements, and options for meeting these requirements; and
(b) means of enhancing the airline's management flexibility and effectiveness, and the efficiency of its operating structures.

Scope for Amalgamation with Qantas. The Government has considered suggestions that Australian Airlines and Qantas should be amalgamated, but has rejected this course of action. The Government has taken this decision, in part, on similar grounds to those I outlined earlier in support of the Government's decision that Qantas will, for the foreseeable future, remain Australia's sole international airline and will not be permitted to operate domestic scheduled air services. If such a proposed merger were to take place, it would be difficult for the Government to resist pressures from other domestic operators to be allowed to operate as designated international carriers, thereby placing the Government's single designation policy in jeopardy.

In any case, Qantas and Australian, neither of whom have sought amalgamation, undertake significantly different operations and require different aircraft fleets and business structures. Their route characteristics are such that only very limited opportunity exists for the exchange or substitution of aircraft between the two airlines, and there would be few substantial economies resulting from a merger in the short term.

If a merger were to occur there would, moreover, be a number of extremely complex, difficult and potentially volatile industrial relations issues demanding resolution, associated with the simultaneous employment of international and domestic flight crews who presently work under quite separate industrial awards.

It is, of course, open to both Qantas and Australian to enter into appropriate commercial arrangements-such as leasing of equipment and facilities or the operation of routes on behalf of the other-should this be to their mutual advantage, just as such arrangements are open to any other carriers.
CONCLUDING SUMMARY

Let me say, in conclusion, that what is involved in the Government's economic deregulation policy is not a simple, or simple-minded, lifting of existing controls, but a complex group of interacting policies involving a number of internal checks and balances.
The key elements of that total policy are, in summary, as follows:
(1) withdrawal from detailed economic regulatory controls over aircraft imports and capacity, air fares and route entry;
(2) continuation and enhancement of regulatory controls over aviation safety and security;

(3) watchdog protection for consumers through the application of the Trade Practices Act, appropriate fare scrutiny by the Prices Surveillance Authority (PSA), and assured access to terminal facilities by new entrants to the industry;

(4) action to strengthen Australian Airlines to confront the post 1990 environment, including immediate incorporation, removal of a number of public service controls immediately with a review of others to follow, and a full review of options available for generating necessary capitalisation and enhancing managerial effectiveness;

(5) neither Qantas nor any other international airline to carry domestic passengers or freight on regular services; international operators into Australia to be confined to less than 15% equity in any Australian domestic carrier; and Qantas to remain Australia's sole designated international carrier; and

(6) as interim measures to encourage competition before 1990, Qantas's interlining rights to be restored, and restrictions on large aircraft passenger charters by domestic operators to be modified; and arrangements for the approval of commercial domestic charters by Qantas to be subject to review on termination of the Airlines Agreement.

This option involves Commonwealth withdrawing from pricing and route entry controls, capacity determinations and control of import of aircraft on economic grounds. Safety regulatory controls remain.

The expected advantages of this option are improvements in economic efficiency; increased satisfaction of consumer demand through the availability of a wider range of fares and a greater variety in the types, standards and frequency of services; reduced regulatory costs; and even-handed treatment of all airline operators by the Government. The airline industry would become subject to normal industry controls such as Trade Practices and Prices Surveillance.

Implementation of this option could be expected to lead to the most favourable outcome for consumers, and the Australian economy as a whole, and allow for a far greater degree of competition in the aviation industry than the status quo or options 2 to 4.

It would be necessary to ensure that safety standards were maintained following economic deregulation. Overseas experience suggests that if this option were to be adopted then enhancement of the safety regulatory function would be desirable.

1. Australia's policy in relation to the operation of international non-scheduled cargo flights to and from Australia is that charter operators should be as free as possible to conduct genuine non-scheduled operations.
(a) Non-scheduled cargo-only flights may carry mixed consignments of any cargo into and out of Australia.
(b) The aeronautical authorities of all countries involved in any proposed flights must accept them as being genuine non-scheduled operations.
(c) Applications for single entity, own use and one-off flights and for ad hoc programs of up to three months may reasonably expect automatic approval.

(d) Applications for programs of charters for periods longer than three months and up to twelve months will be considered on a case-by-case basis, particularly where proposals involve new market opportunities.
2. Factors such as foreign policy considerations, or air service negotiations and arrangements, will be taken into account in assessing applications.
3. Flights will be subject to normal operational and safety requirements, and the requirements of the Air Navigation Act and Regulations.
ATTACHMENT D
GUIDELINES FOR INTERNATIONAL PASSENGER CHARTER FLIGHTS

1. A principal aim of Australia's aviation policies is to promote the development and maintenance of a network of commercially viable regular scheduled services between Australia and overseas. Non-scheduled (charter) operations are encouraged where these are compatible with this objective. Development of inbound tourism to Australia is of special interest.

2. Applications for non-scheduled services to Australia fall into two categories: those that will receive automatic approval, and those that will be considered on a case-by-case basis. Guidelines in relation to each of these categories, as well as a number of general requirements applicable to all international passenger charters, are set out below.
A. APPLICATIONS TO RECEIVE AUTOMATIC APPROVAL
3. Single or ad-hoc charters of the following types will receive automatic approval:
(a) Affinity group;
(b) Own-use charters where passengers do not contribute to meeting costs of the operation (eg including mineral exploration and employee incentive/reward flights);
(c) Special event charters; or
(d) Round-the-world and other drop-in charters which include Australia as part of a broader itinerary.
4. Programs of charters with each of the following characteristics will also receive automatic approval:
(a) Charters which are inbound, ie carrying foreign passengers only to Australia and out again.

(b) Where the proposed charter flights are over routes not currently served on a scheduled basis by airlines designated under air services arrangements between Australia and the other country(s) concerned. Flights to Australia may arrive and depart from different gateways. Passengers carried on the charter flights to/from Australia may stopover at one gateway and depart via another gateway on separate flights in a charter program.

(c) A charter program which comprises up to 4 return services per month and operates for up to 3 consecutive months. The positioning legs on the first outbound and last inbound flight are not counted in the number of services. Further programs could be approved, but would be considered after a review of the first program. Pending the completion of the review, charter flights beyond the end of the first program may be approved on an ad-hoc basis. The main criterion in giving approval for further programs is that they continue to meet the Guidelines for automatic approval; and that all conditions of approval of the first program were complied with; and

(d) All passengers on charter services must have purchased a significant ground component as part of their travel for consumption in Australia, in addition to the airfare component. This would include, for example, accommodation and ground tours.
B. APPLICATIONS TO RECEIVE CASE-BY-CASE CONSIDERATION

5. Applications which do not meet the terms and conditions set out above will be considered on a case-by-case basis. For example, where there is interest in developing new market opportunities, but end-to-end traffic levels are not sufficient to support commercially viable direct scheduled services, sympathetic consideration may be given to programs of charters whose purpose is to test and develop markets and traffic flows. The size of program and associated conditions would depend on the particular circumstances.
6. In considering all applications in this category, regard will be had to:

(a) origin of expected traffic, whether there are scheduled services between that country and destinations in Australia to which charters would operate, and the adequacy of such scheduled services; and
(b) whether there might be adverse impact on commercial viability of scheduled services.
C. GENERAL REQUIREMENTS

7. While any operator is eligible to seek approval to operate non-scheduled services, a condition of approval is that operators must comply with Australia's normal operational and safety requirements. Information for intending applications is contained in the Australian Aeronautical Information Publications (AIP-FAL).

8. Approval of charter programs or individual charter flights must also be obtained from the authorities of the other country(s) involved. The onus is on the operator to obtain such approval and the Australian Government takes no responsibility for the operator's failure to do so.
9. Charter operators will be required to provide evidence that suitable consumer protection arrangements are in place.

10. Approval may be deferred or not granted for foreign policy reasons, or where the proposal impinges on air services negotiations or rights exchanged between Australia and the country(s) from which the charters were to originate.
11. In the event that, in the operation of a charter flight or program, the operator breached one or more elements of the foregoing guidelines, approval may be withdrawn at one months notice.

12. An operator having received approval for, or having commenced a charter program, could normally expect to complete that program should a scheduled carrier subsequently obtain approval to commence a regular scheduled service over a route on which the charter operator was flying. Further programs would be subject to a review to determine whether traffic demand was sufficient to allow for charter operations to continue should a scheduled service subsequently commence on a route.
OCTOBER 1987

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move an amendment to the motion which has just been moved by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add:

``, and notes the long overdue adoption by the Government of a substantial part of the Coalition's aviation policy; further notes the Government's de facto decision to privatise Australian Airlines, which is the inevitable and proper consequence of the deregulation of the airline industry; and condemns the Government for:

(a) the time lost since the first day that notice of termination of the Two Airlines Agreement could have been given (January 1987) and the effect this has had on the postponement of the commencement of deregulation of the Australian airline industry;
(b) its inaction during this period in not preventing the removal of competitors in the airline industry, which will substantially reduce competition;

(c) the repeal of legislation which the previous Coalition Government had in place to convert the then Trans Australia Airlines (TAA) into a company, thereby reducing the ability of TAA to readily adjust to the new deregulated environment;
(d) the absence of pre-1990 informal measures to facilitate deregulation;
(e) its failure to provide the necessary infrastructure at Australia's airports, especially Kingsford-Smith Airport in Sydney, so as to cope with present and, more importantly, future congestion;
(f) not completely deregulating domestic and international airfreight carried by Australian airlines; and
(g) creating unnecessary uncertaintly amongst Australian Airline employees as to their future''.

The statement which the Minister has delivered today is clearly a long overdue adoption by the Government of a substantial part of the coalition's aviation policy. It is absolutely clear, from the body of the document itself, that there has been a de facto decision to privatise Australian Airlines. That is the situation. It does not matter whether we look at it sideways, upside down or backwards; it still comes out the same: there has been a decision by the Hawke Labor Government to privatise Australian Airlines. The reasons are quite clear. I would like to set out those reasons as we go through in some detail the amendment which I have just moved. The Minister, at page 37 of his statement, announced the establishment of an advisory group to undertake an examination of the operations of Australian Airlines. I will quote from his statement. He says:

Even if we take all the steps I have just foreshadowed-incorporation, removal of day-to-day controls, and consideration of the removal of more broad ranging controls-questions still remain as to how Australian Airlines will be able to optimise its managerial effectiveness in the post deregulation environment, and in particular how it will be able to meet its future capital requirements.

That statement refers to the establishment of a company to operate Australian Airlines. It acknowledges, firstly, that Australian Airlines, being publicly owned, will not have the capacity to raise enough capital and that, consequently, in order to undertake its commitments in the 1990s it needs to be converted to a public company, obviously as a precursor to its being floated on the public stock exchanges, allowing ownership by ordinary Australians. That is absolutely consistent with the Liberal and National parties' attitude to the privatisation of Australian Airlines as enunciated in our aviation policy at the election in July.

It is quite clear that the Government is intending to privatise Australian Airlines. One wonders why it has not come out and said it is going to do it now. It is skipping round with words-weasel words, as some people would say-describing changes in managerial capacity and the capacity to raise future capital requirements. It talks about managerial effectiveness and sets up an advisory group of people who obviously have expertise in this area to advise on how this will occur. But why does it not face the fact that it is going down the track of privatisation, and why does it not say so?

It is particularly galling to note that the Minister draws back from the edge of saying that after we have heard Ansett Airlines in recent times, in talking about the whole issue of deregulation of the airlines and the privatisation of Australian Airlines, make this point absolutely clear. Let me repeat what Ansett has said. It has said that, before any deregulation of the airlines can occur, Australian Airlines should be privatised and put into public ownership for the Australian people. That is what Ansett Airlines says. It is the competitor of Australian Airlines. But what has this Government said? It has turned the approach around the other way. It has said, `We are going to deregulate first', and left in the air the questions of privatisation. I repeat: the people who are closest to the industry say that it should be done the other way around so as to ensure the proper privatisation of Australian Airlines. The Government has apparently embarked on a course which may not lead to the success with the privatisation of the Australian airlines that it would want.

The de facto decision to privatise is quite clear when we look at the various details of the statement that has been put out. The decision which the Government has taken on deregulation is obviously leading to a freer environment amongst Australian airline operators. That is to be welcomed and is certainly something which we in the Liberal and National parties have been pushing for some time. But if the Government has decided on this route-and clearly it has-why did it, when it first came to power in 1983, as one of its first acts, repeal the very legislation which the Fraser Government had put in place during its period of office up to 1983 which set up Australian Airlines, then called Trans Australia Airlines, as a public company? The situation is now reversed. The Government has gone back on its tracks and is now leading in the direction of privatisation, which is obviously inevitable, and again is facing the folly of its earlier mistakes in that area.

The whole purpose of today's announcement is to act as a smokescreen for what is to come in the months ahead. The Labor Party is engaged in an enormous internal debate over the whole question of privatisation. The decision it makes will affect Australian Airlines, Telecom Australia, the Overseas Telecommunications Commission, Aussat and numerous other government bodies. Every day we read of the differences of opinion expressed by members of the Labor Party about privatisation. We can understand that the Labor Party is split on this issue. Indeed, we welcome the decision of the Cabinet to press on with this important development for Australia's future, because it is acknowledged that it is the only way in which airlines and other Commonwealth instrumentalities will be able to raise sufficient capital to meet the needs of the community in the years ahead. That is why the Opposition supports the decision that has been announced. We make it absolutely clear that we support the Cabinet decision of the Hawke Labor Government on this matter. Consequently, we wish the Labor Party all the best in the debates that ensue in its efforts to change its platform in July next year.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are all heart.
—We will be rooting on the sidelines for you, Senator, and wishing you all the best. I wish now to turn to the detail of my amendment. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: and notes the long overdue adoption by the Government of a substantial part of the Coalition's aviation policy; further notes the Government's de facto decision to privatise Australian Airlines, which is the inevitable and proper consequence of the deregulation of the airline industry;

That is the fundamental point that we in the Liberal and National parties wish to make today: The Government has decided to privatise Australian Airlines and, consequently, it is now incumbent upon the Labor Party to fall in line with the decision of Cabinet to ensure that that occurs. My amendment then details several points that I wish to discuss. The amendment continues:
and condemns the Government for:

(a) the time lost since the first day that notice of termination of the Two Airlines Agreement could have been given (January 1987) and the effect this has had on the postponement of the commencement of deregulation of the Australian airline industry;

Clearly the Government had the power to make this decision almost a year ago, yet it failed to do so. The reason it failed to do so was that it was facing an election. It denied that it intended to hold that election some time in 1987 and particularly early in 1987. Clearly it was not in the Government's perceived political interests to expose an issue such as the privatisation of Australian Airlines at a time leading up to an election. Obviously the interests of Australians were again sacrificed in order to ensure that there were as few ripples as possible within the Labor Party on the very vexed question, to its members, of privatisation. Again the delay in the decision being taken occurred purely for political purposes and had no relationship to the best interests of the Australian community. Paragraph (b) of my amendment reads:
its inaction-
that is, the Government's inaction-
during this period in not preventing the removal of competitors in the airline industry, which will substantially reduce competition;

During the Government's period of inaction and delay since last January, we have seen the takeover of East-West Airlines Ltd. The de facto third airline in this country was swallowed up by Ansett Airlines. Consequently, competition in the airline industry has diminished. That take- over would not have occurred and perhaps the best interests of Australia would have been better served had East-West Airlines been allowed to continue its operations in another fashion. The Government's inaction of almost a year ago has meant that East-West Airlines has been swept off the board as a future competitor in a deregulated airline market. Again, that is a direct result of the Hawke Labor Government putting its political interests ahead of the interests of the people of Australia. That has been the long and sorry history of this Government since it came to power in March 1983. Paragraph (c) of my amendment reads:

the repeal of legislation which the previous Coalition Government had in place to convert the then Trans Australia Airlines (TAA) into a company, thereby reducing the ability of TAA to readily adjust to the new deregulated environment;

This is a most important paragraph in my amendment. Honourable senators will well remember the debates that took place in this Parliament in 1982 when the Fraser Government was pushing through legislation to set up TAA as a public company. During those debates members of the Labor Party, including those who are now part of the Hawke Labor Cabinet, expressed the view that such a move would have a detrimental effect on the interests of Australians, particularly rural Australians. Yet, that very principle has now been adopted by the Hawke Government some four and a half years late, at a time when the processes of deregulating the airline industry in this country will be set back.

Again, the former coalition's policies have been vindicated by the actions of this Government; they have finally been accepted. We on this side of the chamber applaud the Government for coming to its senses, albeit so late. However, we are getting used to that from the Hawke Labor Government. This proposal can join the long list of proposals put forward by the Liberal and National parties, both in government and in opposition, which have been taken up finally by this Government in its own time. On this occasion it once again has done so at a time which is most suitable to it politically rather than to the best interests of the Australian people. Para- graph (d) of my amendment reads:
The absence of pre-1990 informal measures to facilitated deregulation;
