Mr Acting Deputy President, you may not know that when the aviation industry in the United States was deregulated some years ago, although a certain formal date was fixed for that deregulation, informal negotiations took place which led to that deregulation occurring ahead of the fixed date. We believe that the way is well open for this Government to undertake such informal negotiations with Ansett Airlines and Australian Airlines to set in train the deregulation of the airline industry before the two-airline agreement ends in 1990. However, the Government has not seen fit to consider that course. We know the reason for that. Again, the public interest is being set aside in favour of the internal processes of the Labor Party. We know that Labor Party members will have to debate such proposals at their national conference next July in order to determine Labor Party policy on privatisation. Consequently, all these matters should be set aside until after the Labor Party has determined its policy. Australia is bumbling along under this Government which has no clear policy. It is the Government's objective in the meantime to organise its members for when the vote is taken on the floor of the Labor Party conference.

The agreement has some three years to run before it collapses. Consequently, there is plenty of time for this Government to initiate discussions with the airline industry to start a new era of aviation development in this country by encouraging the operators presently in the field to adopt new techniques which the Government expects to operate after 1990. Again, that is not on the Labor Party's agenda because it simply does not have the political will to push the issue through its national conference. Rather it has to wait and see what its masters in the trade union movement will allow it to do before undertaking the proper measures of deregulation and privatisation. In my amendment point (e) states that the Government is condemned for:
its failure to provide the necessary infrastructure at Australia's airports, especially the Kingsford-Smith Airport in Sydney, so as to cope with present and, more importantly, future congestion;

Mr Acting Deputy President, the Liberal and National parties have set down in their aviation policy that a Liberal government would investigate the implementation of a far more open approach to the development of the necessary airport terminals in places that are obviously bursting at the seams at present and that need redevelopment. That does not receive any attention in the Minister's statement. That is to be regretted because it seems that there is a lack of co-ordination in what the Government is intending to do with deregulation, which presumably means more business for the airlines, and its lack of consideration of its impact upon infrastructure support at airports.

All of us who often travel by air through New South Wales know of the congestion that occurs at Sydney Airport at various times, the delays that occur to the travelling public as a result of not being able to land because of aircraft congestion in the area. Yet this Government does not address that matter in this statement by the Minister. It is absolutely vital to the future development of aviation that the question be addressed.

Again we have to ask the question: Is there some political reason why the Government is not addressing this? We do not have to look too far for the answer. We all know, firstly, that the Sydney Airport question is of great political concern to the Australian Labor Party in New South Wales. Secondly, the New South Wales Government under Premier Unsworth will hold an election within the next few months, certainly before the ALP conference that will lead to such trouble for the ALP next July. So again the political interests of the Labor Party are being put before the interests of the nation and before the interests of the travelling public, particularly those people who use Sydney Airport. Again the political interests of Mr Unsworth are being best served by this Minister who in his statement has refused even to comment upon the problems of Sydney Airport which, as we know, are becoming more and more extensive. Paragraph (f) of my amendment states that the Government is condemned for:
not completely deregulating domestic and international airfreight carried by Australian airlines . . .

including Qantas. That is of very real concern to those who need the services of air freight carriers in this country. We all know that freight costs are an enormous burden for business and consequently for the consumer in Australia. Therefore, one would have thought that the Government would have tackled that area immediately. We can only assume that again action in the interest of the Australian community is being delayed because the Government faces internal political problems with its debate over privatisation and will not be prepared to face up to that issue until it has resolved that point at its national conference in July of next year. That means further burdens for the Australian community at a time when we have very extensive cost structures which are helping to increase the uncompetitiveness of Australian industry, which make it more difficult for us to serve our markets overseas and consequently sell effectively and create jobs for Australians. Again the Australian community's position is being put second to the political needs of the Hawke Labor Government. The last point in my amendment, (g), reads:
creating unnecessary uncertainty amongst Australian airline employees as to their future.

As I said at the outset, the move by the Government announced today is a de facto move for the privatisation of Australian Airlines; there is no doubt about that. Because the Government has not been prepared to say clearly that that is its intention, this will generate concern amongst the employees of Australian Airlines. They must be in some doubt over the next year or two before decisions are finally taken by this Government as to its intentions. They will not know, for instance, whether they will have jobs in the future or whether they will be able to purchase shares in the new public company that might be established for Australian Airlines. They do not know whether they will be required in future. Those matters are of very great concern to the Liberal and National parties. People who work for Australian Airlines have every reason to be disturbed at the Government's lack of clarity in the statement today and its lack of commitment and certainly its lack of candidacy at this time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Candour.

—Candour. Candidacy is what you and I usually do, Senator. The lack of candour by the Government on this matter must be of great concern to the people. The Government makes play of two particular things in the announcement today. It has given special attention to two matters. The first is consumer protection. We in the Liberal and National parties support fully the approach of allowing the Trade Practices Commission to view the operations of airlines and to ensure that proper practices are engaged in. The other point is of less value to the community and that is the involvement of the Prices Surveillance Authority. One has to wonder what the Government has in mind with this move if it is really interested in true competition. It seems to me that introducing surveillance of prices and the possible setting of minimum and maximum prices does not necessarily serve the best interests of the Australian community in a competitive environment. That seems to be a rather contradictory objective of the Government in this situation when it has put down so many lofty and worthy ideals that it is seeking to achieve by the deregulation of Australian Airlines as it has now announced in this statement. So one has to wonder about the real intentions of the Government in that area.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally I turn to safety. We of course support the Government's strong commitment to the maintenance of the highest level of safety standards for the operation of Australian airlines. Everbody recognises that this is the No. 1 priority in the operation of Australia's airlines. However, one wonders at the wisdom of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in selecting the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support, Mr Duncan, as the Minister in charge of investigating the legislation for safety standards when we have already observed how easy it is for Mr Duncan, as Senator Gareth Evans's offsider in the Department of Transport and Communications, to get it wrong. He cannot even read and interpret correctly a ministerial brief in respect of the Amann Aviation Pty Ltd affair in the House of Representatives.

I hope that the Minister for Transport and Communications will be double guessing Mr Duncan because, quite clearly, there will be some lack of commitment by this side of the House to trust Mr Duncan's efforts until we see quite clearly what he will be proposing. So we hope that the Minister for Transport and Communications will take a direct and personal interest in this most important matter for the benefit of all Australians who are using the airlines. Unfortunately, with the Minister's history of commitment to the airlines, to safety and to certain other flight activities, in one way or another, we cannot be certain that even that is in the best of hands. Nevertheless, let me restate the Liberal and National parties' commitment to the principle that safety standards in the air are a No. 1 priority. We will be ensuring, with all the vigilance at our disposal, that the Government sees to it that those safety standards are maintained and we will be giving all reasonable support to measures that are designed to enhance that. This is notwithstanding the fact that Mr Duncan may be bringing those measures forward. We will, of course, be examining them all the more closely because he is bringing them forward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support and second the amendment to the motion moved by my colleague Senator Messner. I should say at the outset-I hope that the Government will accept this statement of our position-that we naturally welcome any movement in this or indeed any other area of the economy towards greater deregulation. If the statement which the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) has put down were merely a statement designed to further the cause of deregulation in Australia I would have nothing but praise for it. Again, so as not to be misunderstood, let me say that of course I welcome the motion, taken in isolation, to bring to an end the two-airline agreement, although I notice that that motion is being advanced only in the Senate today and I understand that it is not presently being advanced in the other chamber, which gives rise to some questions perhaps as to whether this matter is quite so straightforward. Of course, I may be incorrect in that speculation but time will tell and I will look at the facts as they develop.

SPEECH.PARA: But my chief point, and the point I want to focus upon in these remarks, is the falsehood which the Government again seeks to perpetrate in putting forward this motion today as a motion concerned with deregulating the airline industry. It is a motion which, in its practical essentials, is about selling Australian Airlines; there should be no mistake about that. Of course, it is a very elaborate move to cover that underlying objective. The enormously lengthy statement, which was made available to the Opposition at 8 o'clock this morning and which Senator Evans incorporated in Hansard when he spoke earlier, has obviously, from any reading of it, been very carefully crafted, and I compliment the Minister in that respect. Of course, the time and expertise and the political input which have gone into its crafting are also evident in the fact that we are blessed-if that is the appropriate word-with what I might call a somewhat jazzed-up version of the same statement which not only sets it out in very nicely printed form but also benefits us with a photograph of the Minister, not normally a matter which I would feel necessary to record among my remunerations in this place.

To return to my basic theme, I have to say that the key to this whole document is not that it is yet another move on the part of a government committed to deregulation and enjoying the deserved plaudits, in some respects, of the public in that regard, but that it is a move which seeks to overlay an underlying political decision on the Government's part to sell off Australian Airlines. I make it very plain, and I think Senator Messner has also, that we on this side of the chamber welcome that decision. What we deplore is the Government's lack of candour in not telling us and the Australian public. Once again, this Government is making, I believe, the philosophical error-the Government may not think it is a political error-of attempting to deceive the Australian public about its true intentions. However, whether it will be successful in that regard remains to be seen.

I happened to note on page 10 of this morning's Australian Financial Review an article by Anne Davies entitled `Gareth Evans crosses privatisation Rubicon'. I do not know that I want to follow that particular allusion too far. We have enough Caesars on the Government side of the House without letting another one come into office. I would just like to quote the opening paragraph of that article because I think it sums up-and I give full marks to its author for this-the reality underlying this motion from the Government side. The paragraph in question reads as follows:
Despite assurances that the question of privatisation of Australian Airlines will be left until next year's ALP National Conference, the announcement today-
that is, the announcement by Senator Evans today-
on deregulation of the airline industry will further commit the Government to the privatisation road.
I cannot stress too much that that is what we are talking about today. That is what this debate and the resumed debate on Friday, or whenever it is, will be and should be concentrating upon.

Let us look in a little more detail at some aspect of the Minister's statement; not so much the statement that the Minister has just made to the chamber but the lengthy document in printed form which I referred to earlier in these remarks. The Minister said at the very outset that this motion:
will bring the two airlines policy to an end-
and this is the key point-
and open Australia's interstate air services to free competition.

Let us look at the question of whether that is what it will do, or perhaps what interpretation we should place upon the words `free competition' in that context. I think I am correct in saying that, as things stand in the airline industry today, it is the two-airline agreement upon which, ironically enough, Australian Airlines depends for its economic and financial survival. As we all know, that was not the situation when the two-airline agreement was initiated. The whole purpose of that agreement at the time of its initiation was to protect Ansett-ANA or whatever it was called in those days. Today, through a process which I do not have time to go into, essentially the market share of Australian Airlines is heavily dependent upon the existence and operation of the two-airline agreement. It would follow from that quite inevitably, even if nothing else were to happen in the intervening three years, that the termination of the two-airline agreement would undoubtedly place Australian Airlines under the most severe pressure from its major competitor, Ansett Airlines of Australia.

Of course, some other things will be happening in the intervening three years. They have already begun to happen. I refer particularly to the takeover of East-West Airlines Ltd, a matter which I understand is, in some aspects at least, still before the Trade Practices Commission. It is very clear that in a deregulated situation the takeover by Ansett of East-West Airlines will add further to the position of market dominance that that company already holds as against Australian Airlines. Again I do not want to be misunderstood; I repeat, the Opposition welcomes the proposal by the Government to end the two-airline agreement. It welcomes the deregulatory aspects of that proposal but points out that what this motion is really about is a decision in effect to bypass-I think that is the best word-the Australian Labor Party national conference next July at which time the whole question of privatisation, including not least the privatisation of Australian Airlines, was to be debated. No doubt it still will be debated at that time but in a formal sense only. So let us have that clearly on the table.

The Minister's circulated statement also says that, as a result of the termination of the two-airline agreement, existing constraints on the entry of new domestic operators to trunk routes will be removed. In theory, that is perfectly true. The question is: How relevant to the facts or the likely facts is that theory? I suggest that it is not very relevant at all and that we will see the two existing major airlines operating on these trunk routes and we will not have new domestic operators to provide the competition that ideally one would like to see. To quote from the Minister's circulated statement, in that regard the Government has said:
It is the Government's belief that the aviation industry does not display characteristics which significantly distinguish it from other industries.

That is a view the Government is entitled to put and have debated, not merely in this chamber but publicly, but I remind the Minister of the view to the contrary which has been stated publicly by none other than the Trade Practices Commission in its supplementary submission to the May Independent Review of Economic Regulation of Domestic Aviation in March last year. At that time the Trade Practices Commission quite correctly stated that the two-airline policy, and therefore the two-airline situation, `could best be described as securing a monopoly consisting of two airlines'. That is not what one would normally describe as an industry which does not display characteristics which significantly distinguish it from other industries.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are talking about after the post-deregulation situation.

—I am aware of that, but I am saying that this highly capital intensive industry, in which one company already has a considerable stranglehold on the market and will obtain, as a result of the termination of the two-airline agreement, an even greater stranglehold on the market, is not one in which ease of entry will be simple. I hope that statement, at any rate, will not be contested even from the Government side of the House.
—It is perfectly true.

—It is perfectly true. Senator Evans is correct on this occasion. I welcome the Minister's assent to my proposition. We do not need it, in one sense, because we have an even more informed authority than the Minister, and certainly than myself, on these matters in the person of none other than Sir Peter Abeles. On 12 August last he was interviewed on the Carleton-Walsh Report when Mr Carleton was still enjoying the privilege of working for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. Mr Carleton put a proposition to Sir Peter Abeles. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: But you will also be able to dominate the aviation industry in Australia, won't you?
To that proposition Sir Peter replied:
We will be the dominant airline.

So, there is no question about what the outcome of this set of decisions will be. It will be to make Ansett Airlines, in the words of its principal, Sir Peter Abeles, the dominant airline. Because of that, because of these quite ineluctable economic facts, there will be no alternative for the Government but to proceed to sell off, to privatise, Australian Airlines. The alternative would be to see Australian Airlines simply go down the tube. Those members of the Labor Party who are presently struggling desperately to preserve an objective I do not share, namely, to preserve Australian Airlines in the public sector, will be struggling just as desperately under those circumstances to get it sold in order to help preserve some competition in the industry. Of course, they will have our full support. It is just that we on this side of the chamber would like to see the Government coming clean about this matter, not merely with the Australian people generally but even with its own dissenters, if I may put it that way.

We have before us this morning a dissembling statement, a statement which purports to move towards a certain outcome but under the cloak of that actually moves towards not a different outcome, because the purported outcome will be present, but a very much wider outcome; one that contains a major political objective on the part of the Executive Government as distinct from the Labor Party Caucus, at this time at least, namely to sell off, to privatise, Australian Airlines. That is what this motion is about.

In the statement that the Minister was good enough to circulate and provide to us earlier today it is stated that the Government has taken the view that there is a need to apply the Trade Practices Act to the new aviation industry environment. Naturally, again, we on this side of the chamber welcome that statement of intent. However, what can such a statement mean in the circumstances in prospect?

As I have said, we have an industry which is presently characterised by two major operators, one of which is inherently very considerably more powerful than the other. Indeed, it does not go too far to say that the other airline is essentially being propped up by the two-airline agreement, and the Government is proposing to terminate that agreement. The outcome of that can only be that Australian Airlines will suffer very considerably in terms of the openly competitive situation it will then face. It will be starting so far behind scratch that I think it is fair to say it is unlikely to make the grade under those loaded dice conditions. One must ask whether, indeed, this is not yet another example-as we have seen in some other areas of policy in recent times; not least, the media-of the Government moving, in its mysterious ways, to look after some of its friends. I do not assert that view at this time, but we on this side of the chamber will, of course, be watching very closely the future development of events in this area.

I turn to one or two particular aspects of the amendment to the Minister's motion moved by my colleague Senator Messner. As I think he pointed out, if the Government had been serious and had been open, frank and candid about these matters, if it had actually been moved by the spirit of deregulation to which it now claims to adhere in this area of policy, it would have been open to it to move in this matter a good deal earlier, in fact, some nine months or so ago. Yet, it did not do so.

In one sense I suppose it is hardly worth again recording the point-but I shall do so for the sake of the record-that one of the machinery hurdles which the Government will have to surmount as it approaches its new-found task of selling Australian Airlines lies in the fact that it actually repealed legislation passed by the previous coalition Government, which had at that time already converted what was then Trans Australia Airlines or TAA, now Australian Airlines, to company form. If that legislation had not been repealed it would have been much easier for the Government to move forward on the sale of Australian Airlines to its actual but undeclared objective of selling Australian Airlines, I presume without having to bring into this Parliament new legislation-to which, I should say, we would give a very good wind-which would do no more, effectively, than simply restore the legislation which this Government so wilfully and dogmatically repealed when it first came to office. Unimportant in one sense though the point may be, in another sense nothing could more clearly reveal the cynicism with which this Government has approached the whole difficult and vexed question of airline policy during the past 4 1/2 years.

As my colleague Senator Messner said, the abuse which was heaped on members of the Opposition-of which at that stage I was not a part-by Ministers of this Government in the last two or three years, not merely in the context of the privatisation debate generally but in the context of this matter in particular, does not make pretty history when today we find Senator Evans coming into this chamber, putting his hand on his heart and saying that he stands for deregulation but, sotto voce, not incorporated in Hansard, that he also stands for the selling off of Australian Airlines. I do not wish to be unduly unkind to the Minister, but I think that one has to say that today we are witnessing an act of palpable hypocrisy on the part of Senator Evans. I think we should put that on the record.

I repeat what I said at the outset of these remarks-that the Opposition welcomes this move to end the two-airline policy. That is the declared objective of Senator Evans's motion. We welcome it. What we deplore is the lack of candour in the Minister's statement and the Government's position in not coming clean with the Senate and, through us, the Parliament and the people of this country more generally by saying that what this motion is really about is selling Australian Airlines. Again-let me be clear-we approve of that proposal, although it is really a non-proposal, a concealed proposal. We approve of that, but we thoroughly disapprove of the Government's lack of candour, its disingenuousness and its characteristic lack of frankness with the Australian people which leads it to seek to conceal its real motives in bringing forward this motion today.

I conclude these remarks by quoting a further two or three paragraphs from that article in the Australian Financial Review to which I referred earlier. Again, I think the writer is to be congratulated on her perceptiveness as to what this particular proposal is all about. She states:
The question of whether Australian-
I think she means Australian Airlines-
faces death by `slow strangulation'-
following the ending of the two-airline agreement-
through lack of capital and inability to change quickly will be brought into sharp focus.

Indeed it will. Nothing so wonderfully concentrates an airline executive's mind than the thought that he is to be commercially hanged in the morning. That is what I think, in commercial terms at least, this proposal will actually do to Australian Airlines.

TALK.START.PARA: —He sounded remarkably cheerful on radio this morning under those circumstances.
—I am sure he was. I again quote the article:

SPEECH.PARA: More importantly, Senator Evans' game plan will tend to limit viability of alternatives that the Left-
I presume Miss Davies means the Left in the Minister's Party-
has been working on-such as an amalgamation of Qantas and Australian.

I do not want to comment on that proposal for the amalgamation of Qantas Airways Ltd and Australian Airlines, but merely note the comment which obviously is correct-indeed, I had this partly in mind when I paid my earlier compliments to the Minister about the carefully crafted nature of his statement-that that option has indeed been locked out. I see the Minister nodding his head and expressing appreciation of the accuracy of my comments. It is clear that the author of the article in this morning's Australian Financial Review is perfectly correct in the assumption that the Minister's statement has been carefully crafted to:
limit viability of alternatives that the Left-
that is, the Left of the Australian Labor Party-
has been working on . . .

It is obviously correct. At the end of the day, when it is clear that we are moving-as we are at last, thank goodness-towards the ending of the two-airline agreement, the whole thrust of expressions of opinion from employees of Australian Airlines, not merely from the executive, which I think has been in favour of it for some time, but from the staff, the employees, of that organisation, will be towards asking the Government to get the airline out of government hands and into the private sector as quickly as possible because otherwise-and probably in any case-the airline will have its commercial throat cut. Of course, as the writer of the article says:
The need for capital to meet the onslaught from Ansett will finally lead the Government towards the privatisation path.

There is no question that this will finally lead the Government there: it is there already. It is simply that the Government has not told us that as yet. I repeat that we welcome the Minister's proposal to end the two-airline agreement and we welcome the underlying proposal, namely the proposed sale of Australian Airlines, but we very much deplore the Government's lack of candour in not telling us or the Australian people that that is its underlying motivation for this statement today.
Debate (on motion by Senator McKiernan) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 September, on motion by Senator Tate:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has commenced debating the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1987, which is a massive document. It is about 89 pages long and the Bill proposes amendments to 87 Acts and repeals 24 Acts. During the last decade it has become regular practice to have one or two such Bills every year. They are said to contain only drafting and technical matters, but from time to time items arousing some political controversy have found their way into the Bills. I read from the general outline in the explanatory memorandum:

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments made by this Bill have a number of purposes such as the tidying up, correction or updating of legislation. Other amendments implement changes that are of minor policy significance or are of a routine administrative nature. None of the amendments made by this Bill has any significant financial impact.

The idea of having such Bills was introduced during the period of the Fraser Government. They were a means whereby the Parliament could readily deal with a large number of amendments of a minor nature without any great delay. As I said, this Bill amends 87 Acts and repeals 24 Acts. So in one measure the Parliament is able to deal with what in the past would have required 111 Acts of Parliament. So, of course, this has been a very effective way of reducing the amount of wasted time in the Parliament. One could perhaps mention to Mr Kelty that this would probably be of some relevance in a productivity claim. There can, however, be some difficulty in that the practice in effect limits the time that members of parliament have to debate various policy matters. There is always the possibility that the Government can fail properly to draw some controversial matter to the attention of the Parliament. We always have the worry that something we have missed will slip through in this massive document. The other thing is that such legislation tends to treat the Parliament simply as a processing machine.

Opposition shadow Ministers and, no doubt, Australian Democrats shadow Ministers and va-rious other people try to examine the legislation in detail with a view to ascertaining whether there is some matter that really ought to be considered by the Parliament in more detail. We hope that we have not missed something. The Opposition is so concerned about this matter that in the other place-I point this out to the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate)-it is going to propose that one of the standing committees, which the House of Representatives is intending to establish under the new processes ought to be given the job of analysing such legislation in the future and reporting to the Parliament as to whether there are any matters of concern to which the Parliament ought to give greater detailed consideration. In due course a proposal of that nature will be introduced in the other House by our shadow Attorney-General, Mr Peter Reith.

In the meantime, there are a number of matters with which we will be dealing in the committee stage and which need some explanations. Those matters will be dealt with by way of amendments. I just mention that matters of great significance are concerned. For example, I notice that in the Acts Interpretation Act one provision deals with the rule of interpretation that `may' means `shall' in some circumstances. That has always seemed to me to be a most peculiar provision, but the truth is that under the interpretation of Acts of parliament in the past there have been occasions when the courts have decided that the word `may' did not grant a discretion but really meant `shall'. For example, a Bill which says that the Governor-General in Council may appoint someone to a particular position in fact means that the Governor-General in Council shall appoint someone to the position. That is the sort of example the layman may understand more easily.

What happened in the past was that every time the parliamentary draftsman used the word `may' he added the words `at his discretion'. In other words, the person had an absolute discretion. But the draftsman ran into difficulty with our new non-sexist language and so he had to say `at his or her discretion'-which has become a very difficult task. The parliamentary draftsman is now proposing to overcome this problem by always using the word `may' as meaning `may' and never meaning `shall'. In this Bill there is a proposal to define the word `may' as always importing a discretion.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is much clearer, thank you.

—I understand the complexity of this matter but the truth is that it will be of great interest to lawyers-yet it is going through in this Bill which deals with amendments to 87 Acts. Lawyers all round Australia will have to be aware that in future `may' means `may'. As a matter of interest it means may only in relation to any future Bills passed.
—It may mean may.
—In certain circumstances.
—Yes, in future circumstances it will mean may and in past circumstances it may mean shall. I hope that is very clear.

SPEECH.PARA: Policy items are included in this Bill. For example, it deals with the Canned Fruits Marketing Act 1979 and extends the life of the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation by some 12 months. Of course, the Opposition supports that proposal, but it is a policy matter, not simply a mechanical matter. In the amendment to the Dairy Produce Act there is a proposal to implement Government policy on cross membership of executive councils of the Australian dairy industry conferences and the Australian Dairy Corporation. Again, we do not oppose it but it is a policy matter, not simply some mechanical matter.

I notice my colleague Senator Puplick in the chamber; he has told me that the amendment to the National Museum of Australia Act 1980 touches on a policy question regarding disposal of material. I understand that although Senator Puplick disagrees with that policy he acknowledges that the Bill does not make any significant changes that he wishes to oppose at this stage. There are matters of detail and importance in this Bill and ones of such a nature that the Opposition believes that it would be wise for a parliamentary committee, such as one of the new House of Representatives standing committees, to analyse these Bills as they come through Parliament from time to time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1987. When similar legislation was initiated under the Fraser Government it was supported by the Australian Democrats as a means of dealing with the host of tidying up items that are required in legislation. In the Australian Government's Legislation Handbook dealing with miscellaneous Bills is a description of the procedure. These are the guidelines set down in it, which I would like to quote because they are important in this debate. The handbook says:

SPEECH.PARA: Guidelines applicable in determining whether a matter is suitable for inclusion in such an omnibus Bill are that:
only matters genuinely dealing with tidying up, correction and updating, routine administrative changes or changes of minor policy significance may be included
no matter that is contentious, or is closely related to a contentious matter, may be included
matters involving lengthy and complex drafting, particularly of a kind that may hold up the Bill, generally should not be included
matters involving substantial policy issues (including legal policy issues) generally should not be included
no matter constituting a change to the National Companies and Securities legislation may be included
no matter imposing, abolishing or varying a tax or varying the incidence of a tax may be included
no matter involving an appropriation may be included

That gives a fairly good indication of the general agreement as to what these Bills were about. However, over time, those guidelines have been pressed to their very limit. Fairly obviously, this procedure is now being used to bring through items that should not be brought through in this way. It is interesting that the Victorian Parliament appointed its Legal and Constitutional Committee to have a look at this motion for the Victorian Parliament. In its report it advised against such a move. The reasons why are also very important because they bear on what the Democrat concerns are with this Bill and possibly with subsequent Bills.

The procedures have also come under significant criticism from other committees of this chamber, notably the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. The basis of the criticisms is that these omnibus Bills, which are supposed to conform to the guidelines that I have just read out, often contain items of a significant nature. An example quoted in the report to the Victorian Parliament provides:

Eleven and one half pages of the Act are devoted to changes of a substantive nature to the Copyright Act, a number of which involve criminal offences and the setting of and infliction of penalties on persons who do not conform with the requirements of the Copyright Act.

That obvious breaking of the agreement did not stop that legislation going through. Again, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has commented adversely on these Bills from time to time. For example, in 1983 there were criticisms of a miscellaneous provisions Bill because clause 7 (5) increased penalty rates and the schedule to the Bill proposed to increase the penalty rate from 10 to 20 per cent in respect of a great many Acts. There were also proposed amendments to penalties applying to offences against the Air Navigation Act, the proposed substitution of a new section to the Navigation Act, and the proposed insertion in the Wool Industry Act of a section concerning the refunding of moneys and so on. Many reports of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee have raised such arguments.
The majority of the adverse comments to the Victorian committee came from the legal profession. It is worth quoting from some of those submissions. The Law Reform Committee said that it:

is of the opinion that a Statutory Law Miscellaneous Provisions Act should only contain amendments to certain typographical, grammatical type errors and that it should contain nothing which could be said to be substantive.
It is possible that the Government of the day may try to make substantive amendments by this `back door' method avoiding public scrutiny and debate.

Again, the Law Council of Australia pointed out that it has a very firm policy in relation to omnibus legislation, and that that policy had been put to the Federal Government. The Council went on to say that its policy:

is that `omnibus legislation' is acceptable for amendment to legislation in the most routine of matters only, that any changes of a policy nature should not be incorporated in such legislation, nor should it be used for the amendment of what might be termed `major legislation'.
The Council added that it:
has frequently received from the Government assurances that it would abide by that policy but regrettably those assurances have not always been realised.
That has been borne out by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee.
The Law Institute of Victoria opposed the concept of miscellaneous provisions Bills for a number of reasons. They are:
members of the public are presumed to know the law, but legislation of this type makes the principle more difficult to fulfil because of problem of finding amendments to a particular Act
miscellaneous provisions legislation makes it even more difficult than at present for lawyers to learn of changes to specific legislation and to advise the public accordingly

there may be situations where people cannot be represented by lawyers-for example, where they appear before certain tribunals-and in these circumstances there is a real risk that changes to a particular Act will be overlooked and not acted upon
guidelines existing at federal level are unsatisfactory
generally there appears to be scope for such a procedure to be abused by the executive.
The Institute listed a number of reasons for finding current Federal guidelines dealing with miscellaneous provisions Bills unsatisfactory, including:
The Institute listed a number of reasons for finding current federal guidelines dealing with Miscellaneous Provisions Bills unsatisfactory, including:
they involve the exercise of discretion and judgment-for example, as to what is a change of ``minor policy significance'' or what is a ``contentious matter''

the list of matters stated as not to be included in a Miscellaneous Provisions Bill is inadequate-for example, it does not include matters affecting civil liberties or the right to legal representation
in practice, the guidelines have not always been adhered to by federal parliamentary counsel
it would be difficult for Members of Parliament to give proper consideration to all aspects of the many amendments to different Acts contained in a Miscellaneous Provisions Bill
there is a real risk that amendments made to each Act will not be given the same degree of consideration as would be the case had they been contained in separate Bills

It seems to me that those criticisms are well founded. This Bill, as with previous Bills, shows clear lapses in the application of the guidelines. For our part, in future, if we believe that some of these items have been pressed to their limit, taken beyond their limit or have not been most rigorously and strictly adhered to, we will vote against such Bills, whether or not we happen to agree with the items that are contained in them, in terms of amendments of a policy nature. That vote will be a registered vote of protest against using what is a very useful procedure in a way which simply abuses the method that is before us. We hope that the types of comments that Senator Lewis and I have made will be accepted as being not an attempt to derail the process but an attempt to put it back on the proper rails and have it dealt with in a proper fashion. I believe that if there is any doubt about an item, the judgment should be made that it should not be included. At the moment if there is any doubt, it tends to be included rather than left out.

We will support the amendments that Senator Lewis has proposed and circulated. We believe that these types of items need more consideration. Some of those, at least, were not included in the legislation when it was circulated in the last Parliament. We therefore believe that it is useful to have a chance to look at these matters. As a matter of principle, we believe that if any group within the Senate wishes to have some more time to consider these types of matters, it should be given that time. After all, if we were complying very strictly with the notion that it is not contentious and is simply a matter of tidying up, these types of problems would not arise. I hope that in future this type of debate does not have to occur. As I say, we believe it is a useful method of dealing with non-contentious items; otherwise the Notice Paper would be cluttered with an enormous number of Bills. But I also signal our intention in the future to vote against such Bills unless those guidelines are strictly adhered to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lewis said in his remarks dealing with this legislation that there was one amendment contained in the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1987 to which I wished to draw attention. It is in regard to one of the amendments to the National Museum of Australia Act 1980. This amendment introduces a new policy in terms of the method by which material may be disposed of from a national historical collection. I indicate, as the shadow Minister for environment, arts and the bicentenary, that this is a policy decision which the Government has made with which I disagree. Had I been the Minister, I would not have consented to such an amendment to the Act. I think it is a retrograde step.

SPEECH.PARA: At the moment the National Museum of Australia is the custodian of a large amount of material which is properly regarded as being part of the national historical collection. It does not have at the moment the capacity simply to throw it away if it believes that the material that it is holding is surplus to its requirements or it simply does not wish to continue to maintain that material. What it must do at the moment, essentially, is find a method by which it can dispose of material from its own collection by sale, gift or exchange. The amendment to the Act would insert a new sub-section 9a which, in part, reads:

. . . the Council may resolve that historical material owned by or in the possession of the Museum, but not in the national historical collection, be disposed of by sale, gift, exchange for other historical material, or destruction.

The question which always arises in museums, as indeed it arises in libraries, is the question of the disposal of surplus material. The amendment provides that that material may be destroyed. Subsequently, it states:

. . . the Council shall not resolve that historical material be disposed of by destruction unless the Council is satisfied that the material has no saleable value and cannot be disposed of in any other way.

I am unclear as to what tests the Council must bring to bear in order to satisfy itself that the historical material cannot be disposed of in any other way; in other words, that it cannot be given away, for example, and should be destroyed.

One of the pleasant features of Australian cultural policy in the last couple of years has been the encouragement of the establishment of regional museums and regional galleries in which material is on display outside the major collecting institutions in Australia. There are a large number of these small galleries, small museums, which, in my view, would be quite prepared, if they knew of the availability of material which is otherwise potentially marked for destruction, to take that material, include it in their local collections and give it some degree of display. It would therefore seem to me that at the very least there should be a requirement upon the Council to do something, such as to publish in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette a list of those items which it has tentatively earmarked for destruction, so that persons-they do not have to be collecting institutions; they may be individuals-who are prepared to take that material and prevent it from being destroyed are given the opportunity to so do.

The fact that the amendment to the Act does not in any sense say how the Council shall resolve that material cannot be disposed of in any other way is, I think, an unfortunate addition to the Act. There is a protection that if the value of the historical material exceeds $5,000, the Minister has to give approval for the disposal. I see no particular problem with that. Nevertheless, as Senator Lewis and Senator Macklin have indicated, this represents a change of policy. It is a matter which is of significance in that it provides the legislative and legal framework for the control of materials which are in the possession of a major institution-namely, the National Museum of Australia.

I do not believe that statute law miscellaneous provisions legislation provides the way in which such changes in policy should be made. If the Government accedes to the Opposition's request in the House of Representatives for this matter to be scrutinised by a committee of the House, I hope that if other people have particular problems and particular objections to this change of policy, they will have the opportunity to express them. I simply say, in my capacity as the shadow Minister, that it is a policy determination of which I do not approve and which I would not have recommended or supported.

There is one other matter about which I seek some guidance from the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate). I also have responsibility for the oversight of the Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act 1983. I would be grateful for the advice of the Minister for Justice as to what precisely is the distinction between regulations and orders. I am unclear about this, particularly having regard to the fact that the explanatory memorandum refers us to the Navigation Act on this matter. My understanding is that that Act has all sorts of arcane arrangements in British imperial law, virtually none of which is understandable to people who are not specialists in admiralty jurisdiction and matters of that nature. Despite all the very considerable assistance that has been given to me by my colleague Senator Hamer, who is one of the few people who understand what the Navigation Act is all about, I am unclear as to the purport of the distinction between regulations and orders, particularly in regard to the change which is to be made in the definitions section which, in part, reads:
Insert the following definition:
`` `the regulations', except in sections 33 and 34 or to the extent that the regulations provide otherwise, includes orders made pursuant to the regulations;''.
I am sure that the Minister would be only too well equipped to give me a detailed explanation of this significant point of law.

TALK.START.PARA: —Lucid, no doubt.
—As Senator Macklin says, no doubt it will be a lucid explanation. I look forward to it with great anticipation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I rise having just been thrown a challenge by Senator Puplick to which I feel quite inadequate to respond. However, I am somewhat comforted by the fact that there is an old adage that ignorance of the law is no excuse. Hitherto, the only people of whatever station, economic circumstance, or whatever, who have been able to take advantage of an exception have been judges at first instance. I regard myself in this chamber as perhaps the equivalent of a judge at first instance. Rather than hazard an answer to Senator Puplick that could well be overturned on appeal, I will take the question on notice and make sure that a full explanation is given to him at a later stage: I hope that it will not be too much later.

SPEECH.PARA: The common law adage to which I referred is of some concern when there is a Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill before us. As I think both Senator Lewis and Senator Macklin pointed out, when there is such omnibus legislation which purports to amend a wide variety of laws applying to the people of the Commonwealth of Australia, quite clearly there is a problem in making legal practitioners and ordinary people who might be affected by such changes aware that such legislative amendments have been brought about, amendments which modify some imposition of an obligation on them, delete some provision which imposed some obligation on them, or somehow modify the law which hitherto applied to them. Arrangements are made whereby persons who are entitled to Commonwealth statutes and are regular purchasers of them get a monthly and then an annual update of the statutes as amended, including amendments made by the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill. To that extent, there is a recognition of the need to put in the hands of practitioners, as speedily as possible and in a comprehensible form, the information related to the principal Acts with which they are concerned and on which they advise their clients. It is important that they be given the information as speedily as possible. I can assure the chamber that that is attempted.

I agree with both Senator Lewis and Senator Macklin that it is important that the Government adhere as strictly as is possible-or even without that qualification-to the guidelines which have been put down and which Ministers need to observe when they propose that matters be included in the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill. In general, I believe that there is a genuine attempt to conform with those guidelines. Occasionally, matters may slip through. I think that the contraction of this session, with fewer sitting weeks than is normal, and the Budget being delayed by a month, has led to a situation where, because the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills and similar committees have not been constituted early enough, we have not perhaps had an opportunity for the scrutiny by Senate committees of some of the matters which normally would be looked at before such a very large Bill came into the chamber. Therefore, I foreshadow that the Government will agree to a proposal by Senator Lewis, which, I understand, will be consequential upon certain amendments being moved and passed in this chamber, that the four clauses which are the subject of his amendments be sent to the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances and the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration for them to give a very speedy report so the matters can be elucidated and clarified for the benefit of both chambers as this matter is dealt with.

I do not think that I need to comment any further on the general policy. We have taken the admonitions and forewarnings to heart. In particular, we will take into account the foreshadowed proposal that a House of Representatives committee be established to look at this omnibus legislation as a whole. I do not know whether any such committee would feel competent to look at all the matters, but it may have a role somewhat analogous to that of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee and that may be of some use. However, at the moment the Government has not determined its position on the foreshadowed proposal to establish a committee in another place. It is small comfort that the Caucus legal committee, under the chairmanship of Mr Peter Cleeland, is very conscious of the need for the legislation to conform to the guidelines which have been outlined by Senator Macklin. That committee is very rigorous in its analysis of proposals which are put forward and, on occasions, has sent matters back, saying that they are to be brought forward in ordinary legislation, much to the annoyance of the Minister concerned. So there are already some informal committees seeking Executive adherence to the guidelines. However, if Parliament wants to get further and better assurance through its own committee system, I can understand what leads to that aspiration.

This Bill, I think, requires a fairly speedy passage. Many of the matters in the Bill were passed at the second reading stage in the House of Representatives before the end of the autumn session, before the double dissolution. So there are matters here which ordinarily could have been expected to be passed into law by the end of the autumn session this year. Therefore, I am grateful to those honourable senators who have indicated that, with the exception of the matters to which Senator Lewis referred, the Bill will be accorded a speedy passage.

Senator Puplick referred to the National Museum of Australia Act and the proposed amendments to the Act. My understanding is that, since the Act was amended in 1985, operational experience has demonstrated a need for the legislation to identify clearly the powers of the museum to dispose of historical material which might be in the possession of the museum but which has not been formally accessioned into the national historical collection. The Attorney-General's Department has advised that there is no power in the museum to dispose of historical material not in the national historical collection. There is some consequential sensitivity and urgency in amending the Act, and I will explain why. It has transpired that the museum wishes to dispose of two groups of material which are not in the national historical collection, namely, a collection of Tasmanian Aboriginal skeletal specimens and a collection of Melanesian artefacts. The return of the skeletal material to the Aboriginal people was announced before the hiatus in the Act was realised. I think that, to that extent, this represents an attempt to overcome that problem. I just wished to put that on the record as a major part of the reasoning that lies behind these amendments. I thank those honourable senators who have spoken at the second reading stage. I look forward to the second reading being carried.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Amendments are proposed to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. Page 42 of the explanatory memorandum states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Registrar has the power under s. 139 (4) to certify an alteration to the rules of registered organisations or refuse to certify such an alteration. Doubt exists as to the power of a Registrar to certify only part of a rule alteration.

Proposed s. 139 (7) is to operate to validate the certification of rule alterations, the validity of which might otherwise be in doubt because a Registrar had certified only part of the rule alteration.
I do not expect an answer immediately, but I ask the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate): What is the issue that gave rise to that particular recommendation?
The main reason I rose to my feet was to refer to the amendment which relates to the Non-government Schools (Loans Guarantee) Act 1977. Page 94 of the explanatory memorandum states:
Proposed amendment of s. 3 omits the definition of the `Commonwealth Schools Commission'. It is consequent upon the proposed amendments to s. 4.

Proposed amendment of s. 4 will empower the Minister, rather than the Commonwealth Schools Commission, to exercise the power to approve building projects of non-government schools for the purposes of the Act. This reflects the change in responsibility for the administration of the Capital Grants Program for government and non-government schools from the Commission to the Department of Employment, Education and Trade.

It seems to me that that is a somewhat significant change. It is a policy change which ought, more appropriately, to be dealt with by an amendment to the Non-government Schools (Loans Guarantee) Act 1977. We, in this chamber, have frequently criticised governments of all persuasions-that is my recollection of it anyhow-for putting into the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act matters which, more appropriately, ought to be dealt with by amendment to the principal Act. That, of course, would enable the Minister concerned to direct attention to the purpose behind the change in policy. This seems to me to be a policy matter. I have not been told to give the matter the consideration it is due, but I would be interested to hear what the Minister has to say about having this matter in the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act rather than as a specific amendment to the Non-government Schools (Loans Guarantee) Act 1977. It appears to me that to pass the authorisation over to the Minister, thus taking it away from the Commonwealth Schools Commission is, indeed, a significant amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 11, Schedule 1, proposed amendments of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901, proposed amendment to paragraph 48 (1) (b), leave out the proposed amendment.
(2) Pages 13 and 14, Schedule 1, proposed amendments of the Audit Act 1901, proposed amendment to sections 32 and 33, leave out the proposed amendment.
(3) Page 15, Schedule 1, proposed amendments of the Audit Act 1901, proposed amendment to subsection 49 (2), leave out the proposed amendment.
(4) Page 16, Schedule 1, proposed amendments of the Audit Act 1901, proposed amendment to subsection 57 (2), leave out the proposed amendment.
[Consequential amendments]
(5) Page 15, Schedule 1, proposed amendments of the Audit Act 1901, proposed amendment to subsection 49 (1), leave out the proposed amendment.
(6) Page 18, Schedule 1, proposed amendments of the Audit Act 1901, proposed amendments to Schedules, leave out the amendments.

The first amendment relates to paragraph 48 (1) (b) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 and the proposal is that the amendment be left out. We feel this provision needs some explanation. In the explanatory memorandum the Government gives the reason for this amendment. It states:
It is necessary to make it clear that regulations may be expressed to commence at the commencement of a specified Act, even if the Act is to commence on a proclaimed date.

I think I understand the reasoning for that. It seems to me to be fairly logical, but there are a couple of matters which concern us on this side of the chamber. In particular, our concern relates to the recent Australia Card legislation. Some of my colleagues and I have been concerned because, if the proposal had gone through, this might have been a way which the Australia Card Bill could have been implemented notwithstanding the Senate's power to disallow the regulations. We feel that some explanation is necessary and, accordingly, we propose that this amendment go off to a Senate committee for investigation and report. That is what we would normally seek to do, but in a few minutes I will explain what is proposed as an alternative.

My amendments then refer to sections 32 and 33 of the Audit Act. Again, I am proposing that we leave out the proposed amendment. These sections deal with the responsibility of the Minister for Finance in the process of issuing appropriated amounts. We believe that the Minister's power, proposed under this amendment, should be considered by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration.

I will not refer to the third amendment for the moment, I will go on to the fourth amendment because it is, similarly, a proposal which purports to set out the details which should be included in any Act appropriating moneys of the Loan Fund. Again, this is a matter which we believe should be considered by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration with a view to reporting back to the Parliament as to the reason for the proposed amendment. That would be the normal procedure, but that would substantially delay the Bill because these amendments would be referred to a committee for consideration and report in due course. The Senate would then consider the report of its committee and deal with the Bill. Rather than delay the Bill in that manner, what I have proposed-I believe it will have the support of the Committee-is that these amendments be left out of this Bill so that the Senate can pass the Bill today without them. After the Bill has been read a third time I shall seek the leave of the Senate to have those matters referred to a committee for consideration and report back to the Senate. In the meantime, the Government will introduce the Bill in the House of Representatives with these provisions put back into the Bill by an amendment. By that time one would hope that the Senate committee would have investigated and considered these matters so that in due course the Bill would come back to this chamber amended by the House of Representatives. It would probably be passed by this chamber without further amendment. That is what is proposed in my amendments (1), (2) and (4) and consequential amendments (5) and (6).

I turn now to what I believe to be a much more substantial matter, and that is my proposed amendment (3), which deals with the proposed amendment to section 49 (2) of the Audit Act 1901. The explanatory memorandum reads:

Proposed amendment of section 49 (2) would give to the Minister for Finance the authority to approve variations of the format of the Monthly Statement. This replaces the current requirement for prior approval of both Houses of Parliament. Proposed new section 49 (3)-
in fact, I believe it is proposed new sections 49 (2) and (3)-
will require the Minister to table details and explanations of variations in Parliament.

While Parliament has approved variations to the format of Monthly Statements, the act of approving a variation is seen largely to be an administrative matter. It is considered that, as an administrative matter, this should more appropriately be handled by the Minister for Finance.

The Opposition does not see this as an administrative matter; we see it as a straight-out attempt to take away from the Parliament a right that the Parliament has always had, and that is to oversee the nature of the monthly financial statement which the Minister for Finance is required to table in the Parliament. If the Government's amendment goes through in the manner that is proposed, the Minister for Finance will be able to vary that statement in any way that he sees fit. For example, he could produce simply a one-line statement containing no detail. The Minister could take the attitude that that is the form in which he will present the financial statement and not supply any further information, and the Parliament would be powerless to do anything about it. There is another means by which to alter the format in which the financial statement is presented; it could be done by way of regulation. In that event the Parliament would have the power to disallow the form proposed if it were considered unsatisfactory. I caution the Minister and his officers that that also would present a difficulty. If the regulation were disallowed, would it mean that the Minister would be provided with no form in which the financial statement could be presented? If the Government puts forward an alternative proposal--

TALK.START.PARA: —The schedules remain unaltered.

—The Minister has grasped the point that I am trying to make-that, if the Government were to put forward an alternative proposal which had the effect that the Minister for Finance was left with no form in which to present the financial statement, the Minister would still be able to do what he wished. Of course, the Opposition would oppose such an alternative. The Opposition would have no major objection to a proposal put forward by the Government that ensured that the Parliament retained some degree of control over the form in which the Minister presented the monthly financial statement. That deals with the amendments I have moved. As I say, I shall be seeking the leave of the Senate to refer ultimately three substantive matters to its committees for consideration. Amendment (3) seeks to leave out the proposed amendment to section 49 (2) of the Audit Act 1901, and I anticipate that at some stage in the future the Government will propose an alternative to that amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall respond first to the matters raised by Senator Harradine. At this moment I am unable to give him an explanation of the genesis of the proposal dealing with the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, put forward no doubt by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis). I know that certain discussions took place between the Industrial Registrar, the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Minister following the decision of Mr Justice Keely in Linsket's case. I am unable to go beyond that to give the honourable senator the fullest explanation possible, but perhaps that gives a hint which we could follow up a little later.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine referred also to the proposed amendment to the Non-government Schools (Loans Guarantee) Act 1977, which is dealt with at page 94 of the explanatory memorandum. The amendment appears to involve a transition of power from the Commonwealth Schools Commission to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training to approve building projects for non-government schools for the purposes of the Act. I am informed that that reflects the change in responsibility for the administration of the capital grants program for government and non-government schools from the Commission to the Department of Employment, Education and Training. That decision having been taken and the responsibility no longer residing in the Commonwealth Schools Commission, the proposed amendment is merely a matter of form to indicate where that particular power resides. It simply indicates that the power is to be drawn back into the Minister's possession rather than being exercised by the Commission. The Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill simply gives effect to that consequential matter, following the change in responsibilities which has been announced elsewhere. The statute itself does not try to change those responsibilities; apparently that has been undertaken by way of administrative arrangements, as set out by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I know no more than that at this stage.

I turn now to the matters raised by Senator Lewis. In the course of the morning considerable discussion has taken place between Senator Lewis, Senator Macklin and me. That discussion has led to a very sensible and amicable resolution of the queries and misgivings that have been raised. I can assure the Senate that the Government had no nefarious intent of trying to disguise the proposed amendment to the Acts Interpretation Act by including it in this Bill. Apparently queries have been raised as to whether it is possible to make a regulation that does not have a particular commencing date or that does not commence at a definite time in relation to the commencement of a statute.

The proposed amendments endeavour to deal with a couple of situations that have arisen in the past. It might be useful to put those matters on the record. A regulation under the Australian Capital Territory Tax Transfers of Marketable Securities Act had to come into force at 5 p.m. on a particular date. Presumably that is when the Act came into force. The commencement of the regulation was to coincide with the Statute coming into force. Provisions in the Acts Interpretation Act make it impossible for regulations to come into force at a particular hour of the day. That led to problems which were noticed. The Act was especially amended in an effort to deal with that problem, but it is preferable that the Act contain a more general provision, and that is what is proposed here.

Secondly, regulations were sought to be made under the Protection of the Sea (Civil Liability) Act 1981 pursuant to Australian ratification of a protocol. Those regulations were required to come into force when another Act which provided for ratification itself came into force. I am told that that would be when the protocol came into force for Australia. That date could not be identified in advance, so the provision proposed in the Bill is designed to deal with that matter. The genesis of the amendment lies in those problems and has nothing to do with the Australia Card legislation. Nevertheless, I think it is appropriate that the matter be examined by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs and that that Committee report to the Senate speedily.

Referring to the provisions of the Bill which deal with the Audit Act, may I simply say, without wanting to prejudge the attitude of the Government to the matters raised by Senator Lewis, that I agree with him. I suppose to some extent I am still influenced by my having been Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills and having in mind the traditions of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. I do not think it is appropriate that a matter in a schedule to a statute be changed by a ministerial directive or statement which itself cannot be disallowed. We cannot have an amendment of a statute included in a schedule to the statute by way of ministerial dictate which in itself is not disallowable. One can see why this sort of machinery was thought to be useful. I am sure we can come up with a method which, by bringing into force the power of disallowance in the chamber-let us say that this is now done by way of regulation rather than by the proposed method-we can overcome that problem. I thank the chamber for indicating its willingness to pass this legislation with the exception of the matters that have been raised by Senator Lewis.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) looks at what I have circulated about what I propose to seek leave to do after the third reading he will see that I am proposing that the amendment to paragraph 48 (1) (b) go to the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances for report and that the audit amendments would go to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. May I seek leave of the Committee to make an explanation about another area not on this subject because it is causing someone who is listening to the broadcast great concern?
—Perhaps we could dispose of the amendments first. That would take a very short time and then we could come back to that matter.

—Mr Chairman, during the second reading debate I mentioned the alteration of the Acts Interpretation Act in relation to the expression `may' no longer meaning `shall'. Someone has had such concern about this-I do not blame the person-as to point out the radical alteration that this makes to statutory interpretation and to ring my colleague Senator Stone about it.
—Was it Ewart Smith?

—No, I do not believe it was Mr Smith. He pointed out that this is a prospective amendment. In other words, it quite clearly says that in the interests of caution proposed new section 33 (2a) will apply only to Acts assented to after the amendment is made. That was why we were saying that sometimes `may' means may and sometimes it might mean `shall'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The point I wish to raise was raised by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills last time it looked at this piece of legislation in the last Parliament. It concerns the proposed new sub-section for the Anglo-Australian Telescope Agreement Act. It is a rather extraordinary proposition that on page 11 the Bill states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Board has such additional functions as are conferred on it by the regulations.

Presumably at the moment the Board is limited in its functions to the operation and management of the Anglo-Australian Telescope in accordance with the agreement set down under the Act. It is now going to be able to do anything. This is the most extraordinary sort of proposition. In any shape or form it is a most inappropriate delegation of legislative power. However, there may be some other type of explanation which is not forthcoming. It certainly was not forthcoming to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. The Minister may be able to look at that so that the next time the Bill returns there will be an adequate explanation as to what that provision is doing there. I foreshadow that if there is not an adequate explanation I will move for that piece to be deleted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has criticised the amendment enabling additional functions to be conferred on the Anglo-Australian Telescope Board by regulations, suggesting that additional functions should be conferred by the Act itself. This matter was dealt with in the second reading speech. We have been advised that the nature of the additional functions to be conferred on the Board is dependent on negotiations between the Australian and United Kingdom governments and those negotiations have yet to be completed. We have also been advised that arrangements for Australian administration of a United Kingdom telescope co-located with the Anglo-Australian Telescope must be in place by the beginning of next year.
