TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, both as Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and as the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. It follows the Minister's statement yesterday in Question Time that `the relevance of unit labour costs is of very significant importance in terms of maintaining international competitiveness'. Is the Minister aware that, according to the latest Treasury Round-up, nominal unit labour costs in Australia increased by 7.5 per cent over 1986-87 compared with an average in our trading partners of 3 per cent, which is 2.2 percentage points worse than in the preceding year? Is he further aware that Treasury estimates that unit labour costs will grow by at least 6 per cent over 1987-88-around double the rate of our trading partners? Does the Minister regard these actual and anticipated outcomes as satisfactory? If not, what does the Government intend to do to bring these costs more into line with those existing in countries with which we compete?

—I am aware of the figures which Senator Chaney has cited. I think they were referred to at some length in the Budget Papers in terms of anticipations of wage outcomes for 1987-88. I maintain what I said yesterday: that real unit labour costs are a relevant and important matter in terms of international competitiveness, as are a range of other parameters which go to the question of international competitiveness. I think the question really goes to the heart of the matter of whether the adjustment is proceeding at the right pace. On a range of issues I think it probably is.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister really to address the point as to whether this is satisfactory and whether the Government will act. The suggestion in the Minister's answer is that he thinks the position is satisfactory. Let me quote the Minister that he represents in this place, the Minister for Industrial Relations. He told the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU):

QUESTION.PARA: It is quite fundamental to our prospects of economic recovery that we keep increases in our labour costs broadly in line with those of our international trading competitors. Not to do so would jettison the great opportunities provided by the very large devaluation of the $A and place us in dire economic peril.

I stress the words `dire economic peril'. I ask the Minister: Is he suggesting that labour cost growth double or more that of our trading partners can, by any stretch of the imagination, be described as broadly in line with that of our international trading competitors? Does that not indicate that the present situation leaves us in dire economic peril?

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, it depends on what weight one gives to real unit labour costs in terms of an array of matters which are relevant to international competitiveness. I attach importance to that; and importance has to be attached to it over time, not looking at any particular isolated period. The Minister, in making that statement to the ACTU, was reflecting a concern about constraint in labour costs, and I think to some extent that view has been reflected in ACTU comments about relative wages between Australia and overseas. So whether that falls within the category of `broadly in line' is a matter of judgment, having regard to a number of other factors, including a whole range of very important trade-offs which are being made in respect of wages in this country.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is confusion in the hiatus caused by the Opposition's constitutional vandalism of the Australia Card legislation likely to hamper the Government's efforts to attack the endemic problem of tax evasion?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opportunism and vandalism of members of the Opposition have already hampered the Government's efforts to stamp out tax cheating, not only in their opposition to the Australia Card Bill but also in their predicted further opposition to any measure which will effectively attack tax evasion. Earlier this week, for example, Mr Tuckey, in his particular efforts to protect tax evaders from the discipline of an enhanced tax file number system, went out on a limb on behalf of the taxation and welfare cheats. According to this morning's papers, he was hauled back a bit by other people in the Opposition yesterday-not, I suspect, because they are in principle in disagreement with Mr Tuckey's efforts to protect taxation and welfare cheats but because they fear the electoral consequences of being too openly identified with the interests of those people, as, of course, Mr Tuckey openly identifies himself.

ANSWER.PARA: However, we still do not know what are the answers to these critical questions: Firstly, whether the Opposition will attempt to block anything which requires employers to notify promptly the Australian Taxation Office of the tax file numbers of their employees; and, secondly, whether the Opposition is advocating a 50 per cent interest withholding tax, because nothing less than a 50 per cent interest withholding tax could be effective in ensuring that no tax was evaded on interest received. If the Opposition is advocating a 50 per cent interest withholding tax, it is, of course, advocating that 50 per cent of the interest payments received by pensioners who have a few thousand dollars in a building society account be confiscated, at least in the short term, by the Taxation Office. If that is what the Opposition is advocating, I wish it would come out and say so.

That is by no means an exhaustive list of the measures which are necessary to ensure a greater degree of compliance with the taxation law. But this confusion in the Opposition is not a recent phenomenon. Mr Blunt of the National Party of Australia and Mr Porter and Senator Puplick of the Liberal Party of Australia, as well as Senator Haines, were members of the parliamentary Select Committee on an Australia Card which supported the tax file number system. On 10 December last year, Senator Haines moved an amendment which essentially mirrored the recommendations of the majority report of the Select Committee. I will not read all of the amendment because it is too lengthy, but it commences:
That the integrity of the tax file number be upgraded to that of the proposed Australia Card number based on the following premises:
I will not read all of the premises--

TALK.START.PARA: —You would not accept the recommendations in the Joint Select Committee report before, would you?

—No doubt Senator Knowles depends for her preselection, as a member of the Liberal Party Senate team in Western Australia, on ingratiating herself with the tax evaders who have dominated the Western Australian branch of the Liberal Party for many years. So I am not surprised that she takes the attitude that she does. I will not read all of Senator Haines's amendment but, under Senator Chaney's leadership, the Opposition voted against that amendment as well as against the Bill. But in the Senate on 24 September Senator Chaney was applauding the majority report of the Select Committee on an Australia Card when he spoke in glowing terms of Senator Puplick's contribution to the report of that Committee. Of course, Senator Puplick recommended the upgraded tax file number system in the terms of Senator Haines's amendment of 10 December last, against which the Liberal Party, led by Senator Chaney, voted. To add further to the confusion, Senator Puplick claimed yesterday that I was wrong in interpreting Mr Tuckey's remarks in the way I had interpreted them, although I have yet to see any report of Senator Puplick's assertion, let alone any retraction or correction by Mr Tuckey, of my interpretation of it. Specifically, I repeat that if Senator Puplick is interested in putting out a Press statement on this issue, I would welcome it from him, from Senator Chaney or from anyone on the Opposition front bench, that the Opposition would not oppose an enforcement system which requires employers promptly to notify the Taxation Office of the tax file numbers of their employees.
—Is that what you are proposing?

—I point out to Senator Stone that we are conducting a study. If he has no objections to that I would welcome a statement from him to that effect, because the National Party combined with the Labor Party could carry such legislation.

—Mr President, on a point of order: The Minister is clearly conducting a debate with himself at this stage. He is putting forward an absurd proposition that the Opposition should declare itself on propositions which he has just told us the Government still has under study. He is reducing Question Time to a farce. He should be called to order and made to resume his seat.
—The question asked of the Minister was in order but he is straying from the question he was originally asked. I ask him to take that into account.

—I certainly will, Mr President. I note for the record that there speaks another senator who depends for his preselection on ingratiating himself with the tax evaders who have for many years dominated the Liberal Party's Western Australian branch. It is no wonder the Opposition adopts the attitude it does in the Senate. What I have done is catalogue five about-faces by the Opposition in less than 12 months on this issue. It is about time members of the Opposition got their act together. I would welcome an assurance from the Opposition that it would support a requirement that employers must notify the Tax Office of the tax file numbers of their employees and clarify whether as part of its interest withholding tax proposal-which it quite clearly seems to have supported-it proposes to confiscate, at least in the short term, 50 per cent of the interest earnings of those hundreds of thousands of age pensioners and to do that as a preferred option to a more effective crackdown on taxation cheats.

—My question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate arises from yesterday's statement by the Prime Minister that any `realistic' stance on the Fiji crisis would require us to recognise and presumably to accept that any solution in Fiji would involve the entrenchment of minority Melanesian rule. I ask the Minister: Since any such solution would probably be inconsistent with the principle of one person, one vote, one value, will the Minister now, on behalf of the Government, reaffirm in unequivocal terms the support of the Government-whether it is talking about Australia, Fiji or South Africa, I do not mind-for the principle of equality of all members of an electorate irrespective of their colour or racial origin?

—I suppose I am an old-fashioned Presbyterian but I was brought up to believe that God helps those who help themselves. I think it is peculiarly within the province of this Government to pursue the issue of one vote one value, or near enough to it, in the Australian context. But there are differences which apply in other countries and this Government or any Australian government cannot necessarily have direct or beneficial influence in respect of what happens in those countries. I am not aware of precisely what the Prime Minister said, but I will certainly inquire from him what the purport of his comment was in relation to Fiji and try to provide the honourable senator with a further answer in respect of the detail of his question.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. All I asked the Minister to do was to reaffirm the Government's unequivocal support for the principle of equality. It really does not matter what the Prime Minister said. I ask the Minister: Is he prepared now to reaffirm the Government's support for the principle of one person, one vote, one value in actions that the Government takes or in regimes it wishes to support?

—As I indicated in answer to the earlier question, certainly I am prepared to reaffirm the principle in relation to Australia. But all sorts of factors come to bear when one is considering the position in other countries. It may not be advisable for the Australian Government, in trying to encourage democratic principles in other countries, to make a reaffirmation of that kind. It may not be the most positive way of achieving the result.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the article on business investment appearing in the September issue of the Treasury Round-up of economic statistics? What light does this article shed on the current macro-economic situation in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article. It gives more of the details which underlie the Budget forecast that there will be 5 per cent real growth in total business investment this financial year. It also makes a couple of other very important points. The first is that business spending on motor vehicles has been going through a cycle during which it grew by 21 per cent in 1984-85 and fell in both the next two years and is expected to fall again this financial year, due to a variety of factors-the unleaded petrol legislation, and probably the increased cost of imported vehicles and vehicle components, but substantially to do with the Government's tax reforms which have led to a significant reduction in the extent to which what is in fact consumption spending on motor vehicles has previously been misdefined as investment spending. When that distortion is netted out business investment grew by more than 6 per cent in real terms in the last financial year and is expected to grow by a further 7 per cent this financial year.

ANSWER.PARA: To tackle successfully the long-standing problem of Australia's current account deficit more effort and more investment need to be put into the tradeable goods and possibly services sector, be it to replace imports or to boost exports. The Treasury article referred to does attempt to estimate the extent to which business investment is flowing into the tradeable sector and more specifically it looks at tradeables other than the commodity tradeables which are our traditional export staples. It finds an increasing share of business investment spending going into this area. For example, page 7 of the Treasury Round-up shows that investment in non-commodity tradeable goods and services, or goods defined as manufacturing but excluding food, beverage and tobacco, as a proportion of total investment, has risen from 28.1 per cent in 1983-84 to 34.7 per cent this year. The Treasury Round-up reveals that the gross 5 per cent anticipated increase in total business real investment masks an equally or arguably more important underlying structural change. That is in the quality of the business investment taking place, which is business investment of the quality required to correct the country's current account imbalance.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, and relates to the Nurrungar base in South Australia. Has a nuclear fall-out shelter been constructed beneath the Nurrungar base? If so, does this not prove the contention long held by the peace movement in Australia that the presence of these so-called joint facilities makes Australia a nuclear target? If not, what is the purpose of the recently constructed one-kilometre-deep shaft and radiating tunnels leading out from the shaft, and why has it been necessary to line these tunnels with one-metre-thick concrete?

—I refer Senator Coulter to the Prime Minister's statement in the House of Representatives on 6 June 1984 in which the Government went as far as it would go in public statements about the purposes and roles of those bases. I have nothing to add to the Prime Minister's statement on that occasion.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. I ask whether the Minister is aware of the reported shortfall in key mining personnel, especially in the gold mining industry of Western Australia? Has the Government taken any steps to speed the inflow of immigrants with relevant mining expertise from overseas? Is the shortfall in key mining personnel a problem which is likely to be of long standing? Finally, in view of the appalling history of South Africa in terms of its racial and industrial relations policies, can the Minister give an assurance that special category immigration applications from mining personnel in South Africa will not be accorded any form of preferential treatment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator McKiernan for his question. I am aware of the shortfall in key mining personnel in the gold mining industry in Western Australia. I am aware that the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has commenced negotiations with the industry to establish and meet its requirements. The Department has recognised acute shortages of senior personnel in Western Australia. Special negotiated arrangements are available to industries in need of occupational skills in short supply on domestic labour markets. These arrangements allow streamlined processing of group nominations for migrant entry at the Australian end in return for an industry's commitment to the recruitment and training of Australian residents.

ANSWER.PARA: Discussions with the industry are taking place in the context of the Government's global processing priorities overseas which, of course, will be maintained. I understand completely Senator McKiernan's concerns about the sensitivities of the issue he raises. I will seek full details of the progress of discussions with the industry from the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Transport and Communications to his lunchtime rendezvous with Mr Holmes a Court at Canberra's Lobby restaurant and the fact that it was reported that Mr Holmes a Court was seeking yet another favour from this Government-this time concerning the maintenance of his cross-media ownerships in Perth. In light of this lobbyists lunch, is the Minister aware that there is also a problem of common and cross-media ownership in the rural districts of Australia? I particularly refer to the common ownership in channel MTN9 Griffith and radio 2RG Griffith. This ownership chiefly has been brought about by way of achieving efficiency in business due to the servicing of a small population and the using of common facilities. Compared to the media interests of Mr Holmes a Court this business is very small, but, in fact, it involves the same principle and the same problem. I further ask: If the Government is prepared to rethink its attitude to joint media ownership, will the Minister keep a special consideration for rural Australia and its special requirements, not just the special requirements of media barons?
—The question is based on an entirely false premise. For that reason alone, I do not propose to give it any further answer.
—I ask a supplementary question. If the Minister is willing to accept that he did have lunch with Mr Holmes a Court, will he also answer the question: Who paid for it?
—The premise in question was not of my having had lunch with Mr Holmes a Court, which is by now a notorious public fact, but the subject matter of our discussion at that lunch.

—My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health. I ask: Can the Minister advise the Senate whether assistance provided under the Government's first home owners scheme (FHOS) effectively encourages and assists low to moderate income earners to purchase their first homes? Can the Minister also advise how many additional people have benefited from the Government's decision earlier this year to lift income levels under the first home owners scheme?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Without government assistance many prospective first home buyers would be forced to delay the purchase of their homes. Since the inception of the first home owners assistance scheme on 1 October 1983 it has assisted almost 260,000 low to moderate income households into their first homes. Under FHOS the waiting periods for assistance are short, there is no discriminatory savings requirement, assistance in the forms of non-repayable and tax free grants is available at the time of purchase and home buyers can choose the type of assistance most suited to their circumstances.

ANSWER.PARA: The high application rate for FHOS indicates that the scheme is still successful in providing assistance to the first home buyers and, therefore, stimulating to the construction industry. The 30 march decision to lift income limits will enable an additional 13,000 households to receive first home owners scheme assistance in 1987-88 and will also increase the benefits available to a further 13,000 households. I think that the summary answer to Senator Jones's question is yes.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: BUILDING INDUSTRY WORKERS: SEVERANCE PAY SCHEME

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. The question is pertinent in view of comments made in recent times by Senator Walsh in respect of tax cheats and welfare fraud. I refer the Minister to the new severance pay scheme for building industry workers to come into operation this week. I ask: Does the Minister support the Building Workers Industrial Union of Australia, which states that building workers should be entitled to receive the dole in addition to their severance scheme payout? If so, is this not a form of welfare fraud? Given the temporal nature of the building industry, how can the Minister consider each job finish as a bona fide redundancy for which lump sum severance payments would attract tax on only 5 per cent of the figure at the marginal rate? Is this a form of tax cheating? Will the Minister indicate how widespread he thinks the severance pay scheme will become in other industries where employees are frequently between jobs, for example, seasonal industries such as fruit picking?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has, of course, given consideration to the redundancy scheme for the building industry. The Minister has written to the parties to the purported agreement which, as I understand it, was offered by employers in particular areas of the industry.
—That was collusion.

—Of course, they never do anything except under collusion. The Government has written to parties to the agreement explaining technical deficiencies relating to the scheme, drawing attention to certain concerns of the Government relating to both social security and taxation aspects and indicating that in the Government's view the scheme is in substantial need of amendment if it is either to meet its intended objectives or to satisfy Government wages policy and Conciliation and Arbitration Commission principles.

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of that, it is my understanding that the parties, including those who are not purported signatories to the agreement, are considering the position and are exploring new approaches in response to Government concerns. The Minister expects that all parties with an interest in building industry redundancy will review their positions and seek to develop an arrangement which satisfies both taxation and social security requirements and which is designed to accord with the requirements of the national wage fixing principles.

I must say that, of course, there are and always have been, unique features of this industry. Not all those features are easily translatable to other industries. However, the Government would expect that any scheme developed will be taken to the Commission on its merits, having regard to both the wage fixing principles and the particular features of the building industry. The Government is ready to assist with that process. I also draw Senator Parer's attention to the commitment of the parties to their obligations under the 1987 building industry agreement, in which they expressed a desire for orderly industrial relations. In the Government's view, the redundancy issue has to be seen in the context of that agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister saying that the amendment the Minister is seeking, to satisfy the taxation and social security requirements, is to enable this redundancy payment to be made and yet still entitle workers to receive the dole and pay tax on only 5 per cent of the payment?
—I was saying that, in order to receive any sort of favourable consideration from the Government, the scheme has to conform to the Government's social security, taxation and wage-fixing principles.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. Is he aware of the recent landing of an Indonesian vessel on islands off the coast of the Northern Territory? If so, could he advise the Senate what action was taken in respect of the landing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that Senator Collins takes a very keen interest in matters of the surveillance of the northern coastline and waters. Hence the question, which I am able to answer in some detail for the benefit of the Senate. On 2 October 1987, at 12.50 hours, a Northern Territory police aircraft sighted a vessel displaying the Indonesian flag near Lawson Island. Lawson Island is east of Croker Island, approximately 160 nautical miles east of Darwin. Nine persons were sighted on the vessel and a small craft was also sighted leaving the island for the vessel. A coastal surveillance aircraft was diverted to maintain a watching brief and the Australian Customs Service vessel Jabiru was alerted for immediate response.

ANSWER.PARA: An Australian Federal Police coastal protection unit member and an officer from the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service accompanied the response vessel, which departed Darwin at 15.30 hours on the same day. The Indonesian vessel was tracked by coastal surveillance aircraft from Lawson Island to McCluer Island and finally to New Year Island, where it was eventually intercepted by the response vessel and boarded at 07.10 hours on 3 October 1987. The Indonesian vessel had also landed at New Year Island. The vessel-a 12-metre type 2 fishing vessel Bunga Rampi, with a crew of 15-was seized under the provisions of the Quarantine Act and taken in tow to Darwin, arriving at 09.05 hours on 5 October.

The master of the vessel was interviewed by quarantine and Customs officers in the presence of a representative of the Indonesian consulate in Darwin. At the conclusion of the interview and upon consultation with the Director of Public Prosecutions, the master was charged under sections 20 and 29 (1) of the Quarantine Act and section 58 (1) of the Customs Act. Obviously, court proceedings are to be undertaken. I need go no further on that matter, except to say that I commend those who were responsible for the initial sighting of the vessel, directing the co-ordination of the tracking and the eventual interception of the vessel. I know that Senator Collins will be pleased with this instance of the successful operation of coastal surveillance of the northern waters and coastline, to which the Government attaches the very highest importance.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Will the Minister ask Australia Post to reconsider its decision not to include for commemoration by the pre-stamped envelope program of 1987 the involvement by Australian servicemen in the Vietnam War, particularly inasmuch as one of the grounds for objecting to the request was that `it is of potential public divisiveness and therefore contrary to the criteria for eligibility as a stamp subject'?
—I will raise that matter with Australia Post and communicate a response to the honourable senator in due course.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. Has her attention been drawn to the action of two former Fiji nationals, now naturalised Australian citizens, who tore up their naturalisation certificates on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's 7.30 Report in Brisbane? Is such an action an indication that these two persons do not value their Australian citizenship and should return to Fiji? Are replacement naturalisation certificates available for people who wilfully destroy the original certificates presented to them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Colston for his question. I am aware that two Australian citizens from Fiji tore up their citizenship certificates recently on the 7.30 Report. The destruction of a citizenship certificate does not mean that a person does not value his or her citizenship. In the heat of the moment many people react in a manner that they later regret. I am sure that the persons concerned in this case feel deeply about the situation in Fiji, as indeed we all do. The mere fact that a person destroys his or her citizenship certificate does not result in that person losing his or her Australian citizenship. No legal action can be taken by the Commonwealth against a person for destroying a citizenship certificate, as the certificate is not the property of the Commonwealth.

ANSWER.PARA: If people wish to renounce their Australian citizenship they are required to lodge a formal declaration of renunciation, which takes effect upon registration. The Australian Citizenship Act bars registration of the declaration if the person concerned would become stateless or if the Minister considers that it would not be in the public interest to register the declaration. The Citizenship Act prohibits the issue of replacement certificates to persons who wilfully destroy their original citizenship certificates. If persons who destroy their certificates require evidence that they are Australian citizens, for example for passport purposes, they must apply for a certificate evidencing their citizenship. Such certification can be obtained on application and the payment of a $30 processing fee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister to table the document from which she was reading.
—Will the Minister table the document?
—No.

—I take a point of order, Mr President. Is the Minister claiming that there is particular confidentiality in the document that she is refusing to table? My understanding is that she cannot refuse to table the document unless she claims that there is confidentiality in the document, which she has now read into the record. She cannot simply decline to table a document because it happens to suit her purposes.
—That is the only ground the Minister can use. Is the Minister claiming confidentiality?
—Yes.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MR RAMOS HORTA: APPLICATION FOR RESIDENCY

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs: Is it not a fact that the left wing activist Ramos Horta has applied for permanent residency in Australia?
—I thank the honourable senator for his question. I will refer it to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and advise the honourable senator in due course.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE: WOMEN PILOTS

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Defence: Is it a fact that women cannot be trained as pilots in the Royal Australian Air Force? If so, can he indicate the reasons for this? Can he also indicate what steps are being taken in the Defence Force to promote equal opportunity for women?

—The answer to Senator Bolkus's question is no. Women can be trained as pilots in the Royal Australian Air Force, but they are able to be employed only on non-combat duties. It is Defence Force policy to exclude women from combat and combat-related duties. Section 43 of the Sex Discrimination Act states that this action is not unlawful. Four women commenced pilot training in the Royal Australian Air Force earlier this year, but one has already withdrawn because she failed to meet the required flying standard. Further opportunities for air crew training for women will be identified from time to time according to vacancies, staffing and experience levels. However, there have been very few applications from women to fill the non-combat air crew positions available to them in open competition with men.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I refer to the reintroduction of tertiary education tuition fees by the Labor Government. In particular, I refer to the administration charge introduced by Senator Ryan and now paid by two-thirds of all enrolled students and to Mr Dawkins's ministerial statement of 22 September, which approved tertiary tuition fees for some postgraduate students. I ask specifically: Given the increase to $263 in the administration fee, what total revenue will be raised by this fee next year, and will there be any variation in the proportion retained by universities and colleges? Secondly, what is the Government's estimate of the revenue to be raised through the new postgraduate fees? How many institutions intend to charge these fees and how many has the Minister so far approved? Finally, has the Government now approved the full fee approach of the new Bond university in Queensland?

—In reply to Senator Teague's reference to the administration charge and the consumer price index adjustment to that charge, it was the policy of the Government from the inception of that charge that the charge should be inflation adjusted. With regard to the other specific matters that the honourable senator has raised, I will ask Mr Dawkins to provide answers in writing for him.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. Has the Minister seen the recent Press release by the Opposition spokesman for health, Mr Tuckey, criticising the Government's allocation of $25m to address problems with public hospital waiting lists? Can the Minister advise the Senate what progress has been made in the allocation of hospital waiting list money and what results the Government expects from this program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Tuckey seems to make a habit of exaggeration and misrepresentation of facts concerning public policy. I am aware of the statement made by Mr Tuckey. He claims that 150,000 people are on waiting lists, but only two months ago the Opposition used the figure of 100,000, a figure which was grossly exaggerated. Mr Tuckey asked why public hospitals cannot subcontract from private hospitals. If Mr Tuckey read the Medicare agreements--
—How many are there?

—I might extend that suggestion to Senator Walters as well. If Mr Tuckey read the Medicare agreements he would know that the State governments have the power to make arrangements with private hospitals if they choose to, and some States are already planning such arrangements. The Opposition, in its desperate attempt to disguise its failure to produce an alternative health policy, continues, quite inappropriately, to blame Medicare for any problems in the health sector. Waiting times for elective surgery are being unjustifiably depicted as Medicare-related. State governments have identified the real reasons underlying waiting lists as nursing shortages resulting in bed closures; an undersupply of some specialists, such as orthopaedic and ophthalmic surgeons; advances in technology allowing previously difficult or dangerous procedures to be more routinely performed; and greater public awareness and higher expectations leading to increased demand.

ANSWER.PARA: Some States have already developed programs to address particular bottlenecks in their hospitals. While not wishing to intervene inappropriately in an area of State government responsibility, the Federal Government saw scope to develop a program which would support and maintain the momentum of the current State initiatives. During the election campaign, the Government announced a hospital waiting list program which will provide $25m a year for the next two years. With matching State funds, this means that $100m will be dedicated to hospital waiting list strategies over the next two years. The Commonwealth's $25m has been allocated to the States on virtually a per capita basis. These funds, which will be matched dollar for dollar by the States, will be directed to specific programs which have been clearly demonstrated to have a real impact on waiting times for elective surgery. Funding within the two-year program will be continued only on the basis of the results achieved.

The types of programs which have already been demonstrated to be effective and which have received approval under this initiative are: in Victoria, a five-part program covering dedicated facilities for specific specialities, overseas nurse recruitment, use of private hospitals for recovery and rehabilitation, day surgery and management review; in South Australia-of particular interest to Senator Crowley-day surgery facilities, additional theatre sessions for orthopaedics, enterology, urology and general surgery; and, in New South Wales, expansion of cardiac and orthopaedic services, improved ophthalmology services, development of day surgery facilities and paediatric enhancement projects. Under the program it is anticipated that some 1,000 paediatric, 1,150 cardiac, 3,400 ophthalmic and 18,000 general elective surgery patients will be treated in the course of a year. The cost of the program is $19.14m for 1987-88, and the Commonwealth share is $9.57m.

In conclusion, it is quite clear that Mr Tuckey is not the only member of the Opposition who has no genuine interest in the steps that the Commonwealth, together with the States, is taking to reduce hospital waiting lists.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: BUILDING INDUSTRY WORKERS: SEVERANCE PAY SCHEME

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, follows Senator Parer's question regarding the building industry severance pay agreement. The Minister said that the Government thought that the agreement needed amending. Can the Minister say how the agreement should be amended to fit in with the social security and tax requirements?
—I ask Senator Walters to put that question on notice. The question asks for a lot of detailed matter which is probably not, at this stage, resolved--
—Broadly will do.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I ask whether the Minister has seen this morning's copy of the Australian Financial Review in which, in an article headed `Dollar, interest rates fuel manufacturers' optimism', it is stated that 526 respondents from New South Wales manufacturing industry indicated that they were:

QUESTION.PARA: more optimistic about Australia's business climate than at any time during the past two years, according to a report by the State Bank and the NSW Chamber of Manufactures.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not a dorothy dix question. It is a thoughtful and intelligent question from Senator Childs, who takes an interest in these matters. He asks me whether the optimism or satisfaction is well based. I would think so, because it is a view which has been reflected in numerous comments made to me by members of the business community about, for example, the current investment climate in Australia and investment anticipations-a view which, I must say, was not about to the same extent three or six months ago. I have not seen the article in the Australian Financial Review, but the results of that review seem to reflect a mood which is broadly about in industry and which is very important in itself. Anticipations about capacity to invest and potential returns on investment and so on and about the general state of the economy are very important in terms of the decisions which will be made by businesses both now and in the immediate 12 months or so.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TELECOM AUSTRALIA: PURCHASE OF EASEMENT RIGHTS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a report in the latest edition of the Business Review Weekly that Telecom Australia has purchased exclusive easement rights to the Victorian Railways network? Is the report true? Was the Minister aware of Telecom's intention prior to the acquisition? Does the Minister agree that the deal pre-empts the current internal departmental review of Telecom's activities? Does the Minister agree that the effect of the purchase will be to close out potential new entrants into the optical fibre trunkline business in the event of any government decision to expose Telecom's network activities to private sector competition? Will Telecom's reported arrangement with Vistel allow the Victorian public sector to save an estimated $20m a year by using a private network? If so, why should the same opportunity be denied to the private sector?
—I recall seeing the article to which Senator Alston referred. I do not have a detailed brief on it. I would prefer to respond in detail to the question he raised rather than rabbit on off the cuff.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy aware that the number of farms quarantined for pesticide contamination in Western Australia alone has risen to 64, with a further 25 under investigation? Is he aware that buyers have refused to buy stock from a further 300 for fear of contamination-that is, contamination by association? Is he aware that public utilities such as the State Energy Commission (SEC) have caused contamination to private land? Does the Government accept that part of the blame for contamination is likely to lie with people and bodies other than farmers and that the whole cost should not therefore be borne by the farmers? What action will the Government take, either alone or in conjunction with State governments, to assist farmers and abattoir operators who are currently carrying the whole burden?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was asked whether I was aware of five facts, or alleged facts. The answer is that I was not. I do not believe that the Commonwealth Government has any responsibility for what the State Energy Commission of Western Australia may or may not have done. I must say that the Commonwealth Government did, quite gratuitously, pick up some responsibility for one of the SEC's past mistakes. Charles Court twisted the arm of the SEC commissioners in, I think, 1980, to sign that disastrous take-or-pay contract for North West Shelf gas. The Commonwealth Government has generously forgone very substantial royalty payments in order to assist the State Government to get out of the financial disaster with which Charlie Court lumbered it, because he leaned on the weak SEC commissioners to sign that take-or-pay contract. That, however, was an act-of-grace payment, so to speak, and there was no obligation.

ANSWER.PARA: I will check with Mr Kerin the number of properties which are quarantined or under investigation. He should be able to get the information. Even if the SEC is responsible for some of the contamination at the margin, the fact remains that the overwhelming majority of contaminated soils or crops has been contaminated by chemicals used by farmers.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH SCIENTIFIC AND INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH ORGANISATION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer to the Minister's previous statements about the need to encourage the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) to work more closely with industry through its research program and commercialisation activities. What action have the Minister and the Government taken to bring about this stronger link?
—That is not a dorothy dixer!

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Archer knows, the CSIRO is a very important organisation on which a considerable amount of taxpayers' money has been spent and, for most of its history, properly spent. In answer to the specific part of the question, the CSIRO has just undertaken a very fundamental examination of its purpose, function and structure-the most fundamental examination in its 60-year history.
—The Birch review was a better one.

—I said it was the most fundamental one, Senator. The outcome of this examination is a research organisation which is much more focused on the application of its research results. The CSIRO has arrived at a strategy which will involve it remaining at the forefront of world science and technology. It will have a commitment to the creative application of its research results through bodies such as Sirotech. Priority will be given to research with a high potential to create new products, processes or services which will be of benefit to Australian industry or society.

ANSWER.PARA: Customers or potential customers will be much more involved in setting CSIRO's priorities, financing, conducting of research and implementation of results. CSIRO's capacity to create or capture new knowledge which has longer term potential will be maintained and research in important areas of national interest, such as the environment, the oceans and atmosphere, and human nutrition, will be retained. The new structure, together with the strategy or objectives to which I have just referred, will be put in place as from 1 January 1988. Also, new guidelines are under discussion with CSIRO which will set out the Government's policies and priorities and help to guide the Organisation towards an increasingly productive future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy aware of the crisis among grain farmers on the Eyre Peninsula in South Australia who are expecting poor harvest yields this season for the third year in a row, causing a South Australian Department of Agriculture agronomist to describe their situation as disastrous? Has the Federal Budget reduced interest rate subsidies on rural adjustment loans to farmers to a level which will support a lending program of only $11m to needy South Australian farmers this year, compared with $37m last year? In view of the crisis on Eyre Peninsula, will the Government respond favourably to a request from the South Australian Minister of Agriculture for increased funds for interest rate subsidies on rural adjustment loans to South Australian farmers to allow a much needed increased lending program?
—We have just witnessed another example of why the Liberal Party of Australia deserves to be in opposition. It is full of humbugs and hypocrites. The same Party-
—Mr President, the Minister should be told to withdraw that.
—Order! Senator Walsh will withdraw that statement.

—I will withdraw. I think the facts speak for themselves. The Liberal Party spends most of its time running around the countryside demanding that Government expenditure be ruthlessly slashed by $7 billion, $9 billion, $10 billion, or $22 billion, if one takes the National Party's version of it. It spends the remainder of its time berating the Government for not providing additional handouts for this favoured group, that favoured group or some other favoured group.
—Where there is genuine need.
—I am about to come to that, too, Senator. Having been a practising farmer myself for well over 20 years--
—Not a very good one, either.

—I was quite a good one, actually. I did not get out of farming because I was going broke. The people who get out of farming because they are going broke end up as National Party politicians or sometimes Liberal Party politicians, not as Labor politicians. Anybody who knows anything about agriculture, or wheat growing in particular, would know that there are two major reasons why a substantial number-probably about one-sixth in total-of wheat farmers have very serious debt problems. The first is a combination of excessive purchases of plant-wasteful over-investment in plant and equipment, encouraged by the tax laws left behind by the last Government-and the second is that they paid too much for wheat growing land in the early 1980s, largely in the expectation of receiving untaxed capital gains.
—Who drove the interest rates up to 23 per cent?

—If Senator Messner and his lot had had the nerve and the common sense to reform the taxation system during that barren 7 1/4 years that they spent in government, there would not be nearly as many farmers in financial difficulties now as there are. From 1979 onwards the real price of wheat has been continuously falling, but for most of that period, until 1984 or even 1985, the price of wheat growing land has been going up. Obviously, that could not prevail forever. A major reason for the price of wheat growing land going up is that farmers had been encouraged to believe, and had come to believe, that they would be the beneficiaries of substantial untaxed capital gains from appreciating land prices. Well, it just could not go on. I repeat that if Senator Messner's lot had had any guts and sense, it would not have gone on for the seven barren years that they were in government.
—It is the interest rates that have killed them.

—That is another popular fallacy from someone who will accept, apparently, every opportunity to parade his ignorance of this subject. I will consult Mr Kerin about the specific amounts of money which have been provided in the Budget estimate and their breakup between the States and supply the facts.

—On 21 September, Senator Vallentine asked a question on the joint facilities which I answered in my capacity as the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. I undertook to refer her supplementary question to the Minister for Defence. On Thursday, 24 September, my colleague the Minister for Defence provided a comprehensive statement on the role of the defence support program. I refer the honourable senator to that response, which I am sure will allay any outstanding concerns.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: VNG STANDARD TIME AND FREQUENCY SERVICE

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Calvert asked me a question yesterday about the closure of the VNG facility and I undertook to seek supplementary information. I have now done that. Although the subject matter is fascinating to Senator Calvert and me, I doubt that that fascination will be shared by other people. I seek leave to incorporate the response in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The response read as follows-

Telecom's standard time and frequency service, VNG, has been transmitted from the Commonwealth transmitting station at Lyndhurst in Victoria for many years. However, Telecom itself has made no use of the VNG service for some time as its own needs for time and frequency signals are met through its terrestrial network.

The Commission had been proceeding towards the closure of the VNG service since September 1986; it contacted numerous users of the VNG service with a view to continuing the service if the users were prepared to fund its operation.

Before deciding to terminate the service, Telecom approached known major users, offering to transfer, free of charge, the existing transmitting equipment. In addition, Telecom contacted numerous users of the service with a view to having users fund a short postponement of the closure. However, none of the users of the VNG service was prepared to fund the continuation of the service.

In my former portfolio, as Minister for Resources and Energy, I had sought a postponement of the closure of VNG to 30 September 1987. This was to enable the Bureau of Mineral Resources, which operates some 20 seismological observatories, including those at Mawson and at Macquarie Island, time to examine whether it would fund a continuation of the VNG service or its relocation at another site.

I have recently been advised that the Bureau is establishing an alternative system for its seismological stations and it is expected that the new system will be in place by early next year. There will apparently be some difficulties during the construction of new Omega receivers, particularly at Mawson in Antarctica, but the Bureau decided that it was prepared to accept the closure of VNG on 30 September 1987. I understand that, in the meantime, they will use the less adequate United States' WWV signal from Hawaii.

In addition to the Bureau of Mineral Resources' requirement for VNG, the service was also used by surveying and mapping groups at Federal and State level, by private surveyors, geophysical and mineral exploration companies, and by transportation departments and companies. The signal was also received in neighbouring countries.

The National Standards Commission had conducted a survey of these other users of the VNG service. While the survey indicated that there was extensive and diverse use of the VNG service, the National Standards Commission failed to attract funds from private sector users for a continuation of the service.

DEBATE.TITLE: VISIT TO NORTH AND SOUTH AMERICA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a statement by the Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy) relating to his visit to North and South America.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
I would like to report to the House on the outcome of my visit to Canada, the United States, Brazil, Argentina and Uruguay from 11 to 29 September.

From the outset, I would like to report that in the United States and the various Cairns Group capitals visited, I received many expressions of appreciation for the positive contribution made by the former Minister for Trade, Mr Dawkins, in progressing the movement for world agricultural trade reform and for his most effective leadership as chairman of the Cairns Group.

The purpose of my visit to the United States was to register strongly Australia's concerns with several of the proposals contained in two trade Bills currently being considered by the Congress. The two versions of the Trade Bill, which were originated in each of the Houses of Congress, are in the process of being negotiated to a single Bill by a joint conference which includes members of both Houses. The Bill agreed by the conference will then be returned to both Houses for ratification before onforwarding to the President for his agreement or veto. Many of the proposals in the present versions of the Bill are protectionist in intent and unfortunately accurately reflect the current mood of many of those in Congress. This is a mood which countries like Australia must fight-the alternative is to allow the undermining of the international trade system to the detriment of all countries.

While in Washington I met with 10 congressmen-all of whom are participants in a joint conference of the Congress to consider the Bills-and with leading members of the Reagan Administration. I argued strongly for those congressmen to reconsider the most damaging elements of the Bills. I stressed the obvious contradiction between the radical US proposal for agricultural trade reform which they have tabled in the Uruguay Round negotiations in Geneva and the protectionist tendencies evident in draft US trade legislation. I pointed out that such a contradictory approach to trade policy put at risk the credibility of the United States. I argued that in the interests of all nations, what the United States should be doing is providing leadership in the process of trade reform-not trade destruction. Apart from the illogical and unsustainable direction of the draft legislation, I argued strongly that specific measures, which would directly damage Australia, should be reconsidered. I argued most strongly against the provision in the draft legislation which would restrict the entry of Australian lamb into the United States market. I also argued for the removal of a proposal to introduce an effective export subsidy for US sugar refiners. I repeated the Government's views on the intention to increase the funding for and duration of the export enhancement program. I also expressed concern at other elements of the Bills which would provide increased protection for US industry. I can see no justification for any of these proposals and I said so.

I received a good hearing from all those I met and was able to detail Australia's concern about the Bills and the general direction of US industry policy. I am reasonably optimistic that the final version of the US Trade Bill will emerge from the US Congress in an improved form.

I took up these same concerns with the U.S. Administration. While there was some agreement on the desirable direction of trade policy, I was particularly disappointed with the differences between us on the operation and extension of exports subsidy provisions under the export enhancement program. The Administration's position is that while it opposes export subsidies, in principle, the EEP is seen to have value as a retaliatory measure and as a means of putting pressure on the EC in particular, to negotiate on agricultural trade reform in the Uruguay Round of trade negotiations.

I indicated to the Administration that current US policies were placing only marginal pressure on the EC. I pointed out that contrary to US claims their strategy was proving ineffective in adding substantially to the cost of the Common Agricultural Policy, and that rather it had shifted the adjustment burden onto non-subsidising countries like Australia which were being caught in the subsidies crossfire. I drew out for them the consequences of reduced export income for Australia's purchasing power and what that could mean for future trade between our two countries.

I would like to note that despite the strong protectionist mood which prevails in the Congress there are some signs of recognition that increased protectionism is not the right path to take. One recent indication of this welcome development has been the failure of the Textiles Bill to attract enough support in the US House of Representatives to avoid a presidential veto.

I left the United States encouraged in this view by the efforts of certain congressmen and the Administration to work towards an open and fair trading environment, not only in the United States but globally as well. The statement by President Reagan to the IMF/World Bank meeting last week in Washington that he would veto any protectionist proposal is also a welcome reaffirmation of the Administration position. I am convinced that the repeated representations by this Government, especially given the reasonableness of our views, are essential if we are to protect both our bilateral trade position in the US as well as our position in international trade.

During my discussions in Canada and the US, I indicated clearly my concern that Australia's trading interests should be properly protected in any US-Canada trade agreement. Our officials are closely monitoring more recent negotiations in North America and have again been in contact with Canadian officials this week. It is still too early to judge the final form of the US-Canada agreement. However, the Government will continue to represent strongly our trading interests as the negotiations unfold.

While away I held discussions in Canada, Brazil, Argentina and Uruguay, which are members of the Cairns Group of Fair Traders in Agriculture. The principal objective of my visit to these countries was to discuss with Ministers our common interests in seeking comprehensive agricultural reform, to gain an appreciation of the priorities of these countries in the GATT negotiations, and, in particular, the strategy which the Cairns group might follow for the remainder of 1987.

Firstly, I would emphasise that it was evident during my visit that the Cairns Group has become a recognised and respected voice in the debate on agricultural trade reform. I received strong encouragement, including support from the United States, for the group to continue its efforts in maintaining the momentum for agricultural trade reform in the Uruguay round of trade negotiations.

In all four countries, I was impressed by the strong commitment to the group. I was reassured of the future of the group by the strong expressions of support for the objectives of the group and by the assurances I received of active and constructive participation in its future activities. Argentina has offered to host a further meeting of the group at ministerial level in the first quarter of 1988. Subject to the view of other members of the group on this proposal, I welcomed this offer and indicated Australia's participation towards its success.

I will be visiting Thailand, Malaysia and Indonesia on my way back from Europe later in the month. These ASEAN countries are also members of the Cairns Group. I shall take the opportunity of my visit to obtain their views on the appropriate future strategy of the Cairns group.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.
Debate (on motion by Senator Stone) adjourned.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 7 October, from Senator Puplick:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order 64, I give notice that today I propose to move-
``That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need for the Government to tackle tax evasion and welfare fraud in a way that does not unacceptably trespass on civil liberties and individual privacy and for it to cease its campaign of smear and misrepresentation against opponents of the discredited Australia Card legislation.''
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need for the Government to tackle tax evasion and welfare fraud in a way that does not unacceptably trespass on civil liberties and individual privacy and for it to cease its campaign of smear and misrepresentation against opponents of the discredited Australia Card legislation.

This matter of urgency before the Senate has two elements to it. The first identifies the continuing failure of the Labor Government to deal with the issues of taxation evasion and welfare fraud, except by making slick comments about the necessity for the Australia Card legislation to be passed without amendment. The second element deals with the Government's campaign of smear and misrepresentation against opponents of the discredited Australia Card legislation and allows us to identify why it is that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) are now embarked upon a campaign of smear and deliberate misrepresentation, a campaign which owes its principles to Joseph McCarthy and its techniques to Joseph Goebbels.

The biggest lie which this Government has attempted to put across is that the Australia Card is a simple solution to all of the problems of welfare fraud and tax evasion and that such a system can be introduced without in any way trespassing unduly upon the rights and liberties of Australian citizens. If anything needed to be brought forward to give the lie to that claim by the Government, it is to be found in its own Review of Systems for Dealing with Fraud on the Commonwealth, a report which was presented just a couple of days ago. Page 33 of the report states:
Not all fraud can be prevented or countered. A watertight system would require controls of Orwellian dimension and prohibitive cost.

I am fully aware that Senator Schacht, who has attempted to interject in the last couple of moments, objects neither to Orwellian controls nor to unlimited expenditure of public money. Undoubtedly, he would have had an opportunity to participate in this debate to make sure that people understood that the Australian Labor Party is perfectly happy to go along with a system in which those Orwellian controls are put in place and those prohibitive costs are imposed on the people and the taxpayers of Australia.

I want to make plain the Opposition parties' clear position in response to the Australia Card legislation's defeat, although we have been waiting for the Government to announce clearly what steps it proposed to take from the moment that it realised that its Australia Card legislation was doomed. Today, the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, put out a statement on behalf of the Opposition parties dealing with this matter quite unequivocally. Mr Howard said in his statement:
The Opposition welcomes the Government's decision, in the face of the Liberal and National Parties campaign and overwhelming public opposition, to withdraw the Australia Card legislation.
That legislation was unacceptable to the Opposition because:
it clearly would not have solved the basic problems of tax fraud and welfare cheating;
it would not have been cost effective; and
it represented an unacceptable level of intrusion upon personal privacy and individual civil liberties.
It is now up to the Government to bring forward either legislation or appropriate administrative reforms which will achieve these objectives.

The Opposition makes it clear that we are totally and utterly opposed to taxation fraud and welfare cheating. Such behaviour is not only illegal but it also imposes additional costs and burdens on the vast majority of honest, law-abiding Australian citizens.

In government the Liberal and National Parties waged a relentless and effective attack upon tax evasion. All the major strikes against tax evaders over the past decade were initiated by the former Liberal and National Party Government.

For example, the prescribed payments system, so lauded by the Minister for Finance in the Senate yesterday as a major weapon against tax evasion, was introduced by the Fraser Government in the 1982 Budget.
The Liberal and National Parties will give their support to any reasonable measures which:
(1) effectively eliminate tax fraud and welfare cheating;
(2) are cost effective in so doing; and
(3) do not unreasonably intrude upon personal privacy and individual civil liberties.

This has been the formal position of the Opposition for well over three years. When the idea of some form of national identification system was first proposed we made our position clear and we have not deviated from that at any stage.
We rejected the Australia Card legislation because all the evidence indicated that it failed to meet each of our three tests.
In relation to the use of an upgraded tax file number our position is equally clear.

Firstly, we will support moves to upgrade the degree of integrity of the tax file number system. This is essential to ensure that people do not abuse the system by, for example, having more than one tax file number.

In addition, we will favourably consider any proposals designed to improve the use of tax file numbers for proper taxation and welfare purposes such as those already provided for in the Income Tax Assessment Act. Any such proposals will be judged against our three stated criteria.
However, we will vigorously oppose any attempt to turn the tax file number system into a de facto Australia Card system.

The Opposition and the Senate have indicated what is not acceptable to us, namely the Australia Card legislation as proposed. Equally we have indicated consistently since 1985 what is acceptable to us.

Labor's failure to produce acceptable and proper reforms must bring condemnation upon the Government. It would indicate that they are not serious about addressing the significant problems of tax fraud and welfare cheating but are interested only in playing sleazy and shabby political games at the expense of law-abiding Australians.
Our bona fides in this matter are not open to question, what is in doubt are the Government's.
The Opposition totally rejects the McCarthyist-style campaign of the Government to smear the opponents of the Australia Card as friends of tax evaders and welfare cheats.
The Prime Minister has repeatedly and fraudulently used the figure of $1 billion without providing a skerrick of evidence of how such a figure was determined.

In addition, the former ID Task Force chaired by David Jull, will be renamed the Anti Fraud Task Force and will have a new role of examining available material on methods of dealing with tax and welfare fraud. It will also continue to monitor the general matter of privacy protection for Australians against the creation and misuse of centralised data banks.
We have also moved to ensure that a Senate Committee examine in detail the likely effectiveness and possible flaws of any Government proposals to:
improve the efficiency of the tax system; and
eliminate fraud and abuses in the tax and social security system.

There can be no doubt as to where the Opposition stands and has consistently stood in relation to the question of the elimination of taxation fraud and welfare cheating. By contrast, that stands markedly against the lack of success, indeed the lack of effort, made by this Government directed towards those particular problems.

I turn first, therefore, to the question of what our record was on tax matters and indicate that from early 1978 onwards the Fraser Government followed a steady pattern of outlawing specific tax avoidance practices as they came to light. A string of amendments to taxation laws was announced and subsequently implemented and by the start of 1982 the Government-that is, the Liberal and National Party Government-had introduced over 22 pieces of legislation closing down over 50 tax avoidance schemes of which the landmark decisions were the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act of December 1980 and the new part IVa of the Income Tax Assessment Act. On 16 April 1985, the then Minister for Finance, Mr Dawkins, addressed a seminar, and I quote from a report on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio:

The Finance Minister, Mr Dawkins, says tax avoidance is `no longer an issue in Australia'. Mr Dawkins told a conference of accountants in Sydney last night that both the accountancy profession and the Government had `put the question of tax avoidance behind them'.

They are the words of Mr Dawkins, that it was no longer an issue and the issue of tax avoidance had been put behind the Government. Yet Senator Schacht, Senator Aulich and Senator Ryan come in here bleating about tax avoidance problems despite the fact that their former Minister for Finance, Mr Dawkins, had said that it was no longer an issue and that the Government had put it behind it. It is no wonder that they are sensitive on this question of taxation reform and taxation fraud. If honourable senators look at an article by Ross Gittins in the Sydney Morning Herald on 30 May 1984 analysing what this Government had done to date on the question of tax reform they will see that he indicated that a Labor Party publication prior to the election had, in fact, been issued-a 20-page policy statement on tax avoidance called `A Fairer Taxation System'. Gittins went on to say in his article:
. . . by comparison with all it said and all the promises it made before the election, Labor's performance on tax avoidance has been, in a word, pathetic.
In almost 15 months, Paul Keating has acted on virtually none of the 13 points.

That was in the Government's own document; that was in its own policy statement on this particular matter. So we have an absolute lack of record for the Labor Party. We have Mr Dawkins admitting that the 22 pieces of legislation introduced and passed through the Parliament by the Fraser Government had taken that issue to the point of being a non-issue and an issue which the Government itself had admitted that it had put behind it. Consistently, this Opposition has put before the people of Australia and before the Parliament a series of realistic alternatives. When we have come to the area of fraud in the welfare system we have had two initiatives which we have put before this Parliament on which the Government has sought from time to time to heap scorn and has failed to take up the proposals. The first proposal has been the initiation of a comprehensive policy on the question of work for unemployment benefit. On 20 October 1986, Senator Chaney moved a motion in the Senate which indicated:
The need for the Government to endorse the principle that some form of community work be required of those in receipt of unemployment benefit.

I and a number of other senators had the opportunity to participate in that debate. My colleague Senator Alston produced a paper in October 1986 on workfare which was subsequently, in an amended form, reproduced in the Current Affairs Bulletin of April 1987. We have consistently said, `Here is a method of dealing with part of the difficulty of cheating in the unemployment benefit system'. If one looks once again at the Government's own report, Review of Systems for Dealing with Fraud on the Commonwealth, one will see on page 181 that in analysing the fraud against the Department of Social Security overpayments were detected to the sum of $73.7m of which $32.5m arose in the area of unemployment benefit. That would have been substantially addressed if the Opposition's proposals on the work for benefits scheme had, in fact, been acted upon. But back in 1979 when Mr Hawke was the leader of the Australian Council of Trade Unions he said that the proposal to have any scheme of work for the dole was `a political sham without substantive foundations'. No wonder the Government is not prepared to do anything about that. Yet we know that the schemes work. For instance, we know that the Liberal Government in Tasmania has an excellent scheme which has been operating in George Town. Its work for the dole program has made notable progress.

The other major area which is identified in terms of overpayment in the Department of Social Security has been in the area of supporting parent's benefit-$15.6m out of the $73.7m. Yet on every occasion when Senator Durack and other senators on this side have sought to bring forward changes in areas such as the Family Law Act dealing with maintenance and proposals which would in fact address some of the financial problems in the supporting parent's benefit, again this Government has had absolutely nothing to do with that. This Government has an appalling record on both taxation reform and taxation fraud compared with that of its predecessor, the Fraser Government. In terms of doing something about fraud within the Department of Social Security, it has had from the Opposition positive suggestions dealing with the major areas in which fraud has taken place and it has declined to take any substantive action.

We come, finally, to that part of this motion which, as I say, relates to the campaign mounted by Senator Walsh, the Prime Minister, Senator Ryan and others, which simply gets into the business of attempting to smear and misrepresent those persons who have been genuinely concerned about the Australia Card legislation, presumably a smear which goes to the 85,000-odd Australians who have signed petitions which have been presented in this chamber alone dealing with the question of their opposition to the Australia Card. As I said, it is a campaign based upon taking its principles from Joseph McCarthy and its techniques from Joseph Goebbels. Members of the Labor Party have refined both to an absolute art form. Nobody in this Parliament is better known throughout the length and breadth of the Commonwealth of Australia than Senator Walsh as working on the basis that if one cannot answer a point of substance or address arguments against Labor Party propositions on the basis of the truth, one simply muckrakes and throws dirt in the hope that some of it will stick. Senator Walsh positively revels in the process at every opportunity. The tragedy is that basically decent people such as Senator Ryan find that this is now the only technique that they can manage to bring to account. People such as Senator Schacht find themselves given little pieces of paper to read out at Question Time to allow Senator Walsh to get on with yet another of these techniques.

It is a great pity that Senator Walsh's corrupting techniques have now spread as far as they have throughout the back bench of the Labor Party opposite. Nevertheless, that does not disguise the fact that this Government has been unable to answer the points of substance raised against the Australia Card proposal. It has been unable to answer them and, more particularly, it has failed consistently to bring forward techniques and proposals for the way in which it will go about reforming the taxation system and the welfare system. It refuses to face up to the fact that its primary responsibility in taxation reform ought to be to introduce lower levels of taxation and that its primary responsibility in the welfare system ought to be to cast more personal responsibility upon the recipients of welfare payments. It refuses to face up to those two fundamental requirements for reform of the taxation and welfare systems.

Under those circumstances, the Opposition has no embarrassment about the extent to which it has successfully waged the campaign against the Australia Card, not on behalf of tax cheats, not on behalf of people who are fraudulently receiving payments under the welfare system, but on behalf of the majority of Australians who, at the last election, voted for political parties clearly opposed to the Australia Card-people who are genuinely concerned about their civil liberties and who are aware of the comment in the Review of Systems for Dealing with Fraud on the Commonwealth about the prohibitive costs and the Orwellian dimensions that would be introduced into public life in Australia by introducing the sort of system that this Government favours. We have no embarrassment about our actions because we have attacked the Australia Card on its merits and its demerits. We have indicated clearly what we will support as an alternative. We have indicated clearly by our record on taxation reform and welfare reform that the record of the Opposition parties will stand any scrutiny. Indeed, it will stand any degree of muckraking, personal abuse, smear and misrepresentation which the Labor Party likes to put forward.

Madam Acting Deputy President, as you know, this Government has already been forced into one humiliating backdown on the Australia Card. The very least it can do now is to be honest and decent enough to put forward its alternative proposals, with which we will deal fairly on their merits, on the basis of the principles enunciated in Mr Howard's statement today which I have now put into the record.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the course of the overexcited ranting that Senator Puplick has just inflicted on the Senate, he claimed on a couple of occasions that he was not embarrassed by the Opposition's position on the Australia Card or on measures to crack down on tax evasion and welfare fraud.
