I do not believe Senator Puplick. I think Senator Puplick is very embarrassed, and he has very good reason to be embarrassed. After all, why would he not be embarrassed in bringing before the Senate such a stupid, pointless motion. The motion states that as a matter of urgency the Government should proceed with measures to crack down on tax evasion and welfare fraud, or words to that effect. How ludicrous it is for Senator Puplick to bring this motion forward in the Senate when he and his cohorts opposite have spent the last few weeks doing everything possible, employing every trick in the book, to make sure that the Government could not proceed urgently to introduce the most effective measures yet devised to remove frauds and cheats from the system.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Puplick's actions belie directly his words. Senator Puplick has been put in a very embarrassing and humiliating position, because the Opposition parties have decided to use their numbers to disallow a regulation in order to block the principal Act, to block a piece of legislation which was the cause and trigger for a double dissolution. At the election following that double dissolution the Government was returned to office with an increased majority and therefore with the right to hold a joint sitting and secure the legislation that was the trigger for the double dissolution. Senator Puplick's cohorts opposite have decided to use for the first time in 87 years a minor regulatory power of the Senate to prevent the use of section 57 of the Constitution which was set up precisely to resolve differences between the Houses. It seems that one of the Opposition spokespersons-I do not know whether he is the most official Opposition spokesperson but certainly he is the most vociferous and irritating Opposition spokesperson-Mr Wilson Tuckey, has now decided that he will back down on any measure that might have any chance of being effective in stopping tax evasion.

Senator Puplick was a member of the now famous Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card and a signatory to its report. That Committee recommended the implementation of a number of measures involving the use of tax file numbers. Such measures would not be as effective as an Australia Card but they would be effective in cracking down on the dreadful evasion and cheating that is occurring at the expense of honest taxpayers. Senator Puplick is now in a position where he has to back down from supporting even those most modest measures because Mr Wilson Tuckey has decided, with or without consultation with the Liberals opposite, that he will not allow any effective measure to be taken.

Obviously, the Opposition is in complete disarray about this matter. We have Wilson Tuckey saying one thing one day; we have orders from Liberal Party of Australia headquarters that he should shut up and stop saying those things; we have Wilson Tuckey revealing by his comments that he does not even understand the way in which the current tax legislation operates in respect of employers' obligations in reporting taxable payments to employees. John Howard, who has committed so many somersaults over this issue that he should run away and join the circus, today made a statement in which he tried to re-create some sort of sense of commitment to ending tax evasion.

I should make it clear in the course of this debate that the Opposition appears to grow furious, enraged and embarrassed when the Government points out to it that its actions have assisted tax evaders and welfare frauds. They are the facts, and the Opposition cannot stomach those facts. The Opposition then accuses the Government of saying that every Australian citizen who had worries about the Australia Card was lining up with the tax cheats and the tax frauds. What a distortion that is. We have never said that. Because of the kind of misleading, hysterical campaign in which the Liberals participated, because of the particularly misleading and frightening things that some self-styled leaders of the campaign against the Australia Card said, some people in the community were genuinely worried and concerned about the measures; they misunderstood the measures and feared them because of the misrepresentation of the likes of honourable senators opposite. We are not saying that every person who signed a petition against the introduction of the Australia Card was a supporter of tax cheats or tax frauds. But we are saying that the only effect of the action of Liberal senators opposite is to protect the cheats and the frauds. We also remind them of a fact of which Senator Chaney does not wish to be reminded, that the Leader of the Liberal Party of Australia, John Howard, who apparently has made some bleating statement today to try to restore his credibility in this area, was silent for eight weeks of an election campaign on the question of the Australia Card. It is John Howard and his ilk we are accusing of hypocrisy in this matter, not the citizens of Australia who understandably have been led by a most outrageous campaign of misrepresentation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a point of order. The Minister cannot accuse the Leader of the Opposition of hypocrisy. That is clearly unparliamentary and should be withdrawn.
—Order! I suggest that the Minister withdraw that unparliamentary remark.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, of course I comply with your ruling, but I point out that John Howard was quoted on a number of occasions as supporting these sorts of measures. He then retreated from those remarks, and it appears that today he has discovered the value and benefit of introducing measures to crack down on tax evasion. I shall not describe that series of somersaults in a way that is unparliamentary, but honest, sensible Australian citizens can make up their own minds about what it all means.

SPEECH.PARA: The other extraordinary thing that Senator Puplick tried to do was boast of the Fraser Government's record in the area of tax reform. What a pathetic effort that was. What a shameful and shameless performance that was. I remind honourable senators and the Australian public of the tax reform record of honourable senators opposite. I remind them that it was honourable senators opposite who opposed the recovery of money from bottom of the harbour frauds, who condemned the capital gains tax, who denounced the fringe benefits tax, who criticised the Australia Card, and who derided the introduction of the Cash Transaction Reports Bill. In the course of the recent election campaign they promised to remove most of those tax reform measures if returned to government. Senator Puplick can shout and scream and froth all he likes, but the record of the Opposition parties in opposition-they have been in opposition for the last few years and will be for many years to come-and in government previously has been absolutely pathetic. At the end of the day the Opposition, whether it likes it or not, has lined up with those who are seeking to avoid and evade their honest tax responsibilities.

Senator Puplick has come here today asking us to consider as a matter of urgency the question of acting on tax fraud and welfare fraud. He ignores the fact, as he has ignored it for some months now, that we are doing that. He has suddenly rediscovered himself as some sort of self-professed civil libertarian. He wants us to make sure that we do not unacceptably trespass on civil liberties and individual privacy. We are taking such action. I remind Senator Puplick of the words of a person who is not an Australian, David Lange, the Prime Minister of New Zealand. When asked his views on civil liberties and the Australia Card and the various measures we were proposing, he said that he was very concerned with civil liberties; he was very concerned with the civil liberties of the honest citizen who was being increasingly burdened by the activities of tax evasion and welfare fraud. Mr Lange-I refer to him because he was not a participant in the debate up to that point-gave an honest and direct answer and said that he was concerned with the civil liberties of those honest Australian citizens who are fed up to the back teeth with the welfare frauds and the tax evaders.

Let me remind honourable senators of what Senator Puplick and the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card, of which he was an active member and the report of which he wrote and signed, actually advocated. It is a very different series of steps from what he is advocating today. All he can say today is that he wants the unemployed to be forced to work for the dole. That is the single anti-tax and welfare fraud measure that he has proposed. But a few months ago, when he was a very active member of the Joint Select Committee, he advocated, in recommendation 4.58:

That the use of the tax file number be extended to cover all the financial transactions proposed in the Government submission for the use of the Australia Card by the Australian Taxation Office, as well as for social security purposes.

That is what he said then. What is he saying now? Our Government is currently examining ways of using the tax file numbers to achieve those ends. The Joint Select Committee recommended in recommendation 2 (a):
That the computerisation of all State and Territory Registries of Births, Deaths and Marriages proceed.

It further recommended that the Commonwealth provide appropriate assistance and advice to ensure that that was being done. That is what he recommended then. Did he utter one word about the births, deaths and marriages register today? Did he make one suggestion about how the very widespread fraudulent use of birth certificates documented by Frank Costigan in the report of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union could be dealt with? No. He was totally silent on that question today. Of course, I understand that I am not to use the word `hypocrisy' because it offends the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney). That is what Senator Puplick advocated then; today there is absolute silence.

The Joint Select Committee agreed that there should be a Data Protection Agency. Of course, we accepted that recommendation and we have announced that we are proceeding with a Data Protection Agency. Do we get one word of commendation or support from Senator Puplick, the great civil libertarian, the great self-professed born again civil libertarian, about our adoption of the recommendation of the Joint Select Committee for a Data Protection Agency? There is not a word, total silence now about the single most progressive measure that any government has introduced to protect citizens against the abuse of data held about them in government and some private data banks.

We have, of course, introduced the privacy Bills and we will proceed with them and pass them as soon as possible. They set out a number of very important principles that have been internationally endorsed whereby all government agencies can ensure that the privacy of individuals is properly protected. Do we hear one word of support from Senator Puplick about the good thing the Government is doing in proceeding with the privacy Bills? No, he is totally silent. No doubt Wilson `Iron Bar' Tuckey has silenced him and made a few threats about what would happen should he suggest that he actually supports the Government's Data Protection Agency or the privacy Bills.

All the measures the Government proposes now-the Data Protection Agency, the births, deaths and marriages register, the privacy legislation, the improved use of the tax file system to cut down on cheating and fraud; the current package of measures that the Government has brought forward and announced to replace the Australia Card legislation-were supported by the Joint Select Committee of which Senator Puplick was a member and a contributor and the report of which he was a signatory to. Yet today we heard nothing from him about these wonderful recommendations he was so proud to put his name to a few months ago.

We are including in our measures the greatest array of protections for the individual this country has ever seen. Yet, what do we get from the Opposition? Constant denigration, constant misrepresentation, constant negativism and obstruction. The Opposition parties-I include the Australian Democrats; up to this point they have made no constructive contribution; perhaps Senator Haines will make one today but she has not yet-have given no assistance in the massive task the Government has to pursue in getting the frauds and the cheats out of the system. We have had no assistance in recouping for the Australian people the $1 billion, or thereabouts, that has been assessed as what is being lost to revenue by the cheats and the frauds. So, we have to ask ourselves why Senator Puplick wasted everyone's time by bringing forward such a silly, hypocritical, ultimately self-destructive motion as he did today.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are getting worried.

—The answer clearly is, as my colleague the very experienced senator from the Northern Territory, who has seen a bit of redneck behaviour in his time, knows, Opposition senators are getting worried. They are getting worried because the number of somersaults, backflips, about-turns and contradictions that they have collectively and individually done on this issue has just become too much for the Australian public and too much for the Australian media. They have been able to fool some of the people some of the time but they cannot fool all of the people all of the time, and Senator Puplick's time has run out.

SPEECH.PARA: Madam Acting Deputy President, let me give the Senate a collection of the kinds of things the editorials are saying that have frightened Senator Puplick into bringing this silly motion before the Senate today. The Launceston Examiner-it is a shame Senator Walters is not here to hear this-said:
(An improved tax file number system and other measures) deserved the support of the people of Australia and should get the backing of the Senate.
On 30 September the Daily Sun said:

Those politicians who staged a late anti-ID Card assault can go some way towards redeeming their reputations if they now direct their energies towards formulating an acceptable and workable national strategy to ensure our treasure is expended efficiently and fairly.
The Card has been torn up. Those who shredded it now face the challenge of coming up with a workable alternative.
The Courier-Mail, not known for its radical views, as you would know, Madam Acting Deputy President, said:
The Government should not forget the admission of the Opposition leader, Mr Howard, that he once favoured the idea of the Card.
It's ideals should not be allowed to perish with it.
The reasons for the Card are just as relevant today as when the Government first promoted them.
(An upgraded tax file numbering system) was a consensus option suggested by the first select committee of inquiry into the Card.
On 1 October the Age said:
To its credit, the Government remains determined to diminish tax evasion and welfare fraud. These measures-
referring to the package of measures announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)-
should reinforce the fight against organised crime as well as tax evasion and deserve political and public support.
By abandoning the ID scheme and committing itself to alternative means of combating tax and welfare cheating, the Government has put the Opposition and the Australian Democrats on the spot.
Having recommended an upgraded tax file numbering system . . . they would lose their credibility and respect if they now sought to hinder these options as well.
On 29 September the Daily Mirror said:
In a major policy reversal, Democrats Leader, Senator Janine Haines said that wide ranging use of tax numbers . . . could not be justified.
Yet something must be done to net the tax and welfare cheats.
On 1 October the Sydney Morning Herald said:
Put simply, the Opposition has really nowhere to run on this issue.
Does Mr Howard doubt that up to $900 million a year is being lost this way?
When the majority on the joint select committee rejected last year . . . the Identity Card . . . it embraced an alternative. That alternative was the extension of the tax file number system.
Mr Howard is stretching it if he suggests an enhanced tax file number system is an ID Card by another name.
He risks the judgment that he and the Liberal Party have abandoned principles for sectional interests.
This is an accusation that the Liberal Party, of course, does not like but one that is now being made in the editorials of the Sydney Morning Herald. The Newcastle Herald of 1 October stated:
The victory for the Opposition? Not necessarily.
The method by which the Australia Card was killed has left a dangerous legacy: a precedent that reinforces the supremacy of the undemocratic upper house over an elected government.

Those are very sobering words used in the Newcastle Herald's editorial and it is a very sobering thought that Opposition senators were so determined to exploit, so determined to be opportunistic about this very serious measure and so determined to gain any kind of populist support they might be able to squeeze out of the issue, that they were prepared to act in a way that is contrary, not only in the short term but also in the longer term, to the interests of the proper workings of the Senate and to the interests of democracy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nonsense!

—Senator Stone, a newcomer in this place, says, `Nonsense!', but Senator Stone will not be able to get up in the course of this debate and point to one other occasion in the last 87 years of Federation when a Senate has decided to use a minor regulatory power to block the effect of a principal Act. Whatever he might like to say, he will not be able to give us one example of that and he will not be able to justify the course of action which he persuaded his colleagues to adopt, for which he became a one-day wonder.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter of tax evasion and welfare cheating is urgent. To that extent and that extent only we have a substantial motion before us. But the tactics and behaviour of members of the Opposition have been pathetic, they have been unprincipled, they have been undemocratic and they have been totally unconstructive in assisting a properly elected government to behave responsibly on behalf of honest taxpayers and genuine welfare beneficiaries in this country. The motion deserves the contempt that I hope it will get.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The urgency motion that has been introduced by Senator Puplick calls for the support of the Senate in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to tackle tax evasion and welfare fraud in a way that does not unacceptably trespass on civil liberties and individual privacy and for it to cease its campaign of smear and misrepresentation against opponents of the discredited Australia Card legislation.

That certainly will get the support of the Australian Democrats despite the 20 minutes of rhetoric that we have just heard from the Special Minister of State (Senator Ryan), who so unwisely took on the oversight of this doomed piece of legislation following the election a couple of months ago. The Minister has managed to fire an assortment of shots across an assortment of bows, most of which, I am pleased to say, have missed completely. She finally resorted to quoting from, of all things, an editorial in the Newcastle Herald which is claiming that undemocratically elected upper houses should not have a say in the legislative process. I wonder what she thinks of the sort of situation that we see on a day to day basis in Queensland, which does not have an upper House, undemocratically elected or not, to offset some of the worst excesses of that unicameral system. I point out that this chamber has the same powers as the lower House-it quite rightly has those powers until the people of Australia take them away-and for a very good reason indeed.

Both Senator Ryan and the Newcastle Herald editor seem to think that proportional representation is somehow less democratic as an electoral system than single member electorates that lead to governments being formed with considerably less than 50 per cent of the first preference votes. Now tell me which of those two is less democratic and I will point out that Australia is not, and will never be, a dictatorship while this Senate remains as a House of review with the powers that it currently has. We should not sit back simply because an undemocratically elected government attempts to foist unacceptable legislation down the throats of the Australian public. We in this chamber must not sit back and accept the sorts of unacceptable procedures that were contained in the ID card legislation when other measures can be found to implement the processes and should be tried first.

Let us have a look at what this Government has done over the last few years to crack down on tax avoidance and evasion and social security fraud. In some instances it has had considerable support from us as it had with the prescribed payments scheme, which was an exceptionally successful attempt to crack down on large losses through large scale cash payments in the economy. We were prepared to accept the imposition of a capital gains tax system, of fringe benefits, of an assets test system and of negative gearing, until this Government so churlishly bowed to the demands of the property developers in Sydney and turned turtle on that one, in order to make the tax system in this country fairer and more equitable. More importantly, I stress that this has happened not only since the Government mooted an ID card system at the National Taxation Summit in 1985 but also since the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card brought down its report.

In the last 10 months we have seen significant crackdowns in the social security area and the tax avoidance and evasion areas, both of which have recouped large amounts of money. I think we have to be careful that we do not double count when we are debating what is going on in cracking down on tax and social security fraud. The Government is still claiming that a national identification system of the sort that it proposed in the Australia Card Bill would raise all the money it first predicted, notwithstanding the fact that large chunks of it-in fact, almost the entire amount-have been recouped through a variety of measures since that proposal came into effect.

In April 1987 the Minister for Social Security, Mr Howe, announced a crackdown in the social security area that he anticipated would save $100m annually. This followed the six-point plan announced in February 1986 to recover overpayments resulting in savings of an additional $90m. A further $19.7m was saved as a result of the three-month amnesty on people who were inappropriately and illegally claiming social security benefits-not an insignificant amount of saving from the social welfare fraud area. The May economic statement saw the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announcing a large number of measures to improve administration in a variety of departments, in particular the Australian Taxation Office and the Department of Social Security, and the strengthening of eligibility criteria to counter fraud and abuse. These measures were costed by the Government-not by somebody on this side of the House making up the figures; quite likely the Government was making up the figures, but they are the Government's figures-as follows: changes in benefit eligibility were estimated to raise $65.3m in 1987-88 and $85.3m in 1988-89. Of course, those measures included strengthening residency requirements for access to temporary benefits by people who were temporary residents of this country. On the Government's own figures administration changes, such as increasing debt recovery provisions, would increase by $79m in 1987-88 and $138m in 1988-89, and a further $4m this financial year is estimated to come from the recovery of overpayments.

So there have been significant savings by other non-invasive measures already implemented by this Government in the area of social security. In total, by 1988-89, that is, by the end of the next financial year, some $418m will have been recouped-nearly half a billion dollars over a two-year period-in cracking down on social security fraud alone. I remind the Senate that when the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, was last speaking on this matter he estimated that the Government believed that $4.5 billion would be raised through a fully fledged ID card system over a 10-year period; meaning that, in essence, $450m per year would be raised over that 10 years. Already the Government, in these measures I have mentioned, is coming up with savings of $418m in a two-year period. So, more than half the money in that period has been raised already from those measures.

We then come to some tax fraud prevention procedures introduced by Trevor Boucher, the Commissioner of Taxation, and proudly, and I think justifiably, touted by him recently as raising significant amounts of money. One of those is an improved auditing system. According to the Australian Financial Review of 28 July extra revenue raised was something like $461m in 1985-86 and $723m in 1986-87. That is extra revenue in those 12-month periods, due to increased auditing procedures, of several hundred million dollars. Much of that money has been raised from corporations with offshore structures. That matter should have been attended to a long time ago; but even so, I understand those audits applied initially only to companies making $100m a year profit or more. According to the Commissioner they raised on average $2.5m per company audited. He is now talking about placing in the offices of some of those major companies an auditor as a permanent part of the furniture, so to speak. He will be there for ready reference so that the companies do not have to be spot checked in this way but can more appropriately assess their tax liability during the year. So, $723m was raised during 1986-87 due to the improved auditing measures and more is expected to be raised in 1987-88.

Let me go back a few years to another scheme that this Government introduced, again getting the support of the Australian Democrats, in order to crack down on lost revenue. That was the prescribed payments scheme that I mentioned a while ago. It attacked large scale evasion in the cash economy area and since 1983 it will have raised a total of $2.75 billion, much of it coming from the 50,000 extra tax file number holders who have since registered as a consequence of the implementation of the prescribed payments scheme.

Dividend and interest income is another area where there are distinct possibilities and capabilities of fraud being engaged in. An additional 115 staff were employed by the Tax Office in 1985-86 to check up on possible evasion and avoidance in this area. This led to a huge increase in amended assessments, raising something like $96.2m in that year alone. Indeed, earlier this year in a speech in Queensland the Commissioner of Taxation said that during 1987-88 the dividend and interest check system will be developed into a generalised matching system. Features of the expanded system include, first, aggregation of a variety of income payment types taking in dividend and interest payments, partnership and trust distributions, PPS income-that is, prescribed payments scheme income-rents and unemployment benefits; secondly, extension of the computer-based taxpayer identification process to include taxpayer records for which no assessment has issued; thirdly, production of individual case reports which will summarise all taxpayer related transaction data; fourthly, enhanced presentation and follow up of the unmatched transaction data where no taxpayer record is on file; and, fifthly, production of case reports for registered taxpayers who have not lodged returns but who on the basis of recorded income data have a liability to do so. In addition, he said, the Tax Office will use external sources of information to test whether the level of assets owned by a taxpayer is in line with the level of income returned. So that is an attempt to crack down on what is left of the cash economy by finding out essentially whether people are living beyond their means.

I presume the Tax Office's new $700m computer system will be used to check income from interest payments, dividends and so on. If it is not, it is an appalling waste of money by a government that knew this ID card legislation was going to be defeated in this place and went ahead anyway spending that much of taxpayers' money on a system that may well not be able to be put to a great deal more use. The measures I have just mentioned with regard to tax and social security fraud have in the main been introduced since the Government announced the ID card legislation with claims about how much it would raise from implementing the ID card system. The only exception to that was the prescribed payments scheme which was introduced in 1983. The bulk of the systems I have mentioned today were introduced post mid-1985. Does the Government then not realise there is only so much blood to be got out of the same stone? One cannot recoup this sort of money from these sorts of areas and still get the same or more from a system imposed on top.

Of course we still need to improve and upgrade the tax file number system. There are people who should have one who do not, and people who have two or three who should have only one. I do not accept the comment by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) that a lot of honest, law-abiding citizens have more than one tax file number, because I do not think those two things can necessarily tie up. `Upgraded' does not mean `excessively extended'. `Upgraded' means improved in integrity and made to work properly. I support fully the Opposition's urgency motion today. Other measures must be tried before we go down the invasive, intrusive little frolic of an ID card system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion moved by Senator Puplick. I suggest that the motion needs to be read in a number of segments. It begins with the need for the Government to tackle tax evasion and welfare fraud. That is the first element, so to speak, of the motion before the chamber. The fact is-and honourable senators on the Government side know this perfectly well-that there is no difference between the views on that side of the chamber and the views on this side of the chamber about the overwhelming importance of dealing with tax evasion and welfare fraud. That should be clearly on the record and we should put an end to this divisive and shameful smear campaign coming from the Government side of the chamber to the contrary. That should be put to rest. I appeal to Government senators to stop this nonsense. They know it is nonsense; they know it to be untruthful. It does them no credit and it diminishes not merely their own standing but the standing of this chamber, which is a great deal more important than their personal standing.

SPEECH.PARA: In the past the Australian Labor Party, that is to say the party now in government-and I give it full credit for this-has always been highly intolerant of tax cheats, as any right-minded person should be. However, I have to say that the Labor Party has in the past been much more tolerant of welfare fraud than it has recently become. I greatly welcome the Labor Party's conversion on that matter, but how has it come about that only in the last nine months or so we have started to get measures from this Government to deal with welfare fraud? It is not as though the subject is a new one or that it never came to the attention of the party that occupies the benches on the Government side of the House. As I say, I welcome the conversion of the members of the Government, but let us not have any nonsense from their side that somehow they have always been anxious to crack down on both tax cheats-which they certainly have been, and I acknowledge that-and purveyors of welfare fraud, whereas senators on this side of the chamber have been anxious to do neither. In fact, that is not the truth. In fact, honourable senators opposite are well aware of that and it is to their personal shame that they should put forward views to the contrary.

The second element of Senator Puplick's motion, in a very important qualification-one which I think Senator Haines, as well as Senator Puplick, went out of her way to stress-referred to the need to tackle tax evasion and welfare fraud, something which we all agree must be carried out. The motion stated that this must be done:
. . . in a way that does not unacceptably-
the word `unacceptably' carries a certain weight also-
trespass on civil liberties and individual privacy.

We are all aware that any effective measures to tackle tax evasion and welfare fraud run some risks of trespassing on civil liberties and individual privacy. The key element of that particular phrase is the word `unacceptably'. Of course, when one imparts meaning to a word such as `unacceptably' naturally one imparts a matter of judgment. I would be the first to recognise that. I suppose that those honourable senators on the Government side might say that what constitutes `unacceptably' is different in their eyes from the construing of that word in our eyes. I hope not. I would like again to give honourable senators on the Government side of the chamber the benefit of the doubt on this and to suggest to them that on this matter also their views as to what constitutes an unacceptable trespass on civil liberty and individual privacy might not, on more mature and considered thought than has so far gone into their campaign on this matter-particularly more so than went into the preparation of the Australia Card Bill-differ from the views on this side of the chamber.

Let us be very clear about this. In the course of the last few months since the election we have had the greatest upsurge of public feeling and protest on this question of civil liberties and individual privacy and their possible invasion by the measure proposed to be brought in by this Government than we have seen in Australia before, certainly in my recent memory. I think probably we would have to go back almost to the time of the Vietnam protest to find anything that even begins to match the protest on the Australia Card.

I turn now to the next element of Senator Puplick's motion. I think that that element is, of course, the one which, above all, needs to be brought home to Government senators. I refer to the motion's call on the Government, and honourable senators opposite as its representatives in this place, to cease their campaign of smear and misrepresentation. Senator Puplick and Senator Haines have spoken effectively and eloquently on this matter. They have spoken, I think naturally, in very general terms.

Sometimes I think that an ounce of particular example is worth a ton of generalities on matters of this kind so I would like to mention one particular example that concerns me. Honourable senators will recall the censure motion moved in the House of Representatives on 24 September this year by none other than the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I would like to come back to some of the things Mr Hawke said in that statement as they concerned me. Before I do that, I remind the Senate also of my personal explanation to the Senate on the day preceding, 23 September, when the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), in response to a dorothy dix question from an honourable senator from his own side of the House, made a number of totally unwarranted and totally unfounded allegations about me to which I immediately responded, as one does in this place, as soon as Question Time had ended. Those comments are to be found in the Senate Hansard of that day. They would have been available to people in the Prime Minister's office when they were drafting the speech that he made in the other place on the following day. Let me refer to one or two things that the Prime Minister said at that time. He said:
Senator Stone is unequivocally on the record in support of the ID card. More than that, Senator Stone has strongly urged this Prime Minister to introduce the ID card . . .
He went on:
. . . more than that, he has personally offered me his services to help in the introduction of the ID card.

These are, after all, the remarks not of some irresponsible backbencher but of the Prime Minister of this country in the course of a motion of censure of the Opposition. Mr Acting Deputy President, I ask whether you and other Government senators are aware of the basis for these remarks of the Prime Minister. Let me tell you what the basis for them is. They are based on a report in the Australian newspaper of 29 June 1985. Of course, this was the report which was referred to in this chamber on the preceding day and which I think I dealt with effectively in my personal explanation following that dorothy dix question. Nevertheless, not in the least abashed-not one wit abashed-the Prime Minister brought forward this piece of what he would presumably regard as evidence for his totally unsubstantiated campaign of smear and misrepresentation in regard to this matter.

Time will preclude my spending more time on this matter other than to say that the Prime Minister's statement is a shameful misuse of the parliamentary processes and that his subsequent repetition of these allegations on various radio programs a few days later is even more shameful. The only thing which exceeds it in its degree of shame is the conduct of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), which carried a remark of the Prime Minister along those lines on its PM program. I happened by good chance to hear that remark. I telephoned the ABC, spoke to one of its journalists at about 6.30 p.m. and recorded with him a clear rebuttal of the Prime Minister's remark, which the ABC failed to put to air. I think that one simply has to say that this is the kind of conduct which one has come to associate only too often with the ABC these days. Also, given the new management of the ABC, it is the kind of conduct which, I regret to say, we will have to become only too familiar with. It is entirely consistent with the campaign of smear and misrepresentation from the Government in regard to this matter to which, as I say, Senator Puplick's motion refers.

Let us take another example of fear and smear which took place in Question Time today and, indeed, which I think took place yesterday also. In response to a dorothy dix question the Minister for Finance got up and tried to promote a wave of fear among the pensioners of this country by attempting to suggest that what the Opposition would be proposing in this area of interest and dividend, particularly interest income, would be a form of withholding tax levied at the highest possible marginal rate of 50.25 per cent which would, of course, cut in half the interest income of these poor people. This is the sort of thing we are getting from the Government today. Again, this is not an irresponsible comment from the back bench but a statement by the Minister for Finance. I think that this again illustrates the kind of campaign of fear mongering and smear that we are-I genuinely regret to say-becoming unduly accustomed to find coming from that side of the chamber.

The final part of Senator Puplick's motion of course notes that the `campaign of smear and misrepresentation' is directed by the Government `against opponents of the discredited Australia Card legislation'. The public opinion polls revealed, I think, that more than half the population are strongly opposed to this now defeated legislation. All these people are being vilified by the Government in its campaign of smear and misrepresentation. These are all the strange bedfellows to whom the Prime Minister referred some weeks ago when he went out of his way, among other things, to belittle an honourable man, Mr Ewart Smith, and none other than Mr Ben Lexcen, whose name, I might say, will live a lot longer in the annals of this country than that of the man belittling him. There is not the slightest doubt that the Government should be ashamed of itself for engaging in this campaign.

I close these remarks by recalling that during the last election campaign, at which time I was writing each week a column in the Melbourne Herald and the Sydney Morning Herald, I said, dismayed as I was at that time by the way the Government was conducting the election campaign, that the best election slogan this country had seen in some time was the 1980 slogan of the Australian Labor Party, `Raise the Standard'. I can only deplore the extent to which that slogan, which was put forward, not by the present Prime Minister, but by the then Leader of the Opposition, Bill Hayden, has been departed from by the Government and the extent to which the standard which led to the selection of that slogan has been departed from. Today this is producing the kind of campaign of fear, smear and misrepresentation on this matter which is coming from the Government side.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are faced today with a first from Senator Puplick: the first occasion on which he has gratuitously and frivolously wasted the time of this chamber by putting such a motion before us. The motion has been read on a number of occasions-presumably to fill in time-by people such as Senator Stone. I guess it will not hurt if I refresh people's memories again. The motion is:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to tackle tax evasion and welfare fraud in a way that does not unacceptably trespass on civil liberties and individual privacy and for it to cease its campaign of smear and misrepresentation against opponents of the discredited Australia Card legislation.

In short, Senator Puplick is saying in this motion that, first, we must do something about tax evasion and social welfare fraud and, second, we must not say nasty things about people like Senator Puplick or tax cheats. In broad summary, that is all Senator Puplick has been saying; that he is intending to waste the time of this chamber. I suppose that he is entitled to his moment of glory, like a faded ballerina. It is a moment of glory occasioned by, on the whole, a less than brilliant discovery that a great deal of legislation-not just the Australia Card Bill-can be defeated by refusing to pass the accompanying regulations. It did not take a genius to find that out.

It does not matter to Senator Puplick and other honourable senators opposite that a special select committee discussed this issue, met around Australia, listened to public opinion, read countless thousands of pages of information about it and heard overseas witnesses. It does not matter that a government went to the people on a double dissolution on this basis and was returned with an increased majority. It does not matter that the Liberal Party of Australia in particular, during that campaign, at no stage attempted to raise the issue of the Australia Card because it was frightened of defeat as a result of people seeing the arguments behind the Government's move in this area. It does not matter that all those things have occurred: Senator Puplick is still prepared to savour his moment of glory. He has had that. Suddenly he has realised that public opinion is not as monolithic as he imagines. People have said, `That is fine. You have knocked off the Australia Card by sleight of hand. That is very good. You have done that and it shows how clever you are. What are you going to do now about tax evasion? What are you going to do about social welfare cheating?'.

The people are asking members of the Opposition where they stand and where is their alternative proposal. It does not matter to those opposite that a supposedly little known, retired public servant had to find the smart way to beat the Australia Card Bill, that he had to do the work that they should have done. There is an element of farce in the way the solution was discovered. It was like some legislative aviary let loose. At 4.30 in the morning, according to Mr Ewart Smith, he was awoken by magpies. At 7.30 a.m., when he was shaving, he got a phone call from Senator Stone. I must say that if I got a 7.30 a.m. phone call from Senator Stone that would encourage me to cut myself if I were shaving. After an hour and a half of being berated by Senator Stone at that hour of the morning, Mr Smith decided to do something about the legislation and he told Senator Stone what sort of trick he could pull later in the day. I understand that Mr Ewart Smith later got a letter from a well-wisher congratulating him on thinking up this brilliant idea to defeat the Australia Card through trickery. It said something like, `May the birds sing always in your garden'.

The bird analogy keeps coming up all the time but if we look at what could happen as a result of the Australia Card being dismissed in this way, we could say that the only birds that will be singing around the place are the legal eagles and the accountants protecting the people involved in massive tax evasion and fraud. But Senator Puplick got a bit of a victory out of this matter. Senator Stone got a bit of a victory; it was a wonderful entry into politics. But this was not a victory for a number of people. It was a victory for tax cheats, the people who live off pay as you earn taxpayers and can afford to hire accountants and lawyers to fudge, rearrange their companies and ensure that no tax is paid. I know that some of the richest people in this country proudly boast--

TALK.START.PARA: —Holmes a Court.

—No, I was not including the honourable senator. Those people proudly boast that they have not paid tax for up to 15, and in one case 25, years. They have not paid a single dollar of tax because they use all sorts of mechanisms to evade their responsibilities. They can do that because we do not have something like the Australia Card to make it easy for the authorities that are out to cut out tax evasion, to really move in and do the job properly.

SPEECH.PARA: The defeat of the Australia Card is also a victory for drug pedlars and pornographers-people who have made millions of dollars and been busy year after year suborning and undermining law enforcement authorities. Some honourable senators on the other side can smile but if they believe that crime in this country is not increasing, they should say so now. Having read the Costigan report, the reports on Nugan Hand, the McCabe-Lafranchi report and all the other reports, I believe that we are at the crossroads on what we do about tax evasion and crime.

What are those opposite doing? They are doing nothing. They walk into this place with what they believe to be a clear conscience and rejoice positively in the idea that something like the Australia Card, which will stop this sort of problem and help people to follow the money trail, has been knocked over. Will those opposite rejoice when they look at their children and the next generation and consider the type of society they will grow up in? They should work out just what they did and what part they played in making sure that the balance was tipped in favour of criminals and against law enforcement authorities. Those opposite should think about what they did this day, last week and the week before in making sure that law enforcement authorities cannot do their job. Those opposite have done their bit to tie those authorities' hands behind their backs. If those opposite want to protect the legal profession and the army of accountants involved in tax avoidance, that is fine but they should not expect anyone on this side of the chamber to support them.

Many people have been genuinely concerned about the Australia Card in terms of its effect on civil liberties. As a government, we have not abused people about that. We have said, `Yes, we understand your concerns about civil liberties. We have brought in the Data Protection Agency. We will be bringing in special legislation to protect privacy. We are not dropping that simply because the Australia Card has gone down the chute'. Special editorials in three major newspapers, the Australian, the Age and the Canberra Times, have said, `That is fine. The Australia Card has gone down the chute, but what is the Opposition going to do about all the issues raised?'. As an example, I will quote from the Canberra Times:
At the weekend, Mr Howard foreshadowed the establishment of an Opposition task force to look at ways of cutting down on tax avoidance and fraud . . .

Finally, two years later, the penny has dropped with Mr Howard. He was a Treasurer for I do not know how many years under his own Government when massive tax evasion and fraud was going on. The Canberra Times continued:

. . . and this will include having `a look at the tax number'. Surely, during the long period that the Australia Card legislation was before the Parliament, the Opposition had plenty of time to get its thoughts together. This is an example of the attitude that got it into trouble during the election campaign, an inability to devise policies when they are needed.
This is from a man who was the Treasurer of this country at a time when tax evasion was rampant and the crooks got their start in a way that enabled them to go on to bigger and better things.

It is especially worrying as well when we look at the whole question of what has happened to the credibility of this chamber, the Parliament and the whole process of Senate select committees-an area that particularly concerns me. That was a good Select Committee and most people on it put in time, effort and thought. They were prepared to look at all the options and, at the end of the day, the majority came down 5 : 3 in favour of an upgraded, improved tax file number system. A minority, which included me, wanted to go for an Australia Card with photograph in an attempt to solve basically the same problems of tax evasion and social welfare fraud. That is fine. We spent time on it, we wrote the report-all of us-and we brought it into the chamber to be debated. The Government based legislation on one section of the report.

Now, at the end of the day, when people are expected to stand up and be counted on what they were prepared to put into the report, where do we find the four Opposition members of the Committee-Senator Puplick, Senator Haines, Mr Porter and Mr Blunt? We find them reneging totally on the one major recommendation that they made as an alternative to the Government's Australia Card proposal.

What are we to think of the value of select committees spending hundreds of thousands of dollars of taxpayers' money? What are we to think of the people who came before that Committee and who gave it their time, effort and thought? We said to them, `Yes, yes, we will listen to you and bring down recommendations' but then the Liberals and the Nationals reneged on everything that they put into the report, bar a few minor matters. What are people in Australia to think about that? Does it not make a mockery of the much vaunted Senate select committee system?

How can Senator Haines talk in this place about the Senate's right to reject legislation, the Senate's right to be a House of review and, by implication, the Senate's right to examine issues through select committees? How can she do that when she is prepared to go on a select committee, make recommendations and then renege on them within one year? What will people think about all of us if such things continue? I am reminded by Senator Puplick's general use of literary analogies of the lobster quadrille in Alice in Wonderland: `Will you, won't you, will you, won't you, will you join the dance?'. That is Senator Haines. I would hate to dance the tango with the Democrats-one would be extremely lonely because one would be dancing on one's own. They have moved totally away from their recommendations.

Senator Puplick is embarrassed and that is why we have this motion today. He is embarrassed because his small `l' liberal viewpoint about beating tax evaders-I do not think that he is weak about that-through an upgraded tax file number system or an Australia Card system has been made a mockery of on the other side of the House. He knows that he has been beaten in his own Party room. He knows that the small `l' liberals have been beaten by those who have been chosen to represent the Liberal Party in this place by the tax dodgers and the big money people who do not want any major changes to tax legislation or the effectiveness of attempts to beat tax evasion. That is why this motion is here today and that is why he is pleading with us not to berate him, smear him or attack him because he only did his job. Unfortunately, he did not do his job well enough. He raised issues, some in a significant way and some in ways that have benefited the debate, but he has been beaten in his Party room and he is incredibly embarrassed about it. He has to come in here and lead the debate. Where are all his supporters? Like Senator Stone, they have left the chamber. Nobody is here to support him.

At the end of the day, the Australia Card has gone down the chute. The question now is: What is this chamber going to do about the alternative? What is this chamber going to do about making sure that this society gets back on an even keel again and that the balance is not tipped in favour of those who consider that they do not have to pay tax and can ride on the backs of the pay as you earn taxpayers, or those who suborn law enforcement authorities or politicians simply because they have the money? The balance has to be tipped back the other way. All right, the Opposition does not want the Australia Card. What does it want? Does it want something that will effectively beat the tax evaders and criminals in this community, or does it want to sit on its backside and allow this society to drift into a situation in which, in the long run, the criminals will be able to walk away and lie safely in bed at night saying, `We have beaten them'? I oppose this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was worth having Senator Aulich enter the debate because he is a strong reminder of why it was worth bringing forward the motion. He carried on, as one would have expected from his contribution to earlier debates, with the nonsense that this motion is intended to counter. We had from Senator Aulich the statement that the defeat of the card was a victory for tax cheats, drug dealers and pornographers. I am interested that he brought pornography in, because that is a new twist. I am happy to stand in the company of that great range of people who have opposed the card, including Mr Frank Costigan, QC, who, in his comments, made it clear that he thought that the Australia Card was certainly not the way to go. There can be no person more committed to the fighting of organised crime in this country than Mr Costigan. I am proud to stand in the company of the Anglican Bishop of Perth, the Reverend Michael Challen, the Catholic Social Welfare Commission--
—And tax cheats.

—I hear Senator Aulich muttering, `Tax cheats'. Does he think these people are tax cheats? A great range of people, including many trade unionists, academics, lawyers, and Labor lawyers and politicians when they have not been bound by Caucus, have given us the clear statement that they accept the reasons why the majority of an all-party parliamentary committee rejected the idea of an Australia Card.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a common abhorrence in this chamber of tax and welfare fraud and it is a McCarthyist smear which is being undertaken by the Government to accuse those who have opposed the Australia Card of being the friends of tax cheats and welfare frauds. The reality is that the record of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) in these matters is spotty, while the record of the Liberal Party of Australia is nothing like that which is suggested in this place time and time again by Labor speakers. I take the opportunity in this debate to refer both to the ALP record and to the Liberal record, which belie the tactics being used by the Government in this debate.

With respect to the now Government's record on welfare fraud, I can only say that, as Minister for Social Security in the previous Government, I could be quite certain that any attempt to deal with welfare fraud would be resisted by the Labor Party on the grounds that we were seeking to grind the faces of the poor. Let us take a now uncontentious change to welfare law-the proposition that the Government is now advancing that there should be a strong attempt to recover maintenance from non-supporting parents. Senator Reynolds, the Minister at the table, went public and accused me of attacking the poor when I advocated that in about September 1985 on behalf of the Opposition, but was a little surprised when her Minister, Mr Brian Howe, advocated exactly the same measure in the same week. It is now the policy that the Minister at the table is bound to support. I remind her that she was very quick to score a cheap political point at that time on an issue which the Opposition had considered very carefully-an issue on which the people of Australia would, I believe, demand action, which the Government is now very belatedly promising to deliver.

With respect to the Government's approach to taxation, the record shows a totally different picture from the one which speakers in this debate and Ministers during Question Time and at other times have tried to paint. We find that in 1982 the present Treasurer, Mr Keating, admitted that the dreadful spate of artificial tax avoidance schemes that afflicted this country had started under the Whitlam Government. On 10 September 1982 he stated:
When we were in Government between '73 and '75 the tax avoidance industry started to move into sophisticated contrived schemes. Schemes that were artificial devices to avoid tax.

Senator Chris Puplick has already pointed out in this debate that the early action of Labor when it came into government on this occasion was described by Mr Gittins in very uncomplimentary terms. But the reality is that this country had an absolute disease of artificial tax avoidance. It started under the Whitlam Government. I do not blame the Whitlam Government for that; it was not created by that Government, but that is when it started. The true record is that there was a succession of attacks on that problem under the Liberal Government. By the start of 1982 the Fraser Government had introduced over 22 pieces of legislation, closing down over 50 tax avoidance schemes.

The reality is that in the years from 1976 to 1982 there was a continuous record of legislation being passed by the Parliament which struck down tax avoidance schemes. The final pieces of legislation which were critical to the solution of the problem were passed by the Fraser Government and have not needed to be changed by this Government. The Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act was passed in December 1980. It prospectively created a criminal offence for bottom of the harbour transactions. We replaced that section of the Income Tax Assessment Act which, under High Court rulings, had proved not to strike down artificial tax avoidance schemes, with a new part IVa. That is why in 1984 the then Finance Minister of the Hawke Government, Mr John Dawkins-when he was not trying to engage in a Goebbels exercise of the sort that we are seeing in Australia today-was prepared, on 17 April 1984, to say that the matter of tax avoidance had been put behind us. Mr Dawkins said that because it is true, and this Government's legislative record proves that it is true. The Government has not had to introduce legislation to strike down artificial tax avoidance schemes because those schemes are being dealt with under part IVa of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which was introduced by the Fraser Government.

The only legislation which has been introduced and resisted by the Opposition is legislation which sought to impose new, additional, retrospective tax liability on people who had already been forced to pay their taxes retrospectively under Fraser Government legislation. That is the only example that can be pointed to by the Australian Labor Party of legislation which was frustrated by the Opposition in conjunction with the Australian Democrats. We make no apology for doing that because we believe that it was correct in principle and that the Government's legislation was excessively punitive and was not justified.

It is the gravamen of my remarks that there was an extremely significant tax avoidance problem and, indeed, a tax avoidance industry in this country. The legislative record of the Fraser Government was such as to bring that artificial tax avoidance industry to an end. I refer further to the figures of the Commissioner of Taxation. One can see that the deduction of claims involving tax avoidance peaked in 1977-78 and fell very rapidly thereafter. That occurred because of Fraser Government legislation.

A succession of lies is being put forward in the debate, suggesting that the Opposition has been opposing the Government's attempts to get rid of artificial tax avoidance schemes, and that is clearly not true--

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—I do not have time in this debate to respond to Senator Peter Cook who, as usual, tries to make cheap political points. The reality is that the history of tax avoidance in this country is such that a former Minister for Finance of the Hawke Government was able to say that the question of tax avoidance had been put behind us. That was long before any new legislative initiatives of this Government could be pointed to as bringing that about. The Liberal Party of Australia has a record of continuous legislative action in the face of an epidemic of artificial tax avoidance-action which was ultimately successful in striking it out of Australian society.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of social security fraud, I would like to say, as an ex-Minister for Social Security, that any action I took to crack down on welfare fraud was undertaken under siege from the Labor Party. The Labor Party automatically labelled any attempts to improve the tightness of the welfare system and to prevent fraud as action which was against the poor. Like earlier speakers in this debate, I note with approval the fact that the Government, under the pressure of being in government, has had to change its attitude. Before the last election, the Treasurer proudly said that thousands of people were being struck off the unemployment benefit rolls and $100m was being saved. But the reality is that we sought to introduce work for the dole on a trial basis in 1982 on the basis that that was one of the realistic and non-punitive ways available to crack down on welfare fraud.

TALK.START.PARA: —What's it got to do with social security fraud?

—Everything, because it is impossible to defraud unemployment benefits if one has to turn up and perform some community obligation and put in time. The present Government discontinued that trial project. It has refused to pick up that very worthwhile effort to do away with one of the major areas of welfare fraud in this country; that is, the abuse of the unemployment benefit.

SPEECH.PARA: With respect to the second largest area of abuse-the question of maintenance and abuse of the supporting parent's benefit-the Government has for 4 1/2 years postponed action to recover moneys from parents who are not supporting their children in favour of leaving that obligation in the hands of taxpayers. It is only after 4 1/2 years of government that it has moved to adopt our policy. We have adopted completely consistent attitudes in this matter. Senator Puplick in this debate has already read into the record the statement which was made by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) today with respect to our stance on these matters.

There are three fundamental principles that we stand by, and we have stood by them over the last three years in a very consistent way. We have said that we will subject anything which is done in this field to three tests. It must be demonstrated actually to meet the problems of tax fraud and welfare cheating. In other words, we will not support measures which are not demonstrated to be effective. Secondly, measures must be shown to be cost-effective. We will not accept that one can spend a billion dollars to save $100m. We expect there to be some relationship between what is imposed and the cost of what is being imposed. Finally, and most importantly, we have always said that we will support only those measures which do not intrude unnecessarily on personal privacy and individual civil liberties.

In all the dishonest debate which takes place on this card, the Labor Party continually tries to fudge the fact that when it initially proposed a measure of this kind we did not oppose it on a knee-jerk basis. We did not immediately say, without examining the proposition, `We are opposed to this'; we said we would apply those three tests. We would want to see whether what the Government was doing was effective; we would want to see whether it was cost-effective; and we would want to see whether civil liberties were protected.

The simple reality is that we subjected the Government's proposal to a most careful examination at the parliamentary level, as we have subjected it to the most careful examination at the party level. The reality is that the measure failed to pass the test at the parliament level when an all-party committee recommended against it. The further reality is that we are simply taking the position that, now that the public of Australia has followed that parliamentary inquiry and come to the realisation that the identity card is not an acceptable solution, we will not see that unacceptable solution foisted on the Australian people under the guise of some very extended use of the tax file number. We have in no way set our face against the more effective use of the tax file number and, again, Mr Howard's statement makes that clear. He said:

. . . we will support moves to upgrade the degree of integrity of the tax file number system. This is essential to ensure that people do not abuse the system by, for example, having more than one tax file number.

In addition, we will favourably consider any proposals designed to improve the use of tax file numbers for proper taxation and welfare purposes such as those already provided for the Income Tax Assessment Act. Any such proposals will be judged against our three stated criteria.
He continued:
. . . we will vigorously oppose any attempt to turn the tax file number system into a de facto Australia Card system.

We make no apology for that. It is common knowledge in this Parliament and in the community that if a strict Caucus system did not apply to the Australian Labor Party, many members of the Labor Party would support us in our stand both on the identity card and on any proposed use of the tax file number which turns it into a de facto card.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you support employer notification? No, you will not.

—I reject such an accusation which is a speciality of Senator Walsh, who has just come into the chamber. Senator Walsh should not require the Opposition to answer questions about issues on which the Government itself has not made up its mind. This Government has lamentably failed to bring forward to this point any alternative proposals for Opposition and public consideration. It is a farce to have Ministers challenging the Opposition to declare its position on proposals which have not been defined by the Government, with all of the resources of government. There is much that is farcical about the conduct of political and parliamentary life in this country but, on behalf of the Opposition, I commend this motion because we believe that the real issues are being obfuscated by the Government. There is an attempt, by lie and smear, to create confusion in the public mind. We stand by our principles. We refuse to be bullied into accepting proposals which are not in the national interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Insofar as the matter of urgency refers to the need to tackle tax evasion and welfare fraud, of course it is a matter of urgency. The Opposition is more interested in bringing forward debating points than in producing an alternative to what the Government has done in terms of tackling tax evasion and looking after welfare fraud. No doubt a legitimate claim is made by many who oppose the Australia Card that it transgresses civil liberties. One could accept the Opposition on that. However, the Opposition said that it was opposed to the bottom of the harbour legislation because it was retrospective in its operation. That is a point of law which, again, can be accepted. But when one starts putting these things together one's suspicions rise. It was not just the Australia Card or the bottom of the harbour legislation which the Opposition opposed. It also opposed the disallowance of tax deductible entertainment expenses, the capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax and the closing of loopholes in tax legislation which was confirmed by the Supreme Court of Queensland last year.

SPEECH.PARA: Everybody admits that there is tax fraud and that it is a matter of urgency. Why is it that the Opposition is opposed to every proposition that this Government puts forward to crack down on tax fraud? It would be fair enough if the Opposition opposed only one of the Government's measures, but a pattern has been formed. When the Government asks, legitimately, what that is all about, no matter what the Opposition says, the Government sees that the effect of the Opposition's actions in this chamber and in the other place is to allow people who otherwise would have to pay tax to avoid doing so. The effect of the Opposition's approach over the years has been that a great number of people who, morally at least-the Opposition agrees that, morally at least, they should pay tax-should have paid a substantial amount of tax, have not done so and the rest of us have had to pay extra tax.

The people who are struggling on an average weekly wage, sending their children to school, paying off a mortgage and struggling to make ends meet and to bring up their family in a decent way, over the years have had to pay an incredible amount of tax which they would not otherwise have had to pay. This Government has moved in various ways to stop that, to give the ordinary person in the street a chance to make a decent living. Those people have had imposed on them a frightening and crippling burden of taxation while others have been able to rort the system. They have been able to buy speedboats, build houses on lake shores, take overseas trips and send their children to the most luxurious of schools. Those people do not pay tax whereas others do. Yet, when the Government says that that is a bit hard and that the system is a little unfair, what is the Opposition's response? Does it say, `Yes, you are right; we will try to formulate an alternative measure'? No, it says, `You are very nasty; you are a naughty lot of boys and girls because you've used nasty language to us'.

The reality is, and it is agreed, that through the 1970s and 1980s there has been a rorting of the tax system. Crippling burdens of tax have been imposed on pay as you earn taxpayers and on those on whom it should not have been placed. As soon as this Government gets a little angry and says that we ought to do something about it, the Opposition does not say, `We will try to redress that imbalance'. Instead, it comes in here and says, `You've been naughty; you've been like Goebbels; you've insulted us'. That is the crime involved in this. The crime is not that the Government has tried to protect the small taxpayer; the crime is that the Government has said nasty things to the Opposition. Senator Stone in effect made a personal explanation. Most of his speech was devoted to some statement that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made. Senator Stone said that it was dreadful that the Prime Minister went about developing treaties overseas, that he went about trying to save the tax system and building up industry. Senator Stone said that the Prime Minister looked at those things instead of apologising to Senator Stone. This I gather from reading Senator Stone's speech in this place.

Senator Stone went on for minutes in his speech developing that theme and saying how dreadfully he had been insulted. It is extraordinary that, in a chamber in which politics are conducted and in which political campaigns are conducted, nasty and robust things have been said! What does the Opposition say at its first opportunity when a matter of urgency is debated? It says, `You've been very nasty and naughty to us; isn't this a dreadful thing? The great matter of urgency is the insult that the Labor Party has placed upon us'. The tax rorts do not matter. The Opposition says, `What about the social security people? You haven't ground them down enough. When we were in government, we used to grind them down properly'. Indeed, it did grind them down. We can remember the Greek conspiracy case. How many convictions ensued? Absolutely none. How many people were insulted and ground down by this merciful system about which Senator Chaney tells us? Hundreds!

TALK.START.PARA: —It cost about $10m.

—It cost $10m, all for nought. It was a dreadful mistake. Not only was it a most outrageous injustice but also it cost the Commonwealth $10m of the tax which should have been paid by the people which the Opposition refused to pursue.
—Yet they claim they are concerned about civil liberties.

—Yes; they pursued these people overseas. Opposition members pursued doctors. They tilted at windmills and chased shibboleths. They made no analysis of the situation and did not look at the realities. The situation still continues. The motion states:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to tackle tax evasion and welfare fraud in a way-
in what way; what is specific about this?-
that does not unacceptably trespass on civil liberties . . .

Have we had one suggestion from this so-called Opposition, which is so outraged by this, of what it means by an unacceptable trespass? The only thing it has given specific evidence about as to its being unacceptable is the insult apparently done to Senator Stone.

I am sure that Senator Stone is a very nice man and a very brilliant person, but I hardly think that the time of the Senate and the country should be taken up-especially when he has set aside, as a result of all this, people who would otherwise have made their maiden speeches-for the purposes of a senator, on a broadcast day, making a personal explanation of how he was in some way offended by the Prime Minister because the Prime Minister said something in the thrust of debate. Every time somebody makes a remark across the chamber, such as one of those brilliant remarks that Senator Puplick makes, are we to get Senator Coates, for example, bringing on a matter of public importance the next day to say, `Yesterday Senator Puplick said this awfully nasty thing to me, and it is outrageous'? If somebody says, `What about the big issues of the country?', would Senator Coates be the sort of person to say, `That is the big issue. The big issue is my offended pride'?

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you sound as though you mean it?

—I hope Senator Stone did not mean what he said, Senator Walters-but I think he did. I think he genuinely thought that the Senate's time should be taken up in an explanation concerning the great Senator Stone. I do not deny for one minute that he is a great Senator Stone-like we are all great senators. But really, is this the sort of thing we ought to be spending time on? Should we not be, in effect, talking about the real issues, one of which is how we are to get people to pay their proper tax?

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators should look at the example of what we have done in the field of so-called social security fraud. This is what the Opposition wants us to intensify and extend. The Government has adopted a three-pronged anti-fraud strategy. It has not gone chasing innocent Greeks or innocent doctors. It has tightened social security administration and people on unemployment benefit must now report fortnightly to a social security office. For a person who is genuinely unemployed, that is a big imposition. Nevertheless, the Opposition says, `No, we must go further than that'. I suppose it wants to put people on social security in thumbscrews.

In talking about the way the Opposition goes about looking after social security fraud, I have been reminded of something by that kind hearted and generous spirited man Senator Walsh, who adorns this chamber again and again with the generosity of his spirit. He has pointed out to me that in 1981 the razor gang, under the coalition, said, `We have got to save some money'. The coalition then said, `People who are unemployed can get unemployment benefits without registering with the Commonwealth Employment Service. They can just go and fill in a piece of paper and claim unemployment benefits'. There was then none of this business that the Opposition now proclaims: that people must go out and work for the dole.

Senator Puplick said that people should work for the dole. Senator Puplick is someone for whom I have the highest admiration, and therefore I did not think that he would go back to that old, worn chestnut of people having to work for the dole. That presupposes, of course, that there is work for people on the dole to do.

I see that Senator Parer is in the chamber. He used to be a member of the mining industry, which has slashed jobs. Senator Puplick might ask Senator Parer how many jobs he could provide. But he just makes this wild and vague statement. He provides no evidence that there is work available or that there is any sort of program to cure this problem. That is the disappointing thing about it.

There are good minds on the Opposition side of the chamber. Senator Stone is one. I see the Deputy Whip, Senator Puplick and Senator Parer. None of them-no doubt they planned this before they came in-was able to produce one tittle of evidence, one suggestion as to how they would cure the tax rorts that go on. There is a terribly negative approach to matters. That is why they are in opposition.

The one thing that the Opposition poured out during the election campaign was that it was going to reduce tax. It is a real witches' cauldron. Macbeth would consult those opposite. The witches' cauldron is held over there. We can see the big cauldron over there on the red chairs. They stir it there and they put in a bit of an insult here and a bit of an idea there. Nothing is together.

I was reading the Australian Financial Review of yesterday-6 October 1987. There is a photograph of that outstanding man called Mr Tuckey-looking very grim and extremely ministerial. The article states:
The Federal Opposition has switched its cautious support for the tax file number alternative to the ID card to rejection.
