The article talks about how Opposition members change their minds from time to time. That was on page 5. On page 4, dead opposite, was the significant heading, `Libs act to woo quality candidates'. I reckon that really answers it all.

TALK.START.PARA: —They could certainly do with them.

—Yes. I think that that is the best thing those opposite can do here-get off and get these quality candidates that they are going to woo, as it says on page 4 of the Financial Review, and come back here with a good suggestion. I can guarantee this: led by Senator Walsh, this very reasonable man, we will adopt certain policies if those opposite tell us about them. That is the best thing that they have done-`Libs act to woo quality candidates'. Get into it!

SPEECH.PARA: The only thing I should say is that having looked at that edition of the Financial Review, I then looked at the next day's headline, which was `Libs ease up on tax file number'. One thing about coming from Melbourne is that one is able to cope with the Opposition up here-because the weather there changes four times in a day. As we read through the papers and hear the Opposition propositions put, we find that the policies of the Liberal Party change in the same way. We can cope with the Liberals down there. That probably makes Victoria the great intellectual State of the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Mr Deputy President, there are only one or two things that need to be responded to in terms of points which Senators Ryan, Aulich and Cooney have made in this debate. Senator Ryan has attempted to say that no action was taken by the Opposition to deal with the question of taxation fraud. That is simply untrue, and the evidence which has been put down during today's debate about the 22 pieces of legislation introduced by the previous Government, and in particular the impact of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act 1980 and part IVa of the Income Tax Assessment Act, simply gives the lie to that.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Aulich attempted to misrepresent the recommendations of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card in relation to the use of the tax file number. I will read the first two:

That the use of the tax file number be extended to cover all the financial transactions proposed in the Government submission for use of the Australia Card number by the Australian Taxation Office, as well as for social security purposes.
That all other Departments ie. other than the Australian Taxation Office and Department of Social Security be barred from access to and use of the tax file number.

As Senator Haines said in her speech, an upgraded tax file number system does not mean an unlimited tax file number system. Senator Aulich was at pains to say something about the issue of crime and why something had not been done about it by the Opposition. He fails to address the question of why his Government will not give the National Crime Authority the teeth that it needs to get on with the job in question, why his Government will not act upon all the recommendations of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, and why his Government will not take action upon the reports which it has had from the Australian Federal Police-which reports, indeed, it is intent upon suppressing.

Finally, Senator Cooney comes into the debate. If we were able to believe that he, Senator McKiernan and Senator Collins were heart- broken at the loss of the Australia Card, then perhaps we would take it seriously. But the degree to which they were heartbroken over the loss of the Australia Card was reflected only by the extent-no names, no pack drill-of the number of Labor senators opposite who were offering to shout drinks in the bar on the day on which the thing went down the tubes. Here he is, coming along saying, `Why is that? I see a pattern, a conspiracy'. He looks into the witches' cauldron and sees the pattern of conspiracy. The only thing he cannot see in the witches' cauldron is the pattern of conspiracy about negative gearing, about scraping the bottom of the barrel, if not the bottom of the cauldron, with claims of getting rid of negative gearing, which his own Treasurer scrapped fairly quickly.

He put the system of government upon its head by saying that the responsibility rests with the Opposition to bring forward the methodology by which welfare fraud and tax cheating are to be eliminated. I say to Senator Cooney: That is the Government's job; that is your responsibility, not ours. We have laid down the tests that will be applied to any piece of legislation or any administrative action that the Government brings forward. We challenge the Government to get on with the job and do something. Instead of just grinning around the place at every possible opportunity about the defeat of its own piece of legislation, it should look at the faces of those members of the Labor Party who hold marginal seats and who are as heartbroken as Senator Cooney, Senator McKiernan and Senator Collins were about the Australia Card rightfully being consigned to the dust heap where it properly belongs.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Puplick's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: REVIEW OF SYSTEMS FOR DEALING WITH FRAUD ON THE COMMONWEALTH

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This paper, which was made available to honourable senators this morning, is a considerable document of some 200 pages. In speaking to it for a few moments, it is possible that we will not do justice to the work that went into it or the effort that has been put into it by very senior officers of the Commonwealth. I wish to address myself to a narrow area which has been of concern to me over the years and which remains of concern to me. The document appears to be something of a curate's egg: it appears to contain some quite good analysis but really it seems to opt out of some of the problems that have been of concern to me.

My interests lay in the activities of the Health Insurance Commission. During the time that I was Minister for Health and previously when I had an interest in health matters, I was concerned about the difficulty that we faced in ensuring proper and prompt investigation of matters which appeared to involve fraud upon the Health Insurance Commission. Before I became a member of this place, I was a member of a profession which is an honourable profession. Most of its members are honest and operate in a system that requires honesty as the keystone of its operation. I refer to the system of rebates for medical services based on a fee for service system. It involves some honesty on the part of the provider, and most providers are scrupulously honest. But it is in our interests that anyone who is not honest, who is practising fraud, be detected and that it be acted upon quickly.

I became aware-other senators will have had this experience-that the Australian Federal Police had the conduct of every investigation of fraud or overservicing when it got to a certain stage. It was quite apparent to me that the Australian Federal Police lacked the capacity either to investigate or to act upon the cases sent to them. Certainly, they lacked the capacity to do so with any dispatch or any promptness.

TALK.START.PARA: —They lacked the resources.

—This is part of the problem. At one stage when Mr Fraser was the Prime Minister we actually approached him-a number of the then backbenchers-and he agreed to provide extra resources for exactly that reason; the work which the Australian Federal Police was doing in relation to fraud upon the Health Insurance Commission was very cost effective. The deterrent effect of a successful prosecution or successful investigation was widely known.

SPEECH.PARA: This report identifies that in 1984-85 some 22,224 matters involving fraud were referred to the Australian Federal Police for investigation, and only a percentage of those would have been in relation to the Health Insurance Commission. It is quite clearly impossible for the Australian Federal Police to deal with and to process promptly that number of matters. This report recommends that many of those investigations be referred back to the operating line agency for different administrative procedures and for resolution. Some of those suggestions are obviously sensible but the report misses one point and that is that many of the matters referred to the Australian Federal Police involved small amounts. That did not mean that the matters themselves were small. I will give an example. A doctor may be undertaking a whole range of consultations, each of them for a small amount of money-each process and each procedure for $10, $20 or $30. If we became aware that in such a case there was a need to investigate, if that investigation were carried out and if interviews were held they might throw up only three or four instances of fraud, each involving $50. But they may demonstrate a wider and much larger pattern of misbehaviour.

My concern is that until we realise that it is absolutely essential that the Commonwealth can detect, punish and make examples of those who conduct fraud we will not be protecting the public, protecting ourselves, protecting the public revenue or giving a capacity to use our resources for the things we wish to use them for. I support some of the administrative reforms which have been recommended but I do not find from the tone of this report a proper appreciation of the needs of the Australian Federal Police, the importance of detecting fraud or the need to identify that we have been unable to do so for far too long.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend this report to honourable senators. It really should be read because its recommendations are highly topical. I quote from page 17 of the report to give a taste of the background to it:

SPEECH.PARA: In the early 1980s, reports of various commissions of inquiry revealed a largely unsuspected and disturbing picture of major criminal activity in modern Australian society. Not the least disturbing part of this was a burgeoning tax evasion industry, including `bottom of the harbour' and other tax schemes, highlighted by the 1982 McCabe-Lafranchi Report and in a number of Costigan Royal Commission Reports. Mr Costigan also suggested the involvement of the Federal Ship Painters and Dockers Union in large-scale social security fraud.
Also contained in the report is what I believe to be a classic definition of fraud. The report quotes Jonathan Swift's Gulliver's Travels. It reads:

They look upon fraud as a greater crime than theft, for they allege that care and vigilance with a very common understanding may preserve a man's goods from thieves. But honesty hath no defence against superior cunning and since it is necessary that there should be a perpetual intercourse of buying and selling, dealing upon credit, where fraud is permitted or connived at, or hath no law to punish it, the honest dealer is always undone and the knave gets the advantage.
Honourable senators should refer to some of the recommendations of this report. I quote from page 10. Recommendation 14 reads:
That the Attorney-General, at the next meeting of the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities:

urge all States and the Northern Territory to expedite current programs to computerise corporate affairs records and develop an analytical capacity to facilitate data gathering for the purpose of investigations and legal proceedings;

seek agreement that such records and analytical capacity be made available on-line to the AFP, the DPP, the AGS, the ATO, the ATS, the ACS, the Official Trustee in Bankruptcy, and to other agencies as appropriate.
Recommendation 15 reads:
That the Attorney-General, at the next meeting of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General:

urge all States and the Northern Territory to introduce or to expedite programs to computerise land titles records and to develop an analytical capacity to facilitate data gathering for the purpose of investigations and legal proceedings; and
seek agreement that such records and analytical capacity be made available on-line to the AFP, the DPP, the AGS, the ATO, the Official Trustee in Bankruptcy, and to other agencies as appropriate.
I am sure the topicality of recommendations 23, 24 and 25 will not be lost on honourable senators. I quote from recommendation 23:

That, for a trial period of one year, agencies which believe their efforts to recover moneys owed to the Commonwealth are hampered by lack of access to locator information possessed by other agencies record relevant details and provide them to the Department of Finance for an assessment as to what action may be required including, if necessary, the need for a submission to Cabinet by the end of financial year . . .
Recommendation 24 reads:

That, in order to reduce the incidence and maximise the detection of financial loss, and where it is consistent with the terms of present legislation, agencies adopt co-operative policies in providing information to other agencies and, in particular, where it is cost-effective, consider matching of information relevant to identifying instances of fraud.
Recommendation 25 reads:

That, to meet the immediate needs of the AFP, the DPP and the NCA for adequate access to information from the ATO, the HIC, the DSS and the ACS (the disclosing agencies) for law enforcement, prosecution or civil remedy purposes, the Attorney-General bring forward as soon as possible a proposal for legislation which would override secrecy provisions otherwise applicable . . .
So it goes on. I quote from recommendation 26:

That the present review of secrecy provisions by the Attorney-General's Department be completed within twelve months of the date of acceptance of this recommendation, that it place particular emphasis on the removal of unnecessary constraints upon the flow of information between agencies in relation to fraud, and that upon conclusion of the review the Attorney- General report to Cabinet recommending any desirable changes to legislation.

The reality of all of those recommendations is very simple: they recognise quite sensibly that using on line data collection with exchange between agencies to overcome tax evasion and fraud is not inherently sinister; it is simply a recognition of modern technology. It simply needs to be protected with mechanisms such as the Data Protection Agency. Senator Puplick on the other side, with his concern about combating tax evasion and fraud, could do no more to achieve that end than to support any moves that this Government makes to introduce measures that he totally supported when he was a member of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too wish to study this report of the Review of Systems for Dealing with Fraud on the Commonwealth at considerably greater depth than I have been able to yet. From what I have found in it so far, I regret that I find it to be quite superficial, totally elementary, pointless and, in many respects, absolutely useless. It is the fourth report on crime that has been put down by this Government in the last 4 1/2 years. The Government has not advanced the situation one jot in those four reports. The report sneaked out late one night because, I presume, it would have been laughed at had it come out in daylight. This report must be regarded as a damning indictment of the attitude of this Government and its actions in dealing with crime generally.

SPEECH.PARA: The review of the systems is one thing but the report does not specify the extent of fraud that we are endeavouring to control. There is no mention of whether it is $1m, $1 billion, $4 1/2 billion, as has been mentioned lately, or $10 billion, as has been mentioned in some circles. To me it is fairly fundamental that until one knows the size of the problem one really cannot make up one's mind as to the best way to deal with it. That applies to the Government too. The major point is that the action taken must fit the need and we do not know what the need is. We are not told whether the Government has any idea of what it is either.

We are getting report after report, we are getting words and not actions, and I really feel sorry for Senator Tate, who must be terribly embarrassed by all this. We certainly look to him now to pick up from Minister Young, who has done absolutely nothing over the last four years except give comfort to crooks. We hope that Senator Tate will really be able to show his mettle as a result of this. The report shows up the Government in many ways. I believe that the report is a fraud because it is absolutely typical and predictable and the material is so serious. I think we would laugh about it if it were not so serious.
There has been talk about superficiality. I, too, would like to quote from the report. On page 38 it states:
What is required is recognition that fraud can and does occur, and an explicit, systematic approach to its prevention and detection appropriate to the requirements of the agency in question.
We could not have anything more simplistic than that. Page 40 of the report quotes Douglas Meagher, who was ignominiously sacked, along with Costigan, by this Government. It states:
`Ignorance is bliss. If you do not have a detection system that is going to uncover fraud then you do not know it is happening . . . If you are not looking for it you will not see it.'
On the next page the report states:

It is considered highly desirable that early consideration be given to sample surveys as a means of assessing the effectiveness of resource allocation and present approaches to preventing and detecting fraud.

All this is very simplistic if this problem is so great. I just do not think the Government fully appreciates it. There are indications that Government organisations are handling huge amounts of money and that no one had thought that there could be fraudulent endeavours to obtain it from people outside.

The various recommendations that I found in the early stages of the report are also very naive. I do not think the Government has any system in mind. I make two positive suggestions. Firstly, no system should be considered before discussing it with the Australian Federal Police. The Federal Police can give us plenty of advice on how to prevent some of these problems. Secondly, we totally reject the second recommendation in the report, which suggests that each of these government organisations ought to set up its own mini-police force. We have too many police forces now. If we really want to do the job properly we need to use the professionals. I certainly believe that if the Government falls for having yet more police forces of this nature it can only get further and further into trouble.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report entitled Review of Systems for Dealing with Fraud on the Commonwealth has been sat on by the Government since March this year. As Senator Archer has said, it is only the fourth in a long line of reports that the Government has sat on over several years. In February 1985, Mr Young got a report entitled The Cost of Efficient Policing, which he refused to make public. In April 1985 he called for a second report which was never tabled. In March 1986 he got a third report, which was also known as the `Fraud Report', and he did not do anything about that. In May 1986 he called for a fourth report and that is the one for which Senator Tate now has responsibility. That is also the one to which Mr John Spender was refused access following his freedom of information request. It is also the report which the Federal Secretary of the Australian Federal Police Association (AFPA), Mr Chris Eaton, said that the Government was sitting on, that was a disgrace and that the Federal Police Association was very upset about. He also said:

SPEECH.PARA: A national identity card is not the answer to the type of fraud identified by this secret report.
He said further:
An Australia Card will be just another document open to fraud and able to be misused to cover a trail of organised crime protected by the assumption of validity presented by the card.

Yet this report recommends the Australia Card. It is nonsense! It is not surprising when we look at the composition of the review committee that we find buried, hidden well in the text of this report, that Mr McGuarr, Dr Wilenski, the Commissioner of Taxation and the General Manager of the Health Insurance Commission were notable contributors to this report. Is it any wonder that they were chosen for the job? It is quite interesting also that representatives from the Attorney-General's Department and the Commissioner of Police were co-opted to a couple of meetings later on. They were not made members of the review committee.

Why is this Government so secretive about the report? I think it is simply that it is very well aware that it has been in government for 4 1/2 years now and has just sat on the problem. As we know, a huge amount of taxpayers' money is involved and is being wasted-we do not quite know how much. A former senior solicitor with the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) said that it was between $10 billion and $30 billion. It is enough to make any government move fast but this Government clearly is unable to. I recognise that direct crediting of regular payments, one of the matters which has been referred to in the report, has improved the situation somewhat but I am appalled to find criticism of the government agencies for a lack of training in the prevention and identifying of fraud. I am glad to see that that suggestion is being made and I hope that it will be acted upon. If ever we had a need for action it is in the area of those agencies that are subject to fraud to make sure that their personnel are properly trained in preventing and identifying fraud and detecting and dealing with it.

But an ID card or an indiscriminate swapping of information between departments is totally unacceptable. What we need is an increase in resources for the law enforcement agencies-the Australian Federal Police (AFP), the Director of Public Prosecutions, and the Attorney- General's Department-to prevent the bigger fish from defrauding the Commonwealth. Those agencies do not have the resources they need. The AFP and the AFPA have been lobbying for two years for a 50 per cent increase in staffing to fight these sorts of fraud against the Commonwealth. The report entitled The Cost of Efficient Policing, presented in February 1985, called for 1,364 extra staff. The review that Mick Young established in April 1985 found a shortfall of between 1,000 and 1,400 AFP members and 230 to 350 support staff. Since then this Government has increased the AFP staff level by 145 and by another 104 in this Budget, and it has increased the support staff in the Public Service by only 19 in the last four years. It is not good enough. The DPP also claims that a lack of resources is hindering the fight against fraud.

We will only get the kind of policing against these sorts of frauds that we are prepared to pay for. Staff members alone will not do the entire job but they are a good start. We need political will. Clearly, until now at least, we have not had it. I hope that, after publicity given to this fraud report, the Government will be pushed into action, but I have not seen much evidence in the current Budget to suggest that the Government is really serious.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —This Government is involved in some sort of massive cover-up in relation to fraud against the Commonwealth. The Australian Federal Police Association has been so concerned about the enormous fraud against the Commonwealth that it has called for a royal commission to determine why the Government has not acted on years and years of reports alleging enormous fraud against the Commonwealth. This call has not been addressed by the Government. I see that Senator Walsh is in the chamber and I challenge him in relation to this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: In July the Australian Federal Police Association released figures which put tax fraud at $3 billion. The figures showed customs fraud and evasion at $2.5 billion, social security fraud and over-payments at $2 billion, fraud against defence at $800 million and health and medicare fraud at $700 million, or the equivalent of 11 cents in every dollar of Commonwealth expenditure. Senator Walsh comes into this place and claims to argue against tax evasion and similar cheating. He unmercifully and unfairly attacks people on this side of the House, yet he is strangely silent about his Government's failure to address the issues raised by the Australian Federal Police Association, an independent body which is greatly concerned about the fraud which it sees going on in this nation. One can only wonder whose interests are being protected in what appears to be a massive cover-up by this Government and the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Young. In February 1985 Mr Young received a report entitled The Cost of Efficient Policing, and he refused to table the report. In April 1985 he called for a second report allegedly entitled `Resource Enquiry'. He received that, I understand, in October or November 1985 but again that report has not been made public; it has not been tabled. In March 1986 Mr Young received the `Fraud Report'; again not made public. Why was it not made public? Why is this Government covering up? I challenge Senator Walsh to tell us why the Government is not prepared to make reports public. In May 1986 Mr Young rejected the `Fraud Report'. Does Senator Walsh deny that Mr Young recalled the privately distributed copies of that report and shredded the report so that no one would be able to see what was in it? On 28 May, Senator Gareth Evans said to this chamber:
It is not possible to offer an estimate of computer crime because it is not possible to quantify the extent of unreported and undetected computer fraud.

The Federal Police Association has given its estimate of the massive amount of money the Commonwealth is being defrauded of, certainly enough to make up for the loss of the so-called Australia Card claimed by this Government, and the Government is not doing anything about it. This nonsense report that we have had tabled was released late at night so the media could not get hold of it-that is called media manipulation. It is a very large report. As my colleague Senator Archer said, it contains very little government information and is prepared by government sycophants. The report reveals some criticism of the Government, which is not surprising, but it does not contain anywhere near enough information for people to be able to deal with it properly and, in particular, deal with it in a way the Australian Federal Police wish the Government of the nation to deal with it, by way of royal commission. This Government has reduced the Australian Federal Police budget by $1.5m. How that will help recover these billions of dollars from the people who are defrauding the Commonwealth of Australia, I do not know. I see that Senator Walsh thinks this is a laugh. Senator Walsh and Senator Maguire are laughing and joking about it. I can assure them that neither the Opposition nor the people of Australia consider it to be a laughing matter. I seek leave to continue my remarks later so that we can deal with this matter on another occasion.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

In the limited time available, I was most interested to examine this report. My first comment is that it is regretted that it is the annual report for 1985-86 and therefore the information contained in it must be very out of date. I was particularly interested, because of connections I have had with its predecessor, the Committee on Overseas Professional Qualifications, known as the COPQ. The initial report of that Committee was instrumental in playing its part in events which led eventually to the production of the national language policy to which the Governor-General referred in his Speech on the opening of the Parliament. I quote from page 1 of the report:
The objectives of the Council are:

to assist prospective immigrants in the assessment of their qualifications in Australian terms; and to assist Australian residents who are holders of overseas qualifications to obtain assessment of their qualifications in Australia.

Two of the functions of this Council are to investigate overseas qualifications and to relate the findings to Australian educational standards, and to provide individual assessments of overseas professional qualifications and to assist professions in Australia to evaluate overseas qualifications. It must be realised that the recognition of the overseas qualifications is a problem but it is not a new problem. Page 5 of the report reads:

The problem of the recognition of overseas qualifications in Australia is not new. In 1956 a large influx of professionally qualified people from Hungary was largely responsible for the establishment of a Foreign Practitioners Qualifications Committee (FPQC) in Victoria. In 1968, following the crisis in Czechoslovakia, another group of highly qualified people expressed interest in settling in Australia. As a result, attention was once again focused on the need to update assessment procedures and assist Australian professions to acquire information about professional training in countries outside the British system.

Requests for recognition of overseas professional qualifications have a history going back a number of years. The Council on Overseas Professional Qualifications espouses the commendable principle that as far as is practicable we must ensure that skills brought to this country by migrants are not wasted and procedures for recognition of overseas professional qualifications have been established to ensure that minimum standards are maintained within occupations. The need for a knowledge of Australian codes, practices and conditions is incorporated into these procedures by written and practical examinations. Bridging courses are seen as an essential part of Australia's recognition procedures. Bridging courses can embody two different concepts, that of reorientation and that of retraining. Both these are essential components if overseas professional qualifications are to be properly recognised.

I should like to draw the attention of honourable senators to some of the statistics in the report. In 1985-86 more than 11,000 requests for examination and assessment were received but the growth in applications for assessment in nursing was absolutely dramatic. Out of 11,269 examinations and assessments conducted, 2,973 were for nursing. However, it is puzzling to note that there is no mention of assessments or examinations for people in the medical profession. I ask why that is so. I thank you, Mr Deputy President, for the opportunity to draw the attention of honourable senators to this report on overseas professional qualifications. I recommend that honourable senators read it because of its vitality in the matter of professional qualifications as a whole within Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE FOR THE SCRUTINY OF BILLS

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Cooney, I lay on the table Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 11, dated 7 October, 1987.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 September, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Loans Bill is one of the most important Bills, in my judgment, to come before Parliament in the course of any financial year because it is one of the Bills that allow Parliament to exercise supervision and, in the last analysis, control over the behaviour of the Executive. After all, that is the role of Parliament, the role properly considered of Parliament, as distinct from the Executive Government. Of course, no part of the Parliament has a greater hand in carrying out that role than the Senate. If one wants any evidence of the truth of what I just said, one can point immediately to two very recent examples, one of them of the most overwhelmingly important kind and another that might be thought to be rather minor but in my humble opinion in its own small way important also. I refer, of course, to the action of the Senate in bringing to an end the Government's proposals for the so-called Australia Card, on which we had some debate earlier this afternoon on Senator Puplick's motion of urgency and, indeed, on which we have had some debate in the course of earlier sittings of the Senate. I suppose that for some time both inside and outside the Parliament one has not heard phrases such as `constitutional vandalism' and other examples of overblown rhetoric of that kind which, of course, have resulted from the perfectly constitutional and perfectly proper actions taken by the Senate to deal with that major piece of Government legislation which has led now, of course, to its actually being withdrawn by the Government. That is an example of the proper role of the Senate in a major instance.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, we have seen a much more minor example of the same proper discharge by the Senate of its constitutional responsibilities. I refer to debate somewhat earlier today when the Senate considered the Government's Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1987. This Bill seeks to make changes, described as insignificant or of a purely machinery kind, in no fewer than 87 Acts of this Parliament. I have to say that I think that the experience of debating that Bill earlier this day has given rise, not only here but also in the House of Representatives, to some serious questioning about the manner in which we conduct our affairs in relation to that form of legislation. As Senator Lewis was able to point out today, that particular Bill was one which contained a number of provisions which, in the end, the Senate refused to approve. That was notwithstanding the fact that it was put forward as a purely machinery, purely technical and purely non-policy piece of legislation.

The amendment which I particularly had in mind was that which proposed that in future by ministerial fiat the Minister for Finance would have the sole prerogative of making any change that he, and only he, thought fit in the presentation of the monthly statement of Commonwealth financial transactions-the so-called Niemeyer report, which these days no doubt is a somewhat misleading term. Nevertheless, this is a significant and important monthly report, not merely to the Parliament but to the people of Australia, on the Commonwealth's financial accounts. Had that particular provision not been struck out of the Bill the Minister would have obtained sole power to determine for the future the form of that report. I mention that matter, although I do not want to stray too far from the Loans Bill itself. However, I mention those two examples by way of illustrating my much more general point about the supreme importance of the role of the Parliament and, as I say, particularly of this chamber, in maintaining appropriate supervision and, in the last analysis, control of the Executive Government of the Commonwealth of Australia.

I think the fact that debate on the Loan Bill is traditional again underlines my earlier point that this is one of the most important pieces of financial legislation to come before the Parliament each financial year. It is not a mere piece of machinery legislation although, at times, it takes on that colouration. It is an integral part of the budgetary process and of the budgetary financing process. Of course, as such, each year it very properly gives rise to considerable debate which ranges widely on the subject of the Budget itself, the state of the economy and so on. Of course, this is a time at which debate of that kind is particularly and peculiarly appropriate. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh)-who is not actually gracing us at the moment with his presence-described the Budget less than a week after it was brought down as being in danger of being oversold. I think the Minister for Finance was in danger of understatement. There is no question of the Budget being in danger of being oversold; the Budget very clearly has been oversold.

It is interesting to note and, I hope, perhaps it is salutary for the Government to note, that since about that time there has been the appearance of some signs of the effect of overkill, both in the now somewhat more balanced statements emerging from the financial and economic commentators in our Press and other media and also perhaps as reflected in the behaviour of some elements of the financial markets. It is no longer good enough for representatives of this Government to stand up here in this chamber and rave on to the effect that all of this country's problems are due to the faults of its predecessors. I have no doubt that this Government's predecessors did have some faults; in the eyes of some, no doubt, many faults. However, it is no longer to the least purpose for the Minister for Finance, for Senator Button, or anyone else either here or in the other place to try to persuade us-or to bully us, which is more generally their modus operandi-into acceptance of their view that, in fact, Australia's ills are all bequeathed. After all, this Government has been in office now for 4 1/2 years. That is not an inconsiderable period.

As I was saying, we have, as was revealed as a result of questions in this chamber today, an Australian dollar which from one point of view-what I might loosely call, no doubt, Senator Button's point of view and the point of view of import competing manufacturers in particular-is too dear. As I said, it is a dollar which is uncomfortably high from the point of view of the interests of that particular area of the productive economy. The same undoubtedly would apply in regard to the exporting industries such as the major rural and great mining industries of this country. As I say, from that viewpoint we have a dollar that is too dear. Yet as was illustrated by the extraordinary action of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) last week in placing a virtually total ban on purchases of residential real estate in urban areas by non-Australians and the point of view of the relative international value of Australian assets, we have a dollar that is too cheap. I think that that is a dilemma that this Government has barely begun to realise, let alone begun to face up to in terms of the policy requirements that it will need to induce in due course.

One of the consequences of that kind of dilemma, of course, is the very considerable degree of uncertainty which now pertains not merely in the financial markets, which in this respect I think are not the most important places to look, but in our major industrial sectors. The Minister for Finance has now rejoined us in the chamber. I think I recall earlier this afternoon his responding to one of the rather characteristic dorothy dix questions-which I think are the only kinds of questions which are asked by honourable senators on the other side of the chamber-by reading a little lecture on what the latest Treasury Round-up may or may not have said about the outlook for business investment in this country. I do not propose to follow him in what, I think, turned out to be a somewhat boring recitation-other than to note that, notwithstanding the Government's attempts to suggest that all in the investment garden is, if not yet rosy, certainly taking on the first blush of rosiness, we will have to wait a little longer and wait to see the numbers come up before we accept the Government's newly found euphoria in that area.

The fact is that, if from one point of view our currency is too cheap and from another point of view it is too dear, it is rather hard under those circumstances for manufacturers, for example, to make up their minds on what basis they should begin to plan their future. Should they begin to plan on the assumption that the Australian dollar will rise in value against foreign currencies or should they begin to plan their future, in particular their investment, on the assumption that the dollar will begin to fall? Perhaps the most interesting aspect of that conundrum or dilemma is that I am not sure that the Government, taken as a collective at least, has even begun to understand that it has a problem in that regard. It may be that some glimmer of understanding of that is beginning to dawn on such Ministers as Senator Button and, I would like to think, Senator Walsh; but I doubt that it has yet dawned on the Government, taken as a collective.

A third element of our economic problems with which the 1987-88 Budget purports to deal-I emphasise `purports'-is the problem of our cost structure, future wage rates and, more generally, the whole question of real unit labour costs, which are a function not merely of the present level of and future increase in money wages but also of the present position of and future change in productivity, in this case, I think one must say, on an enterprise basis. We all know that this Government's performance in both those areas bearing upon this fundamental question of the outlook for real unit labour costs has been not merely poor but abysmal. The Government stands in thrall-it has ever since it came to office-to the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the particular power brokers who run that body. The Government is incapable of dealing with this problem of real unit labour costs. It is palsied when it comes to facing up to it.

While I do not wish to comment unduly on what I understand to be the somewhat topical question now before the Remuneration Tribunal, I will just say that a particularly powerful example of the manner in which this Government's policies are being run by Mr Bill Kelty could be noticed in the Press of the last couple of days.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only when it suits them, because they paid no attention whatsoever to the numerous occasions when we either halved or disallowed entirely our parliamentary salary increases.

—I think I have to accept Senator Haines's interjection. Without pursuing this element of my remarks further, the simple points I want to make are: we have an economy which is in a frightful mess and we have a government which, if one can judge by the standards of the Budget, which, after all, is the Government's single most important instrument for economic adjustment during the financial year, seems to have thrown up its hands in the air on dealing with the problems of the economy.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me come rather more directly to the Loans Bill. What is the purpose of a Loan Bill? It seeks to deal with certain quite proper legal constraints which are laid upon the Government in the pursuance of its financial transactions. The single most important such constraint, in this context at least, is that payments from the Consolidated Revenue Fund cannot legally exceed moneys available to that Fund. In 1987-88, it is estimated, there will be a deficit in the Consolidated Revenue Fund-not in the total public account, although there will be a small deficit in the total public account according to the Government's creative accounting processes or ways of looking at these things. In the Consolidated Revenue Fund, which forms a very large part of the total public account, there will be a deficit which was estimated in the second reading speech to be of the order of $2.4 billion.

Because of that, one of two things has to occur: either action must be taken to reduce in some way expenditures out of the Consolidated Revenue Fund to balance out the two sides of that fund, or action must be taken to bring funds into the Consolidated Revenue Fund from somewhere else in the public account. Because that is often the case, not invariably, but in recent years it has generally been the case, it has become customary at this time of the financial year, that is, concurrently with the Budget, appropriation Bills and the other legislation which flows from the Budget process, to seek legislative authority to charge some defence expenditure-as a general rule and because borrowing for defence purposes is not covered without exemption in the terms of the Financial Agreement and therefore the Commonwealth does not have to seek the agreement of the States to undertake such borrowings-to the Loan Fund or to give authority to reimburse the Consolidated Revenue Fund from the Loan Fund, for some other expenditures.

That is what this Bill, for the most part, proposes to do. It seeks authority to borrow money in 1987-88 for defence and other purposes. The second reading speech in the other place, which has been incorporated in this place, states:

This Bill therefore seeks authority to borrow money in 1987-88 for defence and other purposes and to enable certain other expenditures to be met from the Loan Fund rather than from the Consolidated Revenue Fund.

So far, so good. From the viewpoint of the Opposition, we have no real objection to those proposals, so far as they go. In saying that, I do not wish to be misunderstood. I particularly do not wish to be understood to be saying that we regard this legislation as a mere machinery measure which should go through, so to speak, on the voices and without proper scrutiny and detailed consideration. Up to that point, the Opposition, on this occasion, has no objection to the Bill. If that were all the Bill proposed to do, we would be prepared to give it a fair wind. We would have some discussion about it, as we are now doing in the second reading debate; but I imagine that we would not do more than that.
But one aspect of the Bill is in a different category. Again I refer to the second reading speech, in which the Minister says:
In addition, and for the first time, the Bill provides for continuity of that authority-
that is, the borrowing authority-
by the inclusion of a supply clause. In the past, borrowing authority under the annual Loan Act-
it is interesting that the Minister quite properly describes it as a loan Act, in the singular-
ceased to be available on 30 June until the next Loan Act was passed, usually by urgent passage in the Budget sittings.

The provision to go beyond that is what gives rise to difficulty, and there is some relevant history on this matter which should be briefly cited. In 1985 the Government brought in what was again called a Loans Bill 1985, which not merely sought to obtain the requisite borrowing authority for the financing of the transactions of that Budget for 1985-86 but also included a clause which would have provided standing authority for such borrowings rather than the need for annual legislation. In the terms that were used in the Parliament, it would in effect have produced a special appropriation type of borrowing authority rather than an annual appropriation type of borrowing authority. That would have had one effect alone, although an extraordinarily important effect: it would have removed this area of the Government's transactions from the annual review of the Parliament. I was not in this chamber at that time.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, but we were and we were the ones who picked it up.

—Senator Haines reminds me that both the Opposition and the Australian Democrats were here at that time, and to their joint credit, which I fully concede, they made it clear to the Government that they would not accept that major change in legislative process and, as a consequence, that provision was deleted from the Bill in 1985.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not wish to be provocative, but it seems that the Government has amongst its ranks-I do not want to suggest that this comes from officers, although sometimes such things do, so perhaps I should say either the Government or the Department of Finance has within its ranks-some slow learners, because in 1986 another Loans Bill came before Parliament. Again, I was not here, but again this Bill contained a provision seeking to do what, in the previous year, this Parliament had specifically, categorically and for cogently stated reasons, refused to do. I do not wish to use provocative language, but I would have thought that that was a provocative act and it was dealt with as acts of provocation from a Government that does not have a majority in this chamber ought to be dealt with-that is to say, with contumely. That provision was defeated, and once again the Loans Bill 1986-or the Loan Bill 1986 as it emerged-became what the Loan Bill traditionally has been, that is to say, a Bill to provide authority for borrowings relating to the Budget of the financial year in question.

This year there is some sign of educability on the part of the Government, because it has not brought back again the outrageous provision which it has twice introduced. This time, it has produced a seemingly different provision by including a clause which seeks to extend the existing borrowing authority by the inclusion of a Supply clause. If this Bill is passed, borrowing authority under the proposed change would be extended into the following financial year. It would not expire at 30 June, unlike previous Loan Acts, but would be extended into the following financial year of 1988-89 and by the amount included in the Supply Bill (No. 1), which of course we have not yet received. That Bill normally comes in in April or May of the financial year and has effect into the first five months of the following financial year. Because of this new clause, we would have a borrowing authority equivalent to the amount provided in the Supply Bill, although we do not know that amount because the Supply Bill is not yet before Parliament, which would roughly be in the order of some billions of dollars. After all, the defence vote, to which the Supply clause specifically relates, is a very large vote and a Supply provision in respect of the defence vote is therefore, although it is only for five-twelfths of the year, a very large amount. I think that it is fair to say that the provision of such a large Supply provision in this Bill would give the Government more borrowing authority for the financial year 1988-89 than it is seeking in the Loans Bill for this year, even though it has not done anything by way of a new Loans Bill for next year. Some time ago, after the Loans Bill appeared in the House of Representatives and I had a chance to look at it, I issued a Press statement on the matter which made it clear to the Government that, from where the Opposition sat at any rate, although I had not at that time had a chance to consult with others such as Senator Haines, we would not allow, or would do our best to deny to the Government, this evasion of the proper constitutional role of this chamber in bringing to bear a process of scrutiny upon the Government's financial processes.

Therefore, some time ago the Government was forewarned that we would be moving against only this particular provision-not the Bill as a whole-to which the Opposition takes very strong objection. I foreshadow that, in the committee stage, I shall move a number of amendments to this Bill, which I think have already been distributed in the chamber. Certainly, earlier today during the lunch break, I gave a copy to the Minister for Finance as a matter of personal courtesy. We will be moving a number of amendments to deny this provision which the Government is, in a quite extraordinary manner, seeking. All that we are seeking to do by that process is to return the Bill, if that should be the will of the Senate, in that amended form to the same form as in previous years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The legislation before us is a Bill for an Act to authorise the borrowing and expending of money for certain purposes. It is standard practice for this Parliament to deal with a Loans Bill on an annual basis. It is a slender Bill of only nine clauses, but it has quite a significant impact on the way in which not only Parliament operates but also government operates. This legislation has an even more significant element to it, and one which Senator Stone has discussed at some length, in that it extends the period in which governments can borrow through Treasury beyond the end of the financial year with which we are dealing.

SPEECH.PARA: Essentially, this legislation provides for the financing of the prospective deficit in the Consolidated Revenue Fund (CRF) of some $2.4 billion. This includes the financing of the 1987-88 Budget deficit, which is estimated to be $27m, and we will see how accurate that is sometime down the track. Most of the Consolidated Revenue Fund deficit consists of what I think accountants tend to call `below the line financing transactions', which are predominantly payments for maturing debt or prepayments of Commonwealth debt. For legal reasons, expenditures from the Consolidated Revenue Fund in any financial year may not exceed revenue moneys available to it. To the extent of any shortfall in CRF revenues, balancing the CRF requires the charging of expenditure to, or reimbursement of, the Consolidated Revenue Fund from the Loan Fund, where they can be financed out of loan raisings.

There are three options or ways for transferring expenditures from the CRF or reimbursing the CRF from the Loan Fund. The first of those is a delightful piece of creative accounting that operates essentially to charge to the Loan Fund, under the authority of the Loan Act for that purpose, defence expenditure which has been appropriated from the CRF under the authority of the Supply and Appropriation Acts.

While it may seem odd that the Loans Bill authorises borrowing for defence purposes in particular, there is an obvious reason for it. By seeking to borrow for defence purposes, the Commonwealth avoids seeking Loan Council approval for the borrowing, since defence expenditure is exempt from Loan Council coverage. As I said, it is a bit of creative accounting which, I hasten to add, is not sinister in any way; it is just a useful device encompassed by governments to get around having to go to the Loan Council all the time. It has occurred since 1949. Nevertheless, while it is traditional and not sinister, it is not only a creative bit of accounting but also a rather haphazard way of giving governments the authority to borrow.

The other two options are more precise. They require, of course, Loan Council approval. The first of the remaining two options is to utilise existing legislation provisions, known as dual appropriations, for the fairly obvious reason that they can be charged either to the CRF or to the Loan Fund. When the expenditures are charged to the Loan Fund under such legislation, the borrowings to finance them are governed by the limit of the Commonwealth's Loan Council borrowings program. Dual appropriations Bills include most of the States grants Bills, such as those which deal with housing, schools assistance and so on. The second of the remaining two options is to reimburse the CRF with respect to other non-defence expenditure which has been incurred, again, under the authority of Supply and Appropriation Acts, from the Loan Fund under the authority of a Loan Act for that specific purpose. As with the second option that I discussed a moment ago, the borrowings to finance this expenditure are governed by the limit of the Commonwealth's Loan Council borrowings program.

The Loans Bill 1987-soon, I hasten to add, to become the Loans Act-uses these three traditional avenues to deal with the expected Consolidated Revenue Fund deficit. In addition, it proposes that, for the first time, a Supply clause be included to provide continuity of borrowing so that Treasury can borrow between the end of one financial year-that is, 30 June-and the passage of the next financial year's Loans Bill, which usually takes place in the following October or November. I point out that it is passed in October or November because the Parliament does not resume sitting until August, and often the middle of August. There is no reason why it could not be brought further forward so that the hiatus period is shorter than the traditional one of seven months.

In any event, the new element in this legislation is the extension proposed under this Bill to allow legal borrowings to occur after the end of this financial year and prior to the passage of the following financial year's Loans Bill. In other words, it seeks to remove the current restriction on government borrowings, although, as Senator Stone has already pointed out, it does not go as far as the Government has attempted to go in previous years. I hasten to point out to Senator Stone that in 1985, for example, the Australian Democrats noticed that that particular year's Loans Bill would have been the last to be considered by the Parliament. Senator Stone got his guernsey and had his moment in the spotlight a couple of weeks ago. For the record I claim that ours was in 1985.

TALK.START.PARA: —I yield entirely.

—Yes, I am sure that Senator Stone would realise that I would not let that pass without commenting on it. That year the Opposition parties-I dare say because they were overworked and underpaid-let the legislation be passed by the House of Representatives without commenting on the fact that there was a clause in the Bill that removed the need for further Loans Bills. By the time it had been drawn to their attention by us the Bill was before the Senate. As Senator Stone has already noted, I am pleased to say that everybody on this side of the chamber saw the wisdom of removing that element from the Loans Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said a moment ago, this Bill does not go as far as that, but we still need to be cautious when governments try to take for themselves powers that are not open to full parliamentary scrutiny until after the event. I will say more in a moment about the need to extend parliamentary scrutiny of the Loans Bill because a particularly important function of this chamber is the power that is contained in the Senate, which is not in the hands of the Government, of extensive investigation of legislation and questioning of Ministers. This Bill does not go as far as that, but we are concerned that it does include the several months extension of legal borrowings.

We acknowledge that the contentious Supply provision does not affect how much the Commonwealth borrows or how much it spends. What it does affect is the timing of the decision to borrow-at least, that is the stated intention-and it does so to a relatively small degree at the moment. We need to ask ourselves whether that matters a great deal. We need also to ask, if there are savings to be made by giving Treasury the freedom to borrow in the hiatus period between 1 July and the following October, if borrowing terms appear favourable and whether this justifies further diminishing parliamentary scrutiny of Treasury's practices and, hence, of government's policies and intentions. We do not believe it is justified, on the slender grounds that maybe in that period there will be more favourable borrowing conditions of which the Government should be in a position to take advantage.

One of the roles of this place has been referred to by me and by Senator Stone. I must say that I am worried about the number of occasions on which I am agreeing with Senator Stone; one of us is having a major ideological problem and I have not yet had time to work out who it is. In any event, Senator Stone was perfectly correct in arguing that one of the roles of this place is for us to scrutinise and, where necessary, comment on and criticise the Government for its activity, lack of activity or the behaviour of its departments.

What this Bill effectively highlights is the total inadequacy of current parliamentary supervision of the Loans Bill because we do not ever really get the information that we, as members of parliament, need in order to make informed decisions, ask sensible questions and come to rational decisions. While I know that that is asking a bit much of some people around the place, there are a few of us who attempt to do those things from time to time. Senator Walsh will say that this is not one of those times, and he is entitled to that view. But I believe that this chamber has a vital role in the scrutiny measures that we undertake.

As I said earlier, in 1985 and 1986 the Government wanted to make it even more difficult for Parliament to supervise what governments were doing on those occasions. It attempted to remove the Parliament's annual scrutiny of loan raisings absolutely by extending the Government's authority to borrow forever. It seems to me that, especially in these times when the amount of government, domestic and foreign borrowing has become a major focus of economic policy making, the Parliament should not be giving a free hand to the departments of Treasury and Finance to borrow as they wish, when they wish, with scrutiny only after the event.

Currently, the Parliament and the Australian people can only find out what the Government has borrowed for the year that has just passed. In effect, we already give Treasury carte blanche to borrow enormous amounts of money for the following year. We acknowledge that Budget Papers give some indication, but they are not binding and they are often not as comprehensive as we would like. We then have to rely on the government of the day to borrow on the most favourable terms, and only as much as is needed within the generous upper limit-$7 billion this year-imposed by the Loans Bill.

We need more, not less, parliamentary supervision of borrowings. They are becoming an integral and increasing part of the whole system. It is important that the Parliament is in a position to keep tabs on what governments are doing with regard to borrowings, given the impact that this can have on all sorts of things, including our credit rating, the attitude of overseas financiers to Australia, the attitude that investors inside and outside the country are likely to take to us, the level of our dollar and all sorts of other economic imponderables. It is important that tabs are kept. The Parliament should know how much will be borrowed, from whom it will be borrowed and why it will be borrowed. That sort of information should be contained in future Loan Bills. Instead, this Government is intent upon giving itself more power to borrow while reducing Parliament's very limited supervision of its borrowing program. We cannot and will not support that, and nor should any responsible member of parliament. For that reason, we will support the Opposition's amendments which in effect ensure that governments, through Treasury, cannot escape full parliamentary scrutiny by borrowing after the end of one financial year and prior to the passage of the next Loan Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In both 1985 and 1986 the Labor Government included a clause in the Loans Bill that would have had the effect of eliminating the need to present a Loan Bill to Parliament annually. By attempting to change an annual Bill to a standing Bill, the Government was making an amendment that would have reduced the power of the Parliament to scrutinise government expenditure. The powers of the Executive would have been increased by the fact that, thereafter, a Loan Bill would not have needed to be presented to the Parliament for debate. That was a retrograde step. I remind the Senate that, on both occasions, the proposal was rejected by the Senate. In the Loans Bill 1987 the Government appears to be trying to achieve the same result, again by a back-door method, by the inclusion of a new technique-the inclusion of a Supply clause.

SPEECH.PARA: To date, the borrowing authority under the annual Loan Act has ceased to be available on 30 June until the next June Act is passed. The effect of the new clause, a Supply clause, will be to give borrowing authority for the period from 1 July 1988 to the date of commencement of Appropriation Act (No. 1) 1988-89-a period to be know as the Supply period-the amount included in Supply Act (No. 1) 1988-89 for defence purposes. We are told by the Government that this new arrangement will not in any way impinge upon the Parliament's prerogative to appropriate public moneys, but will simply provide a mechanism for financing public expenditures previously provided and appropriated by the Parliament. I believe that there is room for a great deal of scepticism in this area. The danger is that such measures will give the Government sufficient capacity to avoid the presentation of a Loan Bill in 1988, thereby removing the opportunity for the Parliament to debate the issue. That is another retrograde tactic to strengthen the hand of executive government in Australia. I believe that is a matter of concern that the power of the Parliament as a whole to scrutinise the operations of the executive government is being eaten away.

I remind the Senate that, in the last sitting period, we witnessed the weakening of the capacity of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts to scrutinise government expenditure by a similar back-door approach. In fact, the staff of the already overworked secretariat was reduced to one-third of its original level, thus reducing its capacity, and that of the Joint Committee, to investigate adequately all the matters that are necessarily brought before it. Another example is that the Government has denied adequate resources to the Commonwealth Auditor-General, thereby preventing him from fulfilling his statutory obligations to this Parliament and to this Senate.

The Government has referred to the Loans Bill as a `machinery financing measure' and has said that no new financial implications flow from the Bill. However, it overlooks one important thing. It does have important implications for the functioning of this Senate and the Parliament. The elimination of the need to present a Loan Bill annually could have serious consequences for the management of a deficit and accountability to the people of Australia, because it would allow the removal of some items of expenditure from Consolidated Revenue and their inclusion in the items paid for from the Loan Fund. I believe that this is a very serious shortcoming.

Given the extent of this nation's debt, it is an area that should be given greater, not less, scrutiny. The Government has before this Senate a technique for reducing scrutiny by this Parliament in an area which needs additional scrutiny. I remind the Senate that approximately one-third of our external debt is accumulated by the public sector. In fact, the public sector debt for the June quarter of 1987 was $44,371m. It was up on the $38,838m figure for the corresponding quarter of 1985-86. The figures certainly give some justification to the fact that the amendments proposed by Senator Stone should be agreed to and that we should revert to having an annual Loan Bill.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Loans Bill before the Senate is a machinery measure. It was described in the House of Representatives in 1985 by the then shadow Treasurer, Mr Carlton, in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill makes arrangements for the Government to borrow. Previously there used to be an annual Loan Bill to handle this situation for all circumstances arising during a financial year. This Bill has been drafted as standing legislation-
that is, the 1985 Bill-
rather than annual legislation to remove the necessity to pass legislation annually. As the Bill does not itself authorise expenditure-

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!
—I note the interjection from a member of the Liberal Party about the then shadow Treasurer two years ago-

SPEECH.PARA: but merely creates a mechanism whereby expenditures authorised by other legislation can be made, the Opposition does not object to the concept of standing legislation. It merely improves the efficiency of the Parliament. We therefore support the Bill.

That was Mr Carlton accurately describing the Loans Bill of 1985 which included, as a standing piece of legislation, authority for the Government to borrow against efficiencies in the Consolidated Revenue fund under the appropriations for defence purposes. Mr Carlton described it accurately. Some time after he made that accurate statement and statement of support on behalf of the Opposition he had his arm twisted up behind his back by some of the ratbags in the Liberal Party of Australia and the Opposition opposed the Bill in the Senate. Thinking that they might have acquired a sense of responsibility in the succeeding 12 months the Government put up standing appropriations again last year and they were defeated in the Senate again.

The purpose of the standing appropriations, apart from making the Parliament more efficient, as Mr Carlton said, was to enable the Government to take advantage of opportunities which may arise in the early part of the financial year to borrow under favourable terms, opportunities which are not available if the longstanding practice of passing a Loan Bill either in late September or early October is continued. This year the Government decided, since the standing appropriation had been rejected twice, to include under the Supply provision a mechanism under which the Government could borrow in the early part of the financial year if opportunities to borrow advantageously arose. The amendments which have been forecast by the Opposition deny that opportunity.

In the autumn session of Parliament, on the legislation providing for quarterly provisional tax, we had amendments originating from the National Party in Queensland supported, I trust in ignorance-although one cannot be sure of these things-by the Liberal Party and later the Australian Democrats which made that part of the legislation technically inoperative. We also had regulations early this year to curb the overfishing of the Gulf of Carpentaria. The teeth from those regulations were then drawn by the Senate on the most spurious grounds, the grounds in question being that there was no need for the teeth in the Bill because what the Bill sought to do would happen anyway; in other words what members of the Opposition said they feared they themselves asserted would never happen. In that way the logic or illogic of the Opposition's collective mind apparently operated.

In this Bill we have more ignorant and opportunistic meddling in the loan raising program, the effect of which, as I said before-that is of the amendments-is to deny the Commonwealth Government the opportunity to borrow no matter how advantageous that opportunity may be in the first three months of the financial year, thereby, of course, potentially and almost certainly from time to time actually increasing the cost of borrowing to the taxpayer.

For those people who parade themselves as representatives of the private sector, I ask: How would the private sector like to have legislation passed by this Parliament which precluded a private company from borrowing in the first three months of its financial year? The private sector, quite justifiably, of course, would be enraged by such legislation and yet that is precisely the curb which the Opposition proposes to impose on the Government. In that way, as the Treasurer (Mr Keating) succinctly described it, the swill of Australian politics, that swill which has been flushed into the Senate, sabotaged good government. This swill, this Opposition, is comprised of misfits and mediocrities who have been kicked out of the House of Representatives and people who could never get elected to it, including those who, standing alone, got 1.5 per cent of the primary votes.

In an attempt to justify this act of sabotage we were subjected to pontification at some length from Senator Stone, as pompous as it was spurious, about Senate or parliamentary supervision of borrowings. His amendments, by the way, do nothing to enhance parliamentary supervision of borrowings; they just preclude in the first three months of the financial year those borrowings proceeding no matter how advantageous the term may be. This is the same Senator Stone, I remind everyone, who is a member of the Queensland branch of the National Party who obviously can cope without any difficulty at all with the redneck Parliament of that State which scrutinises nothing--

TALK.START.PARA: —Not even a public accounts committee.

—Not even a public accounts committee; and now, on spurious grounds of parliamentary scrutiny, he proposes to move amendments which cancel opportunities to borrow advantageously in the first three months of the year. I say that those grounds are spurious because any scrutiny of borrowings is, by its nature, ex-post. I suppose that is just as well too. Who, for example, would be willing-I think even the Opposition might baulk at this-to allow someone such as former Senator Vigor to get involved in any meaningful way in the scrutiny of the Government's borrowing program? So meanwhile Senator Stone will have no problems at all in coping with that outrageous Government and Parliament of Queensland, but he then pompously and piously attempts to impose, for no valid reason whatever, a measure which will potentially and almost certainly from time to time impose additional borrowing costs on the taxpayers.

SPEECH.PARA: It should be apparent from what I have said that the Government will not accept these amendments. I understand that the Australian Democrats are supporting them. I am advised that it will require major redrafting of the legislation to accommodate those amendments if the Government chose to do so which will close off borrowing opportunities, possibly advantageous borrowing opportunities, for an even longer period at greater cost to the taxpayers, something imposed by people who have power without responsibility, either fiscal or moral.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 1, clause 1, leave out ``Loans'', insert ``Loan''.
(2) Page 2, clause 3, leave out the definitions of ``next financial year'', ``relevant appropriation Act'' and ``supply period'', insert the following definition:
`` `relevant appropriation Act', in relation to the current financial year, means:
(a) the Supply Act (No. 1) 1987-88; or

(b) an Act, whether passed before or after the commencement of this Act, appropriating the Consolidated Revenue Fund for the service of that financial year, being an Act that is expressed to have effect subject to this Act.''.
(3) Page 2, clause 4, leave out subclause (2).
(4) Page 2, subclause 4 (3), leave out ``or (2)''.
(5) Page 3, clause 5, leave out subclause (2).
(6) Page 4, clause 9, leave out subclauses (2) and (3), insert the following subclauses:
``(2) Subsection (1) does not affect the expenditure of money appropriated under the heading ``ADVANCE TO THE MINISTER FOR FINANCE'' in a relevant appropriation Act for the current financial year.
``(3) Nothing in this Act shall be taken to authorise expenditure (otherwise than for the expenses of borrowing) after 30 June 1988.''.

In the course of my remarks in the second reading debate I have already indicated why the Opposition has taken the action of moving these amendments. These amendments are directed to one purpose and one purpose only: to provide the Government with precisely the same degree of borrowing authority that it has always had under Loan Bills, not Loans Bills, year by year throughout the history of Federation. I express my considerable disappointment at the nature of the remarks with which Senator Walsh wound up the second reading debate this evening.

TALK.START.PARA: —They cut very close to the bone.

—No, they did not cut in any way close to the bone. What they did was diminish his standing as a senator and a Minister of the Crown. I suggest that is a matter to which he should begin to give some attention. Be that as it may, I do not wish to indulge in cross chamber argy-bargy with the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh; I merely express my disappointment with the attitude that the Minister took in winding up the second reading debate and in his attempt, once again, to bully the Opposition and in this case also the Australian Democrats-those on this side of the chamber-into acceptance of his point of view. We on this side have become unduly familiar with that bullying process even in the very short space of time in which I have been in this place; it was, indeed, central to the urgency motion moved earlier today by my colleague Senator Puplick in relation to a quite different matter; namely, the need for the Government to cease its campaign of smear and misrepresentation on a quite different subject-the Australia Card debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Within less than two hours of the winding up of that earlier debate Senator Walsh used his bullying tactics on what he purports to describe as a machinery Bill and in response to what I believe any independent observer reading the Hansard of this date tomorrow or at some future time will judge to have been objective, balanced and perfectly proper comments from this side of the House expressing a perfectly proper constitutional point of view. We have had from Senator Walsh not merely bullying but also a further example of his personal proclivity to descend to the level of personal abuse. It is a matter of great regret to see a Minister who in many respects has a capacity to behave as a Dr Jekyll descending into the role of Mr Hyde. I do not propose to extend that aspect of my remarks further.

As I said, the Opposition has one purpose and one purpose only in moving these amendments in the chamber this afternoon, and that is to provide the Government with precisely the same authority to undertake borrowings in the financial year 1987-88 as it has had in every previous year since this Federation came into being and since the Federal Parliament came into operation. Senator Walsh said-I believe I heard him say this in the course of his ill-judged, ill-chosen and ill-tempered remarks-that these proposed amendments represented a curb being placed upon the Government. I can only say that it is a curb that was placed on all previous governments for 86 years, if that is the right way of putting it; and for these purposes I shall accept Senator Walsh's formulation. The only novel aspect of this whole matter is not this so-called curb that Senator Walsh affects to discern-I emphasise those words-in the amendments moved by the Opposition and supported by the Australian Democrats. That is not the change. The change is that in this Parliament today we have a government that has grown so arrogant that it regards itself as no longer being properly subject to the same curbs, to use the word the Minister used, to which all its predecessors have been subject.
