That is the proper sense in which the present situation differs from previous such situations.

I repeat that the sole purpose of moving this body of amendments is to do one thing and one thing only, and that is to give the Government the same borrowing authority that it has had on all previous occasions and, in doing so, to return the Loans Bill to the form in which it has been presented on past occasions. We have moved these amendments not for the purposes that Senator Walsh's fevered imagination has conjured up so that he could engage in a quite synthetic burst of indignation in closing the second reading debate; our purpose, as I said during the second reading debate, and as Senator Haines and my other colleagues on this side of the chamber said, is to preserve to this Parliament, and particularly to this chamber which has a particular role in the scrutiny and review of governmental actions and legislation, the rights, prerogatives and constitutional entitlements and duties of this place in the face of an overwhelmingly arrogant Government that continues to seek to usurp those rights and authorities and to enhance the power not of the Government or the Labor Party but of the Executive.

I inform Senator Walsh that we on this side of the chamber will not submit to those sorts of bullying and power-seeking tactics from members on the Government side. If Senator Walsh is unable to understand that, I regret to say that he is due for much more disturbing afternoons than those that he seems to have had thus far. I suggest that he might like to examine his attitude towards these matters and his attitude towards the Senate. Indeed, he might like to examine his attitude towards the role of this chamber in the processes of government. The Senate is not the Government's chamber. The Government has a majority in the House of Representatives, otherwise in all but the most unusual circumstances it would not be the Government. What this Government does, particularly in the House of Representatives, is use its numbers to drive through the House of Representatives an enormous sausage-like string of legislation, disregarding the balance of argument put forward in debate. I am very glad to say that that is not the way in which the Senate goes about discharging its duties. In the limited way in which I personally hope to take some part in that process, my attitude certainly will not involve that kind of executive power grabbing that this Government continually embarks upon in this Parliament.

To be fair to some members on the Government side of the Senate, I do them the credit of not believing that the sort of attitude expressed in Senator Walsh's ill-tempered remarks in winding up the second reading debate about the attitude of the Executive Government represents the views of all honourable senators-I emphasise the words `honourable senators'-on the Government side of the House. Undoubtedly his remarks represent the views of some of them, perhaps the majority of them. However, I do not believe they represent the views of all of them. I take pleasure and indeed comfort from that thought.

I do not propose to speak in detail to each of the amendments because, as I have said, their purpose is quite straightforward. It is to strike out of this Bill the supply clause to which we on this side of the House in our earlier remarks took objection. Against that background the amendments are straightforward. Some of them are consequential upon the major amendment. I refer, for example, to amendment (4) which simply seeks to leave out reference to sub-clause (2) elsewhere in the Bill which will be necessarily consequent upon an earlier amendment, if that be the will of the chamber. Without further ado, I commend the amendments to the Senate.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Stone's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to order of the Senate of 16 September 1987 I lay on the table of the Senate certain answers to questions relating to the Parliament House Construction Authority which were asked during the proceedings of Estimates Committee E in April 1987. Copies of the answers have been distributed in the chamber. The remaining answers will be tabled pursuant to the order as soon as they are available.

DEBATE.TITLE: OCCUPATIONAL SUPERANNUATION STANDARDS BILL 1987INSURANCE AND SUPERANNUATION COMMISSIONER BILL 1987INSURANCE AND SUPERANNUATION COMMISSIONER (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 October 1987, on motion by Senator Tate:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill 1987, the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner Bill 1987 and the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1987, which are being debated together in the Senate this evening, give effect to a number of announcements by the Government and particularly by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) over a lengthy period. They incorporate proposals to establish a new body called the Insurance and Superannuation Commission which is to be headed by a new statutory officer. That Commission will bring together the existing offices of Insurance Commissioner, Life Insurance Commissioner and Australian Government Actuary, as well as the proposed office relating to occupational superannuation.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to say that while the subject of these Bills is very important and we on this side of the House naturally support the proposals taken in their general framework in order to give effect to a somewhat different method of approaching the question of occupational superannuation from that which has obtained until recently, there are some concerns about the way in which these Bills have been drafted-I do not want to embark again on the debate that we have had in this place a couple of times today-to provide for very considerable powers on the part, particularly, of the new Office of the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner which are not really set out in the body of these Bills.

Yesterday, in Estimates Committee C I had the opportunity to question one of the officers of the Department of the Treasury who were present, Mr Roger Freeney. It emerged from that process that, whereas these Bills do not contain detailed provisions, for example, for the standards to be applied by the new Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner, nevertheless, a great deal of discussion has already gone on between the Government and, particularly, the Treasury and the present statutory officers which has been directed towards setting down standards and agreeing upon those standards. I hope that I am not misquoting the response given to me yesterday evening in the Estimates Committee but I believe that I was told there that the regulations which will in due course govern these standards have already reached a very advanced stage of drafting. I think it is something of a pity, particularly because of the very large ambit which the proposed legislation gives to legislating by way of regulation, that the Government did not choose, in bringing forward these Bills, to foreshadow at the same time the regulations, insofar as they are already basically in being, which would give effect to the Bills themselves-that is to say, the regulations which would put flesh upon the very sketchy statutory bones which are presently before us.

The limited time available to the Opposition for consultations gives rise to some concern, and I will return to that point. In the limited time which has been available to the Opposition to undertake consultations with interested parties outside the Parliament-and there are a great many interested parties outside the Parliament as far as these pieces of legislation are concerned-very frankly, we have had a wide variety of views put to us. I think it is fair to say that there are people, particularly those in the industry who are close to the engine rooms of superannuation schemes and so on-people in the major life offices and people who run various superannuation funds-who are, quite naturally, very anxious to have this legislation on the statute book. After all, they have been waiting for legislation for a very long time. From the day when the Treasurer (Mr Keating) first started talking about these matters-the Government once again having had its policy determined for it by the Australian Council of Trade Unions-it has been a very long time until the Government has finally brought forward this legislation.

It is true that some part of that intervening period has been taken up by an election called by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in double breach of promises to the contrary. But, even if one makes allowances for that loss of the parliamentary timetable, the fact remains that the Government has been extremely dilatory in bringing forward this legislation. Meanwhile, the industry and those whose pecuniary interests are directly involved simply have to make do with Press releases and their imagination as to what, in legislative terms, those Press releases might finally boil down to. That is a very risky business for people whose livelihoods and professional reputations are at stake in these matters.

It is natural-and I understand the feelings on the part of many in what I call the industry-that now that the Government has finally brought forward some legislation, people do not wish it to delay further in putting it on the statute book because at least that will then give some legislative basis for proceeding. Those people, with interests of that kind, naturally see themselves as then being able to talk-as indeed they have, no doubt, already been talking-to the statutory officers concerned, with a view to making their representations to them more effective than they can currently do when there is no legislative framework within which to do so.

In the best of all possible worlds that is certainly not an unacceptable way of proceeding. The problem that one has on this side of the chamber, particularly in light of some recent experiences, including the experience today, is that one does not really feel that one can trust the present Government to behave in a straightforward, frank and candid manner. Even at the outset of today's proceedings we had a statement from Senator Gareth Evans, who I am glad to see has joined us in the chamber, which purported to be-and, in one sense, undoubtedly was-concerned with deregulation of the airlines and with a motion to bring to an end the two-airline policy. But, as honourable senators on this side of the chamber pointed out, it was really concerned with a quite different matter-namely, the Executive's decision to privatise Australian Airlines.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a very intellectually undistinguished analysis.

—I thank Senator Evans. I am glad to have his dispassionate and objective judgment on that question. But let us stick to the facts. Let me re-assert the point I was making, namely, that what we had this morning was the Government putting forward in this chamber a statement which had to do with a particular matter but which had much more to do with a matter not referred to in the statement. That is the sort of behaviour which leads us on this side of the House to suffer from a sense of unease, to use no harsher term, from time to time-indeed, more or less perpetually-about the extent to which we can trust this Government, about this Government's bona fides. I make that point to say that the views the Opposition has had from some people in the industry are understandable from the point of view of the people who form that industry. They are people who behave honourably and straightforwardly and who want to get on with running their businesses without being messed around by governments, particularly this one, and they tend to assume that governments behave as they do. But governments do not always behave as they do. I refer not just to this Government. To be fair to Senator Evans and his colleagues, one has to say that governments generally do not behave as those people do, but this Government particularly does not. Therefore, one has to approach the matter with some caution.

SPEECH.PARA: That caution is reinforced by other representations of one kind or another which have come to us from bodies which are not themselves specifically concerned or involved in the industry but which are nevertheless knowledgeable about these matters and have a more detached and objective viewpoint-certainly a more disinterested one-than do some of the others I have just been referring to. They have considerable doubts about what the Government is proposing. They certainly have considerable doubts about the enormous black holes in this legislation-black holes into which, it would seem, all manner of very important decision-making processes will disappear. To the extent that that can result in legislation by regulation, this raises some of the questions which have been concerning people on this side of the chamber, and, I suspect, some of those on the government side also, for some time and especially since this new session began.

Let me mention one or two of these views. I think it would be improper to name the author of a particular communication I have received, as he is entitled to anonymity, but I assure the Government senators that he is a highly responsible and knowledgeable person in these matters. He has taken the trouble to write a letter to me which reads:

In my view the Government sought to rush unsatisfactory legislation through before the election. The activities of people such as myself with the help of Senator Short and others achieved a deferment.
Indeed, it was because of action taken in this chamber on the eve of the election that a deferment of that earlier legislation was obtained. The letter goes on:
A deferment which allows a proper consideration to be given by Parliament to this legislation.
The writer goes on to say:

The proposed legislation would basically allow the appointment of a commissioner and give that commissioner power to make regulations on any aspect of superannuation as he thinks fit. Superannuation is a long-term arrangement for any individual and while reform is desirable--
I share that sentiment entirely as, I am sure, do all senators on this side of the chamber. The letter goes on:
I am concerned that the present Government has moved too quickly and without adequate consultation with experts in the field. I and others of like mind do not wish to see the legislation defeated.

That is not the gravamen of the letter to me and it is certainly not the gravamen of the remarks which I think I am safe in saying will be coming from this side of the chamber. I quote the letter further:
Rather, we wish to see adequate brakes placed on the ability of a Treasurer or other Ministers to make changes overnight without proper consultation.

The writer says that he would like to see the legislation amended, and, indeed, he has been good enough to propose some draft amendments, which we could come to at an appropriate time depending upon developments between then and now. The point I am trying to convey to Government senators particularly is that this is not just a place where the Government has the right-indeed, here it does not have the power either, and that is the only thing that matters to it-to bring forward Bills of this extremely general and broad kind and expect the Opposition and the Australian Democrats simply to accept them, wave them through, pull out the green flag and say, `Off you go'. We do not believe that is a reasonable expectation on the Government's part, and we certainly do not propose to confirm it, even if it should be held.

I emphasise that we do not approach this matter with any mischievous intent or any intent to block the legislation. We approach it from the standpoint that this is a very important matter, one in which I suspect the aims and objectives of those on the Government side-the ones they would profess to anyway-would not be very different from those of senators on this side. Certainly, the ends are in substantial agreement, although perhaps not total agreement, but one is talking about the means-in this case the legislative means. We are talking about Bills which confer very broad powers upon appointed statutory officials.

I have another letter from a quite different quarter, in this case a quarter with legal orientation, not an industry orientation as such. The correspondent I was quoting previously does have a relationship with the industry although he is totally independent. He is not a part of the industry in that sense; he is an independent and objective critic of it. The further representation I have received comes from a different orientation, a legal one. The writer is speaking, in effect, on behalf of a particular body. I feel sure in this case that he would not object to my making the source of the representation known but as I have not had time to get that clearance I do not intend to make it known at this stage of the debate.

The pith of this particular representation is the stated belief that the appeal procedures contained in the Bill are regarded as totally unsatisfactory. In one sense we could say that that has nothing to do with the framework of superannuation provisions as such but it is, of course, a matter about which again, as I think Senator Haines said in her remarks this afternoon on quite a different topic, the Senate is peculiarly sensitive and about which it ought to be peculiarly sensitive. It ought to be peculiarly sensitive about the rights of individuals-in this case, the rights of a great many individuals-because the superannuation arrangements which are to be constituted under this legislation cover the financial interests of a great many people.

Not to put too fine a point on it, what we have here at this stage-I have to say it on behalf of the Opposition-is something of a dilemma. We certainly have no desire to hold up this legislation. Certainly, we have no desire to hold it up unnecessarily, but we have a very considerable worry that by voting it through the Senate we may be participating in a process about which we have certainly not had time to satisfy ourselves fully. We may also be participating in a process which will result in two things which we regard as inherently objectionable. I refer to the giving of much greater power to unelected persons than those unelected persons should rightly have in the kind of parliamentary democracy in which we have the privilege of living. Secondly, we may also deny some people some rights that they might otherwise be justifiably expecting to receive.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you know what those rights are going to be if the Bill has not yet introduced standards?
—Precisely, Senator Archer. Senator Archer makes the point that since the standards are not contained in the Bills-
—Watson!

—I beg Senator Watson's pardon. I apologise for my mistake, which was made because we have such a high quality of senator from Tasmania. One must always remember that one's colleagues are uniformly of good quality. As Senator Watson said, since the standards are not even contained in the Bill, it is impossible to arrive at any rational conclusion, a priori, about whether the Bills will damage people's rights. I have to say that I think the Government has been seriously defective in the manner in which these Bills have been drafted. I said I would come back to this point--
—You are coming back to it for the fifth time.

—I thank Senator Collins for that comment. One could perhaps understand if these Bills had been part of a rushed process. One could understand if, as a result of some statement last week by the Government, this legislation had to be rushed into the House and into the Senate. One could understand that, although perhaps one would not necessarily in that case condone the fact that the Bills are expressed in such very general terms and that they give rise to the disquiet which I have been expressing, which Senator Watson, by way of interjection, expressed and which, I suspect, other senators on this side of the House will express. It is no good Senator Collins or other honourable senators opposite trying to ridicule the proper expression of concern on the part of senators on the Opposition side of the chamber about these matters. I have to say that if the Government still has some learning to do in regard to the way it behaves in this place we will be perfectly prepared to stay here long enough to teach it. That is enough. I do not wish to pursue that point. I am not seeking to be provocative.
—Have a go; be provocative!
—I wish Senator Haines would not urge me to do so because I am sure that if I did it would begin to unravel that lovely accord to which she referred earlier this afternoon.
—Don't allow yourself to be intimidated by the Democrats.
—They are not nearly as big as some honourable senators on the other side of the House, Senator Collins.
—The Government needs men of substance.

—Yes, I quite agree. I think that I may have said enough to reveal, at least in a preliminary way, that the Opposition really does have some legitimate concerns about the manner in which these Bills are drafted. I was saying before I was--
—Rudely interrupted.

—Not at all; not rudely interrupted. I was saying before I was assisted by Senator Collins that the Press statements giving rise to these Bills have the dust gathering on them they are so old. They have been around for ages. We have a situation in which the Government appears unable to be more explicit on the provisions of these Bills. With those closing comments I simply say that we will want to have another look at the legislation in the further time we will now have.
—He is rounding out nicely.

—Senator Collins invites me to round out. I will be glad to take up his invitation. I know it is offered in the spirit of conciliation and I accept it entirely in that spirit. I believe that we may wish to think further about these matters. Certainly, the attitude of honourable senators on the other side of the chamber is a powerful inducement for us to do so. I leave my remarks at that point.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Mr Robert Wenham-Welcome Home Parade for Vietnam Veterans

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being almost 7.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that many honourable senators have other engagements tonight and I will therefore seek to be brief. This is the first occasion on which I have been able to come to the Senate since my return from parliamentary business to report in the adjournment debate on a matter concerning the father-in-law of one of my constituents who appears to have been detained in Saudi Arabia. It is a matter which is causing some concern. If, indeed, he has been detained we would like the Government to respond. I understand the facts I am putting forward are ex parte and represent the case put to me by one side only. I report them with that caveat.

SPEECH.PARA: Apparently Mr Robert Wenham went to Saudi Arabia about 10 years ago to construct a cattle rearing and meat processing facility. He invested his own money as seed money to help get the project off the ground. The further funds to complete the project, which was then 90 per cent complete, were not forthcoming from the banks when they found their security gone, because the land securing the loan had already been mortgaged.

The company on whose behalf Mr Wenham was undertaking the project, together with Wenham's sponsorship, fell into the hands of a Saudi Arabian prince, Ahmed Al Sudairi, who had somehow acquired the project land from the company. The family says that he stole it, but I have no knowledge of whether that is true. The prince then demanded that Mr Wenham hand over the control of the project to him. The result was that over the last six years no further progress was made in building the project. During this time, the remaining cash reserves of the company disappeared.

It appears that in Saudi Arabia all foreign workers must be sponsored by a Saudi national. It appears further that on arrival foreign workers must hand over their passports and are then issued with an internal Saudi identity card. In order to leave the kingdom, the workers must get the sponsor to reverse the process. The workers get their passports back, yield their identity cards, then leave. Under Saudi law, any sponsor can prevent a foreigner leaving the country by stating to the authorities that he does not wish to return the passport because there are matters that are still pending and incomplete. In such a circumstance, the Saudi national is supposed to go to the civil rights court to state his reasons for doing that and must deposit a bond to cover any losses which might be suffered by the foreigner as a result of detention.

It appears that Mr Bob Wenham has been detained. He has not been able to obtain his passport or leave the country. I have been informed, and I cannot check this point, that the sponsor, Prince Ahmed Al Sudairi, was too powerful to bother with the civil rights court or the cash bond. In fact he simply has not given back the passport. My constituent is therefore stuck in Saudi Arabia. The Sudairi family claimed that Mr Wenham had misappropriated the company's money. However, two audits by international accountants did not substantiate this claim. The audits could not find any fault with the accounts provided by Mr Wenham. Despite this, the Sudairi family continued to pursue Mr Wenham through the courts. It has eventually been decided that the matter should go to arbitration.

Meanwhile, the Sudairi family has had judgment delivered against it; it has had judgment debts awarded against it on its personal guarantees to the banks. Several governments are pressing King Fahd to see that these debts are paid by the Sudairi family. But while Mr Wenham is held in the country the Sudairi family can hold off these creditors by stating that it is trying to get its money back from Mr Wenham. If he were to leave the kingdom, this excuse might disappear. I have been told that the Saudi Foreign Minister is on record as stating that Mr Wenham can leave the country at any time. My constituent disputes this. He said it is simply not true.

Mr Wenham is alleged to have maintained that the Australian Government is fully aware that only representations which could be made at the highest level, Minister to Minister, will secure his release. There have not been representations at the highest level; there have been some periodic conversations between the Australian Embassy and assistants at the Saudi foreign ministry. These have not had any effect and are unlikely to have any effect. I am concerned, first, that the Australian Government appears to want Mr Wenham to submit to arbitration when the Saudi Government has the power to block the result of any arbitration-and, after all, we are dealing with a very powerful member of the Saudi community. Secondly, Mr Wenham has no proper legal representation. Thirdly, the matters to be arbitrated are unknown, the process is biased and the procedure is lengthy. Fourthly, Mr Wenham has no money to cover the fees. After all, he is not supposed to be working in Saudi Arabia and I do not wish to inform the Senate how he is managing to survive. If Mr Wenham had a job, it would obviously be illegal.

My advise suggests that, contrary to the statements of the Australian Ambassador to Saudi Arabia, until very recently the Embassy has hardly ever responded to Mr Wenham's letters and has not been in regular contact with him. I interpolate that I said at the beginning that this is the account I have been given. I have not been able to test it. It is ex parte, but it is of great concern to one of my constituents. Despite all the problems, Mr Wenham has refused even to consider attempting to escape because, he claims, he has done nothing wrong. From the records I hold, this appears to be the case.

Mr Wenham would like recompense for his investment and for the events that have occurred involving him in that country. He would like to have his passport back and be able to move freely between countries. Mr Wenham is an Australian citizen and he is being held in Saudi Arabia. He does not want the Saudis to be able to say that he ran away. In addition, attempting to escape from Saudi Arabia is a very risky business. A person who was unsuccessful in doing that could easily spend a considerable time under appalling conditions in gaol, if the person was not executed.

In summary, it appears that the Australian Government needs to address the problem and tell us about the facts behind the detainment of Mr Bob Wenham in Saudi Arabia over the last six years. We need to be told about his continuing detention, the facts behind it, the loss of the money he has invested in Saudi Arabia and, of course, the loss of the potential rewards of the project and how he is supposed to react to what is intervention by a very powerful citizen of that country to prevent his leaving. In addition, the Government should respond to the suggestion by the Professor of International Law at Oxford University that long term detention on a civil matter is against international conventions-and that appears to be what is happening.

So it would seem that Mr Wenham's detention is in breach of both Saudi law and international conventions, for the reasons I have set out. I believe that the Australian Government should feel that it is under an obligation to intervene to assist any of its citizens in such a situation. I have presented the case of one citizen caught in another country, without possession of his passport and unable to leave. I hope the Government will look at the question of diplomatic protection, which should arise under international conventions, for an Australian passport holder caught in this appalling situation. I invite the Government to give a formal response, if not immediately, as soon as it is able.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened carefully to what Senator Peter Baume said on the Wenham case. It is, of course, a matter which has already received a degree of attention in the media. I am sure that under those circumstances the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) is already aware of at least the general circumstances of the matter. But I will ensure that Senator Baume's remarks are conveyed to him and I will seek and early response, as requested by Senator Baume.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. Australia witnessed recently what I think by any measure was a highly successful welcome home parade for Vietnam veterans. I have been asked by representatives of Northern Territory Vietnam veterans to place on record their appreciation of politicians of all parties who assisted in representations made to them and in the essential travel that was provided. In particular, I have been asked to place on record the appreciation of the Northern Territory Vietnam veterans of the Federal Government and especially its Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, for the essential assistance that was provided in the provision of transport to make the parade the success that it was.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 7.38 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following paper was tabled:
Export Control Act-Export Control (Orders) Regulations-Orders 1987 No. 16-Export Control (Fees) as amended (Amendment).
The following answer to a question was circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 15 September 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce aware of instances of passengers departing Australia from Sydney International Airport who have been able to leave the country without a passport after processing by Customs.
(2) Is the Minister aware of instances of passengers departing Australia from any other airport who have been able to leave the country without a passport after processing by Customs.
(3) Do Customs officers have any powers to prevent the departure from Australia of passengers without passports; if so, what are these powers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: In normal circumstances, the Australian Customs Service requires all passengers leaving Australia through one of our International airports to produce a valid passport as proof of identity.
In special circumstances however, it is not unusual for persons to depart Australia without a passport.
This could occur when:
there is a death in the family and there is no time to wait for the issue of a passport;
there is loss or theft of a passport and travel must be undertaken before a replacement can be issued; or
a foreign national (particularly from New Zealand) has no valid passport but wishes to return to take up residence in their country of origin.
In all these cases, the Australian Customs Service would expect suitable proof of identity to be produced.
In every instance, the final departure is contingent upon the willingness of the airline to carry persons without valid passports.
Officers of the Australian Customs service have no powers to prevent the departure from Australia of passengers without passports. Where they are aware of a legal prohibition to travel such as:
a Departure Prohibition Order issued pursuant to Sub-regulation 16 (1) of the Taxation Administration Act 1953; or
a Family Law Restraining Order issued pursuant to Section 70a of the Family Law Act.
action will be taken to detain those passengers identified in the Order pending action by the relevant authority, such as the Australian Federal Police.
